GAME: The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game
RANK: 102
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Recommended by Joel D., Chris S., the Solo Players Group and Jason L. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
It is a punishing game that keeps you on edge, and unlike every other LCG, you can't really be "behind".  What I mean by that is, you don't have to drop a ton of money to catch up.  You can buy the scenarios you want to play, or the expansions that have the cards you want to build the deck you want and move at your own pace because you're not playing against someone in a competitive setting.  Artwork is stunning and solo and cooperative play offer their own challenges and good times.

I'll persevere a while though. And an extra mark for the implementation of the theme.

RATING: N/A
This is definitely one of my current favorites as it is handy for me to take on the road when I travel. I started when the game came out and have been keeping up with all the expansion packs and deluxe expansions. 

I own five copies of the base game and every deluxe expansion and expansions packs from each of the cycles. I also own the POD quests and playmats from various events. I also own a 4-player set of the wooden tokens made by Team Covenant.

The only thing I don't own are any of the nightmare quests and I am quite okay with that. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The biggest thing that surprised me about this game is how thematic it is. I was simply expecting a cool card game with pretty cards. Not only did I get that, but the missions, the choices you have, the cards, and the card effect all make so much sense thematically. If you are a Tolkien fan you will NOT be disappointed. The game takes you (and you band of heroes that you can choose) on a journey within Middle Earth with varying tasks, enemies, and locations to explore. 

Another thing that surprised me was how great of a Solo game this is. Not too take away from the co-op aspect of this game - it is definitely one of the best - if not the best - 2 player (co-op) game I've played. But its by far the best solo-player game I've played (admittedly I haven't played very many, but I guess that's because I never appealed to me in the first place.)

If you've been researching this game, no doubt you've heard about plethora of expansion packs and something called 'deck-building.' As for expansions, I haven't purchased any yet, though I plan to because there is a lot more adventures that I'd love to go on! There's even a fan expansion with cards and quests to do with the First Age! 
As for deck-building, my only experience with that has been with Pokemon cards back when I was a young kid :P
I haven't actually put together my own deck yet, and before buying this game I'll admit I wasn't to stoked about it, but after getting a bunch of games in using the pre-made decks, I can see the appeal, and even necessity of it to get the most out of this game. I look forward to the day I get more cards, and can start putting together my own 'deck of adventurers' and go on more quests! All that said, I haven't done any of that yet and still enjoy this game immensely.

Anyways, I really think this is a well designed game. It really doesn't feel like a 'card game' to me but instead an adventure in Middle Earth. If that interests you, then I definitely recommend this game to you.

RATING: 7
Enjoyed the LOTR theme, and the game was inelligently made. I bought it for solo play, which made the game VERY difficult. Playing solo as two players is better, but circling the table over and over isn't the best experience. Still enjoy the depth of the game, and it made me want to buy expansions. Definite bonus that it made me crave more and think way to long about deck building strategy, but negative points for the high cost for only 3 single (and one or two ridiculously hard, given the limited player cards) scenarios. Would maybe bump up the score if I had a gaming partner.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I do like this game quite a bit -- enjoying both the theme and the way the game mechanics work. A couple ticks: 1. I bought it for solo play, which is MUCH harder than I thought it would be (playing solo as two players is fine but not my favorite). 2. There are only three scenarios included, one of which is fairly impossible to win without shedding more money out on extra cards/expansions. Still fun but a nuisance. I enjoy the rigorous deck building but not the necessity to spend tons of money to build something great. If I had someone else to play with who was also into deck building, I'd probably raise my rating a notch or two.

Overall mechanics intriguing enough.And the possibility to play it solo or cooperatively just sold it for me.

And Fantasy setting is my all time favorite. Of course, Lord of the Rings, my bible. When is it coming?

Finnally here. Living to my expectations so far, and that is a lot to say (not many games do). Narrative is here, quest stages feel like a story, every quest is like a different puzzle where you need to adapt your deck strategies to survive...

Plays great solo and looking forward to some cooperative games. And the art is fantastic. Now I canÂ´t wait for next chapters coming out.

Might make it to my Top 10 faster than I thought.

RATING: 7.5
This is possibly my favorite game, but I can't justify the LCG format. I would rank it higher if it were more affordable and if the average card quality were higher or more consistent; the core set in particular has some really lame cards (and some excellent ones). I'd be very interested in a revised edition that was also more affordable.

Apart from those issues, I'd rate this a 9.5. It's my favorite co-op.

RATING: 10
After many, many plays of this game, I still find it to be an excellent game with lots of options and tough decisions to be made.  However, it has started to feel somewhat samey to me as my wife and I have done the same quests to death.  I'll continue to play the game, and I'm sure the first expansion pack will re-energize my interest, but right now I'm feeling tired of the game, thus I've downgraded my rating from a 9.5 to an 8.5.

UPDATE (11-6-13): The comments above were written 5-30-11, back when the game was brand new and a delay in the release of the first expansion caused the game to feel a bit played out.  I can say now, almost two and a half years later, that the game is and has been my second favorite game for quite some time.  It's simply a fantastic game system that has been constantly evolving and breaking new ground with each expansion.  There are so many expansions out now that I haven't even been able to play all of them, and the game has maintained a high level of quality with all of its releases that I've played.  I can see myself playing the game for many more years to come.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
(Solo)
4/13/13 - After 7 plays i've played the first scenario exclusively as i've tried to learn how it all works. Spirit looks to be the foundation of any successful deck at this point. It's questing and enemy nullification cards make it indispincible. Leadership pairs nicely with it, with solid resource generation and versatility. Lore is good for support with healing and card draw. I haven't had much luck with Tactics, the only sphere where i've lost a hero...both times Gimli. 

As far as deck construction; it really comes down to finding what you like, or want to accomplish and then build it carefully. A big part is concentration vs. versatility. The more concentrated a deck is, the more frequent you will get the cards you need, but you wont be able to do things outside your zone. The more versatile your deck is, the better able you will be to meet various challenges, but you'll find yourself with more unneeded cards in your hand.

4/20/13 - After much himming and hawwing, I came to the realization tht i'm just not in love with this game. Not enough to countinue down the rabbit hole at this time. it's a solid, beautiful game, but it just doesn't grab me. I think it's too mechanical. When I look at Aragorn, Legolas or Gimli, I don't see characters; I see stats and abilities. It's the same way throughout the game. While the mechanics are good, there are too many other games out and coming soon to pump $200 - $300 in this system, espically when so many of the expansion cards are trash. I believe I have enough to be happy for now.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.85
A Lord of the Rings themed cooperative game?  Awesome!  Well, except I'm not so sure the cooperative part of it really works out so well.  Most of the scenarios have fairly clear strategies that must be utilized for the heroes to win, so it isn't really a game of "assemble whatever deck you'd like and go off on an adventure."  Generally decks have to be assembled with the specific goal of completing a specific scenario, which means that the game is cooperative only so far as you discuss with your companions what the correct strategy is for whatever scenario you've chosen to play.

Once everyone is playing by the dictated strategy to complete the particular scenario, it doesn't really feel like every player (or any player) is adding continual input to make the game feel cooperative.  

Works okay as a solitaire, though.  Nice art in the game, also.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Got this mainly because it's great in solo mode.  It's also *tough*.  In solo play it's almost impossible to succeed at the last campaign unless editing the base deck and getting a bit lucky. Some would say that the game is too difficult and that this is rather transparent ploy to force you to buy more cards... Anyway, it's a decent price for the base set, with great art work and nice components, so maybe buying an expansion or two isn't unreasonable.  Great theme and fans of LOTR, co-ops and fantasy genre will really enjoy this.  Shame it's hard to get hold of the expansions.

RATING: 6
Constructing decks before playing is not my thing. Honing decks after playing is not my thing.

Having said that, this is a lovely looking game with a very interesting play order. It is nice that it can be played coop or solo and can easily be played in 30 to 45 minutes on easy level.

Playing one-handed seems very difficult without constructing decks (see first comment).

As the challenge seems to come before the game is played, it isn't a game I want to continually play.

RATING: 7
Bought on June 4th 2011 at the UK Games Expo, Birmingham. FFG have made an error here in that the number of cards available in this core set is in my opnion insufficient to provide a good variety of games, and even to allow any success at the harder two out of only three scenarios provided. Another 30 cards for aother 5$ or Â£ would have helped hugely. So to feel pressured into buying a SECOND core set just to make it work is poor. The other LCGs available are not as bad as this one for this sort of error. Call of Chthulu and Game of thrones DO play well enough out of the core set. This is a bitch to win esp. solo. Excellent, excellent ideas and artwork and quality let down by insufficient material.

RATING: 9.5
A very good game which is so time-consuming on the one hand and expensive on the other hand that selling my childeren to some human smugglers seemed the only solution to kill those two birds with one stone... luckily I have no children! (anymore?)
Set-up usually takes quite some time and can be a bit flimsy. Theme is awesome. Mechanics are well-thought of and are tied with the story (E.g. Gimli's skill really feels like a perfect fit for Gimli).

Theme (artwork/story/...)
2/2
Gameplay (smooth play/player interaction/strategy&tactics/depth)
5/5
Fun factor (can you afford a smile during play?)
2.5/3



Passage Through Mirkwood: Good quest to get to know the game (but more difficult than its DL suggests!)
Wins/losses: 5/1

Journey Down the Anduin: used to be my favourite quest (when I didn't have much more than the core set). This quest isn't perfect, but when you get through the start, it becomes quite enjoyable.
Wins/losses: 8/4

Escape from Dol Guldur: Random shmandom. I won this quest once, just because not one objective was guarded at the beginning (drew 3 treacheries). Very difficult quest.
Wins/losses: 1/1

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
There's a lot to like in this game. I enjoy the theme so maybe I'm a bit biased. It's certainly a big plus for many people. I especially like that they are not following the books. So all of the characters that you would expect are in the game or will be but the game doesn't feel scripted. But there still has to be a good game there somewhere and I think there is. I like that the game is cooperative. That aspect really seems to fit the theme very well. I like that there is a solo element to the game. That allows you to test decks easily and try new ideas. The gameplay itself is pretty intuitive and the games don't take long to play. The adventures are a nice idea and I like that each has it's own set of encounter cards. That gives each one it's own unique feel. It would be nice if there were more of them but that's what the adventure packs are for. 

Many have said that the game doesn't "feel" like LotR. I understand the criticism but it really doesn't bother me at all. There are so many new elements in the game and so far the story lines are not coming from the book but are derived from them tangentially. I can understand where a lot of the cards originate but most are not mentioned in the books. So yeah, it's hard to "feel" like LotR without a lot of very specific cards that currently don't exist. I think that this will improve a lot as more cards become available. I know that the tactics deck got a big boost and certainly became more tied to the books with the introduction of the eagles in the 1st adventure pack. Also, I really don't 'feel' like a farmer when I play Agricola either but I still enjoy that game.

[8/22/11]
After more plays and a couple of iterations of the FAQ things have cleared up quite a bit. Some of the wording and definitions are a bit unclear but the FAQ does a good job of clearing things up. It would be nice if they were a bit more intuitive. Still it's a pretty solid game. I've played with the 1st and 2nd adventure packs and base game adventures so far but I like what I saw. It looks like each adventure pack will have a different feel. I've also acquired a 2nd copy of the game through a trade and that has made a big difference. Playing 50 card decks is the way to play this game. Of course that now makes one of the three adventures in the starter set completely obsolete and another substantially easier. The most difficult scenario in the starter pretty much requires 50 card decks and two copies of the game anyway so at least that one is still worth playing. So at the moment it kind of sucks having only 3 adventures that will challenge you most games. 

For those of you that aren't interested in building decks you can check out this list of decks for use in the game:

http://www.cardgamedb.com/index.php/lotr/lord-of-the-rings-decks/_/lord-of-the-rings-decks/

There are also several useful FFG guides to solo deck construction on FFGs website:

Part 1
http://www.fantasyflightgames.com/edge_news.asp?eidn=2968

Part 2
http://www.fantasyflightgames.com/edge_news.asp?eidn=2988

Part 3
http://www.fantasyflightgames.com/edge_news.asp?eidn=3008

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I love the feeling and the atmosphere. The game actually lies in cooperating to [i]prepare[/i] [decks] for the quest at hand. Sending your decks off to beat a scenario is very exciting...

... Dwarf theme, please...

I love places, and this game takes you places. It really feels like an adventure!

The game is best with 2 players.

But it has problems as a game. Theoretically a solitaire game even though two players "cooperate." Also, You must know your cards really well to build decks well. This is time consuming and not really part of the game. I think I would prefer to study Chess or Luna or some other game with almost no luck than to spend time learning the canon of cards and card effects that I might not draw in-game anyway. And you must get many expansions to have real options for the game in the first place, and so it is expensive to boot. One gets more satisfaction out of studying a single game like Luna or El Grande or Chess than one gets from buying tons of little "games" in the LOTR:LCG series. That is, as a "game." If you're going for theme, immersion in fantasy, and a cooperative ride with a friend or family member, then the game definitely delivers.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A relatively fast-playing co-op, with heroes and monsters and all the other things you'd expect a Lord of the Rings adventure game to be made of, plus enough flexibility in deck construction/customization to keep my inner CCGer happy.

After building a deck and choosing one of the scenarios (which determines the subset of enemies, locations, and other bad stuff you'll face), the game follows a fairly simple structure of alternate questing and fighting steps, with plenty of points where the players can play cards, and an upkeep step after fighting.

You can play with two players with the base game alone, though we found that the number of cards meant we felt a bit constrained while deckbuilding.  We purchased the Khazad-Dum expansion, and now there's a bit more room for customization.

Components, though it's a card game and they only consist of cards, tokens, and a pair of threat counters, are high-quality.  I sleeved the game, but it's certainly not necessary for the non-OCD.  The rulebook is also laid out well, and makes a game with a fairly simple rule set easy to learn.

EDIT: The more I play of this, the less I like it.  It seems like every game we play of this, regardless of whether we win or lose, the outcome is determined early on.  When we win, it's because we were able to clear the staging area early, which allowed us to quest conservatively and travel/fight to keep the staging area clear.  

When we lose, we had been unable to quest successfully early on, either because of high doom values or because threatening enemies have required our attention.  Unsuccessful quests mean locations get completed slowly, and questing phases get more desparate, but the enemies also don't get dealt with, and once a hero dies, there is no recovery.

RATING: 8.5
Nice deck building game. Highly thematic. Its actually a cooperative game (new approach for deck building games) with players working together against the encounter deck (different enemy cards according to the scenario) in order to accomplice the scenario's requests. Scenarios are of variable difficulty. Great artwork on the cards. The game also supports solo play and is good at it. But only 3 scenarios included?? Shame on you FFG. 

Update after 100 plays: Ok this game is great and I am addicted. I bought everything from Mirkwood, Dwarrowdelf, Against the Shadow, Ringmaker, Angmar Awakens nad the Dreamchaser cycles.

Update after 200 plays: The latest cycles are excellent. Much better story and more advanced mechanics. Great stuff, Icant stop playing. BBut now I am spoiled and I dont want to play Mirkwood Cycle again. Seems so boring and shallow. 

Rating starts as a 7 during the first cycle and goes up to a 9 at the latest cycles because the scanario design and theme gets progressively better.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
12+, 1-2 players, best with 2, 60 mins. Solo play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Bought to play solo (and have still only ever played solo). It works pretty well, though getting started is pretty tough - it seems to be so hard at first. It really requires deck building, despite the misleading positioning as playable out of the box, as single sphere decks have limited power. It could do with more official scenarios. Of course, this is a very good reason for wanting the expansion packs, and the game will only really shine when more has been added to it. But the core is certainly playable as it is, and you will get your money's worth if that is all you buy.

Not all the player cards in the core set come in threes, though they do in the expansions. The number of player cards in the core set is such that they could have provided 2 of each (well, all but 1, but they could have done 14 cards per sphere and added another neutral card, or provided 4 more player cards by removing cards elsewhere). Several of the most useful cards only come with 1 copy. This appears to be just gouging from FFG to persuade people to buy two or three core sets just to get those 'missing' cards.

I have only played solo, but from comments on here, and just from looking at the instructions, it is clear that there are scalability problems, where the same scenario varies enormously in difficulty depending on the number of players. Of course, once you know what the real difficulty is, by number of players, that sort-of does not matter. The lack of balance smacks of lack of playtesting, or, more likely, an acceptance that it is difficult to balance well, and a couldn't give a damn about the consequence. 

Whilst the rules are generally pretty good (and there is a good official video series), the inconsistencies and ambiguous wording on many of the cards (and wording on the cards overrides the rules) and the documentation (or complete lack thereof) about card effects and interactions is very poor, requiring lots of FAQ entries and rule clarifications. Their playtesters must have been awful (or, more likely, not reading the cards because they 'knew' what they did) to have not noted all those ambiguities.  That or they were noted but failed to make it into any documentation. Whatever the reason, the mess does not do FFG any credit.

The quality of the physical bits is excellent. A very sturdy box, nice quality cards, generally excellent artwork, good quality thick tokens and threat trackers.

This is my first, and probably my last, FFG game. I would undoubtedly have given a higher score if it was not just so poorly developed. Very polished presentation, but it is all superficial. If they had spent as much time on the game as they did on the glitz, it would probably have been very good indeed.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9

I suspect it is because it is the only co op game of its kind and myself and the other players do not feel the need to keep each other honest.

RATING: 3
I went in to this game favorably disposed towards it, and after stumbling with the starter Tactics deck initially, I did a bit of deck building and enjoyed it with the Mirkwood scenario.  But then I realized that the other scenarios just didn't feel like fun and I simply don't feel like playing the game any further.  I set it up for the Anduin scenario one evening, stared at everything, then put it all back in the box.  

I think the true problem is that the game really bothers me from a lore/story perspective; I know that's silly, but are we to believe that Denethor, Aragorn, Eowyn, Legolas, Gimli, and Bilbo are all tearing around Mirkwood or hunting for Gollum?  

Anyway, the art is great and the components are excellent, so that's something.  I'm glad a lot of people enjoy the game, but it's not for me.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9

Ranged - exhaust to deal 1 damage to an enemy in the staging area
Sentinel - exhaust to add Defense to another character's Defense against an attack.

Or

When playing solo only include one copy of each encounter card in the encounter deck. For some quests you must however include multiples of some cards. In addition the player's deck's minimum size is reduced to 20 (or 25, still experimenting) cards, but may include only a single copy of each card. The changes to the encounter decks have reduced runs of bad luck immensely and made the quests slightly more predictable. You also don't have to include as many cards in your player deck to counter the worst encounter cards. Reducing the size of the player deck makes that more predictable and allows faster access to key cards. The limit to one copy of each player card on the other hand counterbalance the changes that make the game easier and force you to use cards that would otherwise be rarely used. A nice side effect is that such player decks only require one core set

http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/804444/solo-balance-mod-feedback-welcome
http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/780087/my-solo-variants
http://boardgamegeek.com/filepage/69038/expanded-solo-variant-v0-8

Bombadil variant: each hero begins the game with a single progress token on them. At any time during the game, a player can have a hero they control sing the song (removing the progress token) to activate one of the following effects, of their choice:

Heal that hero 1 damage. Ready that hero. That hero gains +1 Willpower until the end of the phase. That hero gains +1 Attack until the end of the phase. That hero gains +1 Defense until the end of the phase.

RATING: 6
Apart from solo games, I have only played this once, and it was a little better than OK. As a solo game, it is far too difficult. If your starting hand is not (almost) perfect, you may as well start again. Repeat. Repeat. Repeat. For example trying the second of the base scenarios with the cards available at the time (only cards from the base set and the first cycle). Even choosing your starting hand you are in the lap of the gods with the shadow draw. 

I do like the scaling up of difficulty with 2 players, it appears to be a nice mechanic. After a few plays, I am more certain that the game is almost entirely luck based and what cards come up. It is a very average solo game more like a puzzle of getting the right combination of cards to get through the scenario.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
A truly exceptional co-op card game, that brings together theme, story and interesting gameplay 'puzzles' (in various forms). I'd be tempted to rate this much higher, as it is a personal favourite. It both scratches my deckbuilding urges and is a much easier game to teach/play for less competitive players than FFG's other LCGs - while still offering real challenges. It also taught me a great deal about narrative in gaming.

Before I jump into a few technical criticisms, some more great stuff: the art is stellar (look no further than Magali Villeneuve's contributions), the game continues to evolve in interesting directions, and the community/fansites are welcoming and great to interact with.

Two things holding this game back: 
-A core set that a completionist/deckbuilder will feel the urge to buy more than 1 of, despite steeply diminishing returns (due to the encounter cards).
-A timing/rules structure reminiscent of the Game of Thrones LCG that pre-dates some the considerable improvements made in later LCGs since. While being cooperative rather than competitive eases the burden of knowledge, there's still some pretty arcane quirks.

Quite thematic if you keep the movie in mind.  A great design idea that works well if I can get it in under 60 mins...punishingly hard which takes the shine off a little.

RATING: 8.2

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
My favourite LCG and quite simply one of the best cooperative/solo games around in its genre! 

The components are fantastic, and infinitely expandable as the inevitable expansions arrive. It's extremely simple to get the hang of, and setup is extremely easy.

Yet the game itself is supremely tense, and is fully cooperative with everyone chipping in towards a common goal. There is no splitting up to achieve different objectives as in some other coops. Everyone is in the same focus all the time.

A great game with an awesome theme - it's no surprise that it has rocketed up my top 10 list. I had been waiting for this game for quite awhile, and frankly expected it to underwhelm, but boy am I glad to be so wrong!

RATING: 7
Now this game has something to do with Lord of the Rings as you work your way through the world and story of Tolkein's Middle Earth. Spectacular art and intense gameplay make it the best of FF's LCGs and probably one of the better card games in the business. The only thing that keeps it at a 7 is there is too much power creep the further along in the adventures you go. And with that happening the deck you had for that adventure isn't going to work in this adventure. So with each new play we have to remake our decks to have a better chance. Yes. Yes. We know that for some people that retooling of your decks as the story gets more difficult is the best part. But for us it becomes a bit of a chore.

RATING: 5
Two plays, two players.  Flat-out steamrolled the first scenario and found the whole affair boring, questioning why I wouldn't attack with all but one of my bajillion allies every turn.  The second scenario was much more challenging, but I concluded that the underlying game mechanics aren't sufficiently interesting to me in order to generate interest in deckbuilding.  For me, the former has to precede the latter, although several people - like my opponent - enjoy deckbuilding more, and don't concern themselves as much with the underlying engines.  I thought it was playable.  I was glad that I was taught the rules, given the surprising length of the rulebook.  If you're an LOTR or deckbuilding nut, maybe it's for you.  It's harder for me to see excitement in the mechanics, though.

RATING: 5
[co-op card combat, 1-4 players]

==original thoughts==
Only own the core set.  Replaced the terrible insert with UltraPro deck boxes.

Set up and teardown are longer than I normally like, and teaching the game's rhythm is hard.  This plus the long game dureation means I've only started three sessions of this game (one session was adjourned because the night grew too late for my roommate).  If I had the right group, this might come out more often.

The game doesn't scale well for different player counts.  I can't beat the first scenario alone, but it was feasible at 2 and easy at 3.  Haven't played 4.

==2017/11/19==
Maybe I don't like co-ops?

This game is a small mountain of rules.  Each turn has seven-ish phases, and there's SO MUCH card text to read.  And after you climb that mountain, the decisions are pretty obvious.  Eowyn always quests, Aragorn always wants the killing blow.  After learning the game and teaching the game, you're rewarded with a simple set of decisions.

Also, this is a game with "card screw", where you don't draw the cards you actually want.  You don't turn through your deck enough to reliably get the cards you want, and some cards in your hand are just crap.

Maybe the game would be more fun if I could build my own deck?  If the choices in the real game aren't very fun, then maybe the interesting choices are in deckbuilding.  That means dropping more money on the game though, and I don't even like it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9.5
My preferred means of visiting this fictional universe in game form...the amount of customization here is nearly on a Magic level, or it will be when there are enough cards. The artwork is also unparalleled among all the LCGs I've seen, gorgeous renderings that should please fans of both the novels and the films. Really an excellent game, one I will play for years.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Ultimately, I decided that the CCG/LCG format just doesn't work for a co-op game.

Unless you are the 'only a few games play I' type.  and you have several friends of like persuasion.  At that point, the deckbuilding becomes a shared activity to be discussed and debated, instead of a task lumped on the game owner which will rarely be appreciated by the future participants, unless deck failure occurs, in which case it creates a bad game experience.

key point to remember, deckbuilding LCGs still require more investment in the game (mindshare) than fixed deck games.

RATING: 5.5
I bought this on a whim while on a business trip.   I was bored, the reviews were great, and the next stop on my trip was my girlfriend; I liked the idea of a co-op game to play with her, since I just don't see her as a wargamer, and she loves LOTR.

After initially feeling overwhelmed by the rules, I set up the game in my hotel room and eventually figured out the mechanics.  I lost interest in the game pretty quickly.  Maybe deck-building games just aren't for me (although I love Dominion).  It reminds me a bit of Sentinels of the Multiverse, a game I bought with high expectations, only to find the gameplay too difficult to make the game enjoyable.

One thing I found frustrating was simply the disorganization of the game play area.  Maybe I just need a bigger table to play on.

One lesson learned:  I need to pay more attention to the negative comments.  When you pull up comments for a game, it defaults to the higher ratings first, and the glowing reports can tempt one to purchase a game without due diligence.

In any event, I'm packing up the game now with no particular desire to pull it out again.  I may try it one more time if I'm feeling desperate.  Otherwise, it's just going on the shelves.

UPDATE:  Played through a whole solo scenario.  Upgraded from 3 to 5.5, based on my willingness to give it another try or two.  May be more enjoyable with two players.  As it is, still doesn't hold much appeal.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.8
after a couple plays I have to say Im pretty intruiged by this one.  I cant quite tell if everything that's happening is just "busy work" or if there's an actually game here but I enjoyed my plays of it so far.

******

A few more plays now and still enjoying this game despite the fact that it doesn't seem to offer much in the way of meaningful decisions.  Deciding which resources to spend and when, while deciding who to quest with, who to hold back for combat, and who to exhaust (tap) for special powers are all interesting on the surface, but ultimately its the turn of the cards that seem to dictate success of failure. 

Like many games of this sort, the real juicy decisions come in the spaces between the game, where players build their decks in order to prepare for the journey ahead -- gearing up for the journey is half the fun!  The scenarios are varied and decks that work against one won't likely perform so well against another.  You build a deck, throw it against the scenario, tinker, and repeat.  While it may sounds a little "mechanical" it's quite enjoyable.

Still there is much to enjoy here and so far there are a lot of clever little ways in which the game play lines up nicely with the individual quests.  The game does a good job of telling a story while making you feel like you are a part of it.

The last issue is the co-op nature of it.  How well does the game foster that sense of working together with a friend in order to overcome a difficult challenge?  Some of this comes back to deck building.  A sort of "I'll build something to fight the monsters while you put together a questing or healing deck".  There are also a few abilities that some cards have that foster that same sort of "we're in this together" feeling.  But overall it's not QUITE as engaging as a co-op when compared to something like Pandemic or Space Alert.

One last thing.  If you really want to enjoy this game and all it has to offer (as far as deckbuilding) I think you need to drop some cash on adventure packs.  Probably not much of a surprise, but also sort of a bummer.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.4
Updated rating after reading the complete rules by myself and (re)starting the campaign with my home "gang". Probably best with 2 players.

RATING: 6.5
This is a brilliantly well thought out game. The player is required to think hard about each and every move. Very challenging. Even the easiest mission I've lost on several times. I like challenging. My biggest complaint about the game is that the rulebook had errors in it, and was hard to understand. Although it is very thorough and doesn't leave much left in question. One mistake in the rulebook copy I have is that it tells you to take quest cards 120 to 123 out and use them for your first quest. Well using these quest cards give you mix of two different quests, and made the game doubly hard to learn. Instead you need to use the quest cards all with the same title, and ignore what the rulebook tells you.  Overall, I love this game and it is very worth the money. 

EDIT: I've stopped playing this game after the first 2 months of owning it. There are better games out there and it is easy to get sucked into buying all of the expansion packs which shouldn't have been necessary in the first place. I wish I had never spent alot of money on this game. It was good while I was still figuring it out.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
After some plays: not a bad game at all. A lot of hard strategic choices. I think the strategy maintains the stability of a board game without interference from the collectible aspect of the game. This is a constant development struggle game. Both sides are competing in the development, and the card mechanics offer deep strategies. I dislike the scoring rule that forces you to an early victory though. Apart from that, excellent.

RATING: 7
Really fun. I can see that this will get a lot of play for me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Lord of the Rings LCG is essentially Magic the Gathering, the cooperative game.
Well, FFG's design team didn't take any chance, and re-used the usual, oiled mechanics you can find in the grandfather of the CCGs. While this is a sound way to design a fine game, one can wonder if they couldn't find anything more original...
Another annoying aspect of the game is the messy lots of FAQs already out there... Indeed, you can't borrow the whole structure from Magic the Gathering, without writing a similarly daunting set of comprehensive rules... or you will end with this mess (to this problem I must add the awful italian translation...)!
BUT, if one can dig its way out through all these drawbacks, the game is quite challenging and enjoyable (as enjoyable a coop could be for me...).
So, I am willing to give it some more tries and find if it can stand my initial rating of 7.

Edit january 14th, 2012: the first plays left me wanting more. The challenges seem so daunting when you have just one core set, I had to buy another. And I feel the urge to try again and again. Rating raised to 7.5.

Edit january 20th, 2012: the game is growing on me and my GF, and we keep playing it, we're definitely hooked. Rating raised again to 8.

Edit february 15th,2012: after nearly 20 plays, it continues asking to be played... Raised to 8.5!

Edit september 8th, 2013: after more than 60 plays, it still is played but with lesser frequency and enthusiasm. Lowered again to 8.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I fell into the (cunningly set) trap: I had to buy a second core set to find satisfaction as a former CCG player. Now I can build better decks... Is that worth the effort?

Edit january 15th, 2012: short answer to the above question -> YES.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

RATING: 9
Loving Lord of the Rings, co-op games and card games I knew it was a game for me :)

I'm a bit disappointed with the limited options of deck-building in the core set - playing with two players forces you to build dual sphere decks so you have to build a 50 card deck from a pool of 60 cards. Sounds like fun? 

It took me 50 games to feel a bit tired of the game but I am sure that each adventure pack will bring a bit of freshness to the game. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This game fires on all cylinders. Lots of decisions to make with enough randomness to keep it feeling adventurous. A challenging and satisfying experience overall, and tons of variety with the various expansions. I think I would collect this game for the art alone; it's gorgeous and based on the books rather than the movies; it touches on all aspects of Tolkien's world. The deck construction aspect allows you to prepare for your specific quest, and it gives you the feeling of strategizing before adventures much like the journeying company would. This game is a worthy tabletop treatment of Tolkien's masterpiece, and that's saying quite a bit.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Really enjoying this, I am hooked for expansions for a while.  The co-op will not go over with some in the game group, but the game scales well and plays solo.  Don't be fooled - this plays just fine for 3-4 with only one core set - and I find it a bit shady that FFG is stating otherwise.

Artwork and component quality are top notch, the rulebook is only ok.  There are too many important interactions and timing nuances left out, count on the FAQ to be huge after just a couple expansions.

Update: Rating is dropping, as I'm finding little desire to play this even with new cards coming out.  Expansions so far have been...underwhelming.  Rating has bottomed out, games get more boring and procedural over time and it is obvious FFG didn't test nearly enough - just as I thought, the FAQ and errata are out of control
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Rating dropped to 7. Because casual play got some much harder and less fun, since decks have to be tailormade to the latest quests. Good general decks didn't work anymore.

[old comment:]
Upped Rating to 10! This new Rating is meant to include the expansions. Without expansions it would be lower. This is now my most played game. It gives you the C/LCG deckbuilding without the need of a competetive play environment. Just meet with your friend(s) once or twice a month and face the new challenge, improve the decks and face it again until you succeed. Pure genius! Add to that the satisfying solo play and you end with an almost perfect game.

Update: Still going strong (first Hobbit box). What's really good is that the game forces you to adapt and alter your decks or build new decks with new quests. And we even imposed some restrictions on ourselves regarding the Hobbit timeline. Looking forward to the next cycle.

Old comment (old rating 8):
Played a PnP version of the final German edition (4 games, 3 2-player, 1 4-player). Only used the one sphere starter decks.

Rating is not final. Will have to test deckbuilding and multi-sphere decks first.

Everyone who likes Arkham, BSG, Death Angel etc. and knows a little bit of CCG/LCG mechanics and likes the Middle-Earth setting should at least try this when it is released.

UPDATE: Played some more games, but still with the starter decks. Quest 1 is really easy, but we got slaughtered by Quest 2. Still have to try deckbuilding. But has been fun so far.

UPDATE 2:
I now regularly meet with a friend to play this. I bring all the cards (2 core sets + all expansions) and we will build decks or alter the decks from the previous session and try to tackle the new scenario or retry a scenario we had failed earlier. We only play once or twice a month and at this frequency my rating remains a solid 8 with upward tendency.

The really great thing about this game is that you can have CCG style deckbuilding without a functioning competetive game group that is required to enjoy most PvP CCGs/LCGs.

RATING: 10
A well themed adventure game in the Lord of the Rings setting.  For me its the best solo game I've played.  I come from a MtG background and I love to deckbuild.  I have also been seeking something that feels like a Dungeons & Dragons adventure.

This game takes both of those and melds them together into a cohesive game.  You must deckbuild to defeat scenarios.  I enjoy the deckbuilding aspect.  I also like the adventuring aspect.  Each scenario is unique and provides a different adventuring feel.

May hit 1000 plays at some point.

Currently at the tail end of The Ring-Maker Cycle

Great Game.

RATING: N/A
Collin's
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.4
This is a wonderful gaming system that works from 1-4 players.  I can also see it working well with one dedicated player who wants to deck build and family/friends more wanting the casual narrative driven play.  Just got 1 game under my belt thus far but really enjoying it.

The advent of easy mode makes me feel that this is now a great game for a broad audience and there is no longer the need to buy lots of expansions to get cards powerful enough (if there ever was) to stand a chance of winning.  With just the base set you can get a very fun game and whilst I would miss the dials if playing 1 set with 3 to 4 players and we might end up low on counters its easy enough to proxy stuff in for them.

I can see me enjoying this both solo and with others.  I do think my enjoyment will be enhanced with a couple of expansions so I have more options for deck building but there is decent amount of deck building that can be done for 1-2 players with the base set with 2 faction decks.

My one non solo play was a bit of a mixed success.  There are a few different types of player for whom this will work but unless you really want an atmospheric ride if you want to get into the strategy this is a game needing repeat plays to shine.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.8
First plays and first impressions are good.

Important update:

This game is simply too challenging in solo play.Downgraded it to 8 because winning 2 games out of 21 in solo play is not so much fun. While with 3 players we had a 4/4 win. So not balanced well between number of players.

Scenario 3 can not be won unless you have extreme luck with the cards.

Update after 4 more years playing.

One thing is sure though: the game is addicting. I already played the second scenario 15 times with a mixed single deck Lore/ Leadership. Not even touched other combos. Hard game, but for some odd reason, deck construction and solo experience is addicting.

It could be a new hype: a kind of Magic the gathering card collection/construction system with huge solo possibilities. When constructing and playing, cards come to live and you start caring about some combos and odd heroes. Always a good sign.

Card rule questions are obvious but since it is co op play it is mostly common sense that can resolve 99.9% of all problems.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Great card game, perfect for solo play.  It's somewhat of a merge between MTG (you have to manage ressource points to cast spells) and Legendary (there's a 'villain' AI deck to conquer).
The art is gorgeous!
Beware, this is a typical FFG game : endless expansions to keep up with, lots of keywords to remember, etc.
The difficulty is way up there, but it gets manageable once you get used to how the game works.
Recommended if :
-you like a good soloable deckbuilder that's playable within an hour
-you don't mind having your butt being handed to you

RATING: 7.8
A very challenging living card game (LCG) where players play a customized deck of cards and a set of heroes with the aim of defeating creatures and exploring locations in the LotR universe in hopes of successfully completing various quests.  The core set is playable with 2p, but will likely be my solo game of choice for a while.

RATING: 8
Great, great game. The theme is perfect, the art is gorgeous, and the difficulty is just enough where it doesn't feel unbeatable. Love the deck customization aspect. Just fantastic.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.2
I had very high hopes for this game. Unfortunately after three plays I'm already fairly certain that this game does not live up to my expectations. It falls into the Fantasy Flight trap of being so convoluted with rules an mechanisms that playing it is more like following a flowchart than actually having fun. The theme that should be the heart and soul of any Lord of the Rings game is just not there. Quest are as generic as they can get and fail to pull you into the game. Combat makes no sense with the seperate defenders and attackers and the relationship between the different parties and allies is murky at best. Travelling along the river I find allies from Gondor, Rohan and the likes who just happen to be there. Really?! Furthermore the game is not really playable out of the box. The prefab decks don't seem to stand a chance against any but the low level quests. This forces you to get more cards and start deckbuilding. For some this may be just what they're looking for. For me it's a big turnoff. The game is but a shadow of what it could have been and a very big disappointment for me.

Gameplay: :star::star::halfstar::nostar::nostar:
Replayability: :star::star::star::nostar::nostar:
Fun/Social: :star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar:
Components: :star::star::star::nostar::nostar:
Rules: :star::star::star::nostar::nostar:

RATING: 7
Likes:
- The "engine" of the game is absolutely brilliant, and maybe the most innovative AI engine in a Co-op game today
- The artwork is phenomenal, and it just keeps getting better with each expansion.
- Very good balance of difficulty (Not too easy, not to hard).
- Just pure fun.  Have yet to play this with someone who would not want to play again.

Dislikes:
- The cards seem to come out at maybe to fast of a pace?  I find myself only updating decks maybe once a quarter, and by that time, there has been at least 3 new expansions that have come out.
- Expensive to keep up with

RATING: 8.3
Passage through Mirkwood - 2 players (Tactics & Spirit). Completed in 5 rounds, 28+31 threat respectively, 4 dmg on heroes. 4 victory points on Chieftain Ufthuk. Total 109 points.

Journey Through the Anduin - 2 players (Tactics & Spirit). Completed in 6 rounds, 32 + 31 threat respectively, 1 dmg on heroes, 18 victory points off locations & enemies. Total 106 points.

Hunt for Gollum - see below.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.27
Definitely one of my favourite LCG's.  Works so well.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.75
On first play I wasn't convinced at all - it felt clunky and irritating. but then we realised after a month's downtime that we were playing the decks like individual, discrete decks - as soon as we started really working together the game felt like a really deep challenge.

Now I'm definitely looking forward to the next game - want to see how the other two decks work.

EDIT: After several more plays I am really jonesing to get more of this game in. I love the roleplaying experience provided by the encounter deck and the discrete nature of each adventure - the decision to focus more on adventures rather than deckbuilding in the expansions also makes me really happy.

I still couldn't give two hoots about the theme, but the cards and art look pretty great. Rating improved from 7 to 8.25.

EDIT2: The honeymoon is over, and here's why:

- I have five of the six expansions from this cycle, and have started building decks that fit the 'tournament' rules of 50 cards. I have one Rohan deck that works really well, one mono green deck that is pretty awful, and one dwarf/eagle deck that just doesn't work. I can't get the sixth expansion because everyone's out of it everywhere, and thus can't build a mono red eagle deck. Having no good decks means more than solo with the rohirrim simply doesn't work.

- The problem here is that the card pool is just too small - you only get nine usable cards in each expansion, and one playset is really enough to build maybe two decent decks, at least until the card pool increases substantially.

- the level 4 adventures typically destroy these pathetic decks, so we never play the level 5 or higher ones, mainly because we don't enjoy playing the level 4 ones, so why would we proceed to a MORE difficult one? This means most of the cards I've bought are wasted, because the encounter decks are just too frustrating, and not fun to play.

- I can't get anyone to play this with me. I've now taught six people who just won't play any more. The first four learn on the level 4 Anduin adventure, and found the game frustrating, overly complex and resource-starved. Everyone came out of the first game wanting to 'fix' the game. Never a good sign. The last two I taught on the learning scenario, and they had very similar complaints - too few resources, decks too unreliable.

- All of this stems from the pretty dreadful card pool, and the frankly astonishing requirement that decks should be 50 cards, but the decks from the base game are 30. 30 is a good size for a fun game, 50 just means you have 20 shit cards in each deck.

- the card pool is so stunted that every single deck needs the same five cards, so one playset isn't enough to build enough decks to actually play anyone. FFG really should provide full 50-card decks with a full playset of each card in the base game, so deckbuilders have enough cards to always have four decks, so they can constantly be bringing new players into the game. As it is, the game isn't fun unless you buy far too many cards, and frankly, a game should be its own ambassador, not rely on my wallet to proselytise it.

- The game needs FAR MORE of the basic building blocks of CCGs: more reliable card draw, more resources, and SOME BLOODY COST DISCOUNTERS. You can't have steward of Gondor  and Theodred in every deck, nor should you have to! Some more themed cards to make themed decks work would be appreciated too - like Rohan/Gondor/Silvan/Dwarf specific cost-reducers, or attachment  that allow heroes to spend resources on rohan/gondor/dwarf characters despite resource icons. All the new players of this game that I  have taught agree - being resource starved does not make for an interesting game,it makes for a shit game.

- I'm hoping the Khazad-Dum expansion and the final mirkwood cycle pack will allow me to build a functioning dwarf deck and a functioning eagle mono red deck, so the game will be fun again. If that happens, maybe enough people will enjoy playing it for it to hit the table. At the moment, it's getting passed over pretty often.

- The real shame of this is that the thing that made it get passed over was the purchase of the expansions! It was totally playable out of the box, but deckbuilding is a nightmare, especially when you have to add 20 cards per deck, and there aren't enough cards! That's a terrible strategy - making a game worse with every expansion.

RATING: 9

This title has brought me in because of the cooperative angle. I play it solo (noting, yes, that single deck solo is just not going to be practical for a casual gamer such as myself) and I have a blast. The cards are gorgeous and the scenarios give you little thematic, narrative gifts if you're willing to let your imagination play a bit. I anticipate that there will be frustrating scenarios and less than rewarding adventure pack buys here and there, but, hey, it feels like a big playground in Tolkein land - a terrific opportunity for one who loves the books.

RATING: 5.5
I was very much hoping I'd be able to play this out-of-the-box by myself, and after much trial and error and a good deal of online research, I managed to form a deck that pretty consistently beat adventure 1, but 2 was extraordinarily difficult with only one deck... And you can forget about 3!

If you are hoping to play this solo, you WILL need to use two decks and play "for two." 

And call me stubborn, but I'm simply not interested in playing two-handed! :(

And I'm not interested in hunting down specific packs with specific cards just to be able to form a solo "one-handed deck" that I can use.

All that said, the game design itself is lovely and I'm very disappointed that I will probably never find anyone who will "get into" this with me. :(

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Initial rating based on one solo play!

Quite like the art - definitely like the implementation of the theme. Rules are pretty straightforward (and clear). Like the idea of scenarios/quests - although the core game only has limited options, and the co-op (and solo) nature is a nice change from either a "you play hero I'll play Sauron" or 'race for points'.

I like that it's a LCG rather than a CCG, and I like the fact there is deckbuilding.

However all might not be great, first experience was a blow-out, got crushed and I don't think it was poor play on my part. I wonder how much of the game is determined by the random order of the encounter deck, rather than the player decisions (ie. do you play the game, or does it play you).

Need to play it more, and try some expansion packs. Rating likely to change, just not sure in which direction at the moment!

** Update, played it more, both Solo and 2 player, and I'm liking it more, but the 3 scenario limit of the core set seems rather miserly, fortunately there are some great player made scenarios for variety. Rating increased to 8 for now ... [Lore sphere seems to be best in a support role which explains my first game disaster]

*** Update, played some more - and I think 'out of the box' decks are designed for multiplayer play rather than solo, and in that format are fine. I need to investigate deck building, but the current card pool (with one core box) is rather limited! Need another core box (curse you FFG - LCG is a CCG with new clothes ...) 
rating increased, haven't been this gripped by a L(C)CG since MECCG.

RATING: 7.5
The deck building can be a bit overwhelming at times (even with just the core set!). Even though I was using many of the cards and ideas presented in this thread http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/1108855/back-basics-killer-deck-using-only-cards-single-co the game was still largely a disaster for me. After digging the game back out (I wanted to like it!) I used the deck and heroes as presented in the above thread and after a rocky start have had some success at the game. I still have trouble managing cases where I get no low cost allies in the initial card draw or when I get many low threat enemies at the start of the game. Overall I am starting to see how cards interact with each other and am starting to enjoy the game more. I am on to Journey Down the Anduin next. Changed rating from 7 to 7.5.

RATING: 8
-sold-

sleeved

It is not the theme-loaded holy grail of Co-Op that some are praising it. Themewise I would put it in the same category as Lords of Waterdeep, since both have their theme just in pictures and little sentences.
But...
I do love this game. It has nice gameplay without the lots of rules I was expecting.
Well, there aren't that many scenarios included but, hey, FFG has to make money somehow.
By now I was a bit deterred by the LCG-system but this game might change that.
This will definetly go into my collection sooner or later...more sooner than later...ok, I'll order it now.

A few days and a few expansions later this game went through the roof. I have to admit the LCG hook got me. But it is great. This game doesn't even get packed away currently. The box is always on the table, open, waiting for a quick round or two.

After over 30 plays I have to say that this game is a trap. Once you play the base game you think "Yeah, that's cool. This will last a while since I can restructure my deck." Yeah, no! You are through the scenarios and hunger for more instantly. More cards, more adventures...
Hopefully this will cease some day. Before the 24â¬ basegame turns into a 200â¬ set.

After some more scenarios the theme pops up. The three from the base game are just "meh" but later quests really bring the theme with them. A race feels like a race, an overwhelming fight against dozens of enemies feels exactly like that.

RATING: 8.5
Excellent cooperative card game, almost worth the extravagant cost of all those chapter packs. The gameplay is both streamlined and challenging, and the artwork is by far the best of any game I own or have seen. Each time I play I think about what cards are working well for me and which ones I want to change out in a future deck. The multiple scenarios, different spheres, and varied heroes give this game an unbelievable amount of replay value, especially with the solo option. 

UPDATE: Still a favorite of ours, two dozen plays in. The Saga expansions are amazing (and very thematic) and I am continually surprised by the variety and ingenuity of the quest designs. Eat your heart out, Arkham Horror LCG, this one still has you beat.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
It's fun when the cards come out fairly well mixed, but clusters of similar cards can be brutal - to the point of ruining the game.  In one solo game three location cards came out in a row which effectively removed any chance of winning the game.  Even with committing all characters to questing there wasn't enough willpower to overcome the threat, which meant no progress was ever made on the locations, so the threat never decreased.  Game over.  Not a satisfying way to lose the game.

Random "screwage" situations like that dampen my enthusiasm for the game.  Plus there are numerous rules questions about timing and card wording that make the game feel unpolished.  I'm sure many of these will be addressed in a FAQ at some point, but right now the game is kind of "meh" for me.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
This game allows for no unique and different ways to approach a situation. You either have the cards a situation needs, or you lose. In this (not so subtle) way the game forces you to buy the booster packs in wich you find the cards you need to skip the situation. 

All boosters also contain new scenario's wich might sound like a good thing, but all it does in the end, is fill up 75% of the booster pack you just bought with a new scenario, when you desperately need characters etc to beat the current scenarios you already own. This could be solved by selling them separately, but then they would make less of a profit because the scenario's would most likely not sell as good as the other packs....

Buying this game gave me the feeling like i was being conned out of my money, wich is very rare when dealing with FFG, a company i hold in high regards.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Great graphics, smooth gameplay, but... it's LCG.. it will drain all your money if you want to take it serious.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I wasn't sure how a ccg co-op would play but it seems to work well, as well as being different from other co-ops I've played - no mean achievement.

While there's a fair amount of rules, they are in large print with lots of pictures and examples so aren't as intimidating as they might appear - it took us about 10 minutes to get into the swing of things (the only problem we had was remembering to draw shadow cards at the right point).  Despite comments elsewhere about how tough the game is we sucessfully completed the first two scenarios without losing a single hero - maybe it helped that there were three of us?

Looking forward to playing more.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Well, after a bit more play, I think Lord of the Rings LCG is an OK game that just doesn't do it for me. It's too mechanically overwrought (resulting in easily missed rules), and thematically vacuous. The Dwarves are a prime offender; they get really strong powers when they suffering  multiple wounds, but how many times is anybody wounded at all in The Hobbit or Lord of the Rings, never mind twice or more? Again, MECCG got this right, LotR LCG did not. And the quests ae so generic they completely fail to engage. The packaging here is also really problematic. They've gone with a mix of OK, powerful, and insanely powerful cards in the game, so a key to playing well is having the capability to dig through your deck for the key cards. But in deck-building, those key cards are the ones they've given you only one or two copies of, so when you bloat your deck to 50 cards (as requiured by the current deck rules) deck-digging has even more of a premium. So anyway. Again, this all sounds harsh, and LotR LCG isn't that bad. But it's mid-90s game design and except for the production design, it feels the decade out of date that it is.
---
Hmm. Played Scenario 2 three times: once solitaire, once with two players with fixed complimentary decks, once with two players with constructed decks. Each time, we got completely slaughtered while managing to get no more than 3 progress tokens on the first stage. There seem to be a lot of "you lose" card combos in the shadow deck (like a second Cave Troll, the nasty Brown Land location if you've already travelled to a location, and just a lot of locations). None of the games has been at all fun. The hope I hold out for the game is rapidly diminishing.
---
Initial rating based on some solitaire play and giving the game the benefit of some doubt (which it may or may not deserve). Some interesting cooperative levers to pull, and the theme is reasonably well-done. Nice art. Some reasonably well-integrated randomness, which previous FFG LCGs have suffered the lack of. Far closer in flavor to the "ride on a rails" Decipher CCG than the much richer Middle Earth: The Wizards. Fans of MECCG should make sure not to expect too much here. It's FFG after all and somewhat mechanical. FFG in-house designs are mostly blender jobs, with mechanisms pieced together from other games and maybe a few extra blunt force design ideas, and LotR:tCG isn't much different. But, it does seem like it'll be a lot better than the Decipher game was.

Out-of-the-box playability, especially solitaire, is somewhat questionable. First quest is a cake walk, second quest I think several of the pre-made decks are going to get immediately clobbered. You need either more players or to do some deck-building. The combat-heavy deck (Legolas & Gimli) can be especially hosed, while Eowyn can fairly easily keep threat low and rack up quest progress. It is an LCG, so what do you expect I suppose, but good, playable "fixed decks" are a feature of good CCGs which is noticeably absent here.

It's also slightly depressing to think that 15+ years on, none of FFG's LCGs have really evolved that much further than Magic: The Gathering - the design roots of instants, permanents, creatures, combat, tapping, and mana-like power are all still clearly identifiable in Lord of the Rings: The Card Game. As tools go they aren't bad, but this is a problem that could have used some imagination - see: Nightfall.

Anyway, that's a lot of negativity, but my overall impression is that the cooperative angle will work in interesting ways, and that while the design itself isn't more than workmanlike, it may be good enough. We'll see.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Really enjoyed the first play. Great 2p Co-op.

RATING: 5
I'm just not a fan of CCG's, and this is a little too close for my tastes.  It was still somewhat fun to play as a team game, as other players are much better at keeping track of everything that needs to be tracked than I am.  I've just never been a fan of most games that have cards with all kinds of symbols, special abilities, etc to keep track of, and while this one was tolerable in that regard, it still isn't that exciting to me.

I can also imagine this would be great for those that like to deck-build, trying to find an optimal deck for each mission.  I had fun enough just playing with standard decks, but can definitely see the appeal for those that are into it.

So, in the end, my rating doesn't mean the game blows.  It's just not my style.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I greatly dislike the Lord of the Rings IP. The books are filled with racism, sexism, and classism; and those are the heroes in a moral absolutist tale. Couple that with a writing style I found long and tedious, and there is absolutely nothing I enjoyed about them.

The game doesn't change much of that, although it does treat women much better than the original IP does, giving them more presence (as in there are far more of them in the game), full roles as opposed to supporting roles, and where they are just as heroic as the male characters.

Component-wise the game is short the number of cards required to do any deck-building (which, one might argue, is a key attraction of the xcg format).

And yet, I rate the game positively, because for all it's flaws it does have some solid positives.

It is a great co-op game. I found the solo game, since you don't have enough cards to do deck-building, a waste of time. However, the co-op game really drives home the cooperation through play as while decks are solid on their own, two decks playing side by side are more than the sum of their parts. When cards from different spheres are combined interesting and powerful effects can occur (think 1 + 1 = 3 instead of 2).

It's a co-op game where clear individuals work towards a common goal, but not always together. By which I mean that it's a co-op game with individuals as opposed to just one hive mind (which I've realised is essential for me to enjoy co-ops). This is seen in that battles are almost always solo, and that different spheres have different strengths and so work towards the same goals but often in their own way.

One needs to enjoy building decks before play in order to get the most from the game, mind. You have to have the time (and a play partner who has the time as well) to get to know the cards and build decks before play (lonely fun). If you don't enjoy that process, the game will quickly become unenjoyable.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

It's a fun solo/co-op that adds ccg stuff. Fun, but I think I hate FFG rulebooks and the need for immediate FAQ and errata. Traded because rankled at having to muddle my way through the unintuitive rules and crappy rulebook again.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
My criterion for rating games



http://boardgamegeek.com/geeklist/147053/item/2300390#item2300390


1) Sense of wonder: Great story and sense of anticipation as I wait to see what the quest has to throw at me. Also the deckbuilding provides a great deal of variation and I am always hoping my next card will help me. Gandalf, please?  Of course it being fantasy helps me like it even more.

2) Meaningful/fun decisions.  So many choices. Who should I commit to questing? Combat? Should I use this item on my heroes? Use it now? Later? When should I use this event card? So many tough decisions all the way to the end. 

3) Player interaction: Of course there is no interaction in the solo game, however with two players your playing together is vital for you to survive and beat the game. Teamwork is a vital part of this game.

4) Components/artwork Top notch artwork! I mean seriously this game looks amazing! Very fun game. 

5) Game length/complexity: perfect game length. I can knock out a couple of solo games in an hour and One 2 player game in an hour as well.

Bottom line: fun game that i do enjoy, but for some reason i just dont often want to play it.

I think this is a great product and it can only get better.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
In collection since 2015
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
While the card art and overall gloss of this game is very well done, in my initial look at this game I have to say that it just feels unpolished in comparison to the later AH: LCG in terms of narrative treatment, but is probably the better of the two in terms of solo play.

In essence players each pick a set of 1-3 heroes who come from one of several classes of cards. Each turn those heroes generate resource tokens of their class that are used to play cards from your hand that will either increase the size of your team with allies, give the team weapons, or otherwise pull off positive events.

The game is played primarily against the story deck and an accompanying deck of encounter cards that are randomly drawn each turn. Players ultimately want to exhaust their team to make progress on the quest using one of their stats, but the encounter decks continuously spits out enemies and locations that will make it harder and harder to make progress unless they are dealt with first, and doing this also will exhaust your team for the round; this is the juggling act of the game.

Though the game plays pretty smoothly once you get going with it the difficulty seems very dependent on how the encounter decks flips out, as it is very easy for it to be generous or very nasty depending on how fast the high threat cards come out, as those are what create speed bumps for the team.

I'm not crazy about the abstracted nature of the movement on this relative to Arkham Horror: LCG, and I also think the theme is significantly worse than Arkham mostly because of that lack of board play (locations have a much richer theme in Arkham whereas here they are just abstracted in terms of how you visit them) and because there is only a single deck in this to provide a theme gloss whereas Arkham has 2 and an accompanying narrative campaign to pull the thing together. LotR does seem like it is more of a gamer's type game in the sense of min-maxing and deck-building, but its thematic immersion is much lower for me.

On the plus side, if you're into it, solo play seems much more reasonable here though, as there don't seem to be as many ways for the players to really help each other out effectively here and the nature of the team you build for your own deck means you can easily build a diverse solo deck to tackle whatever the scenario might want to throw at you. I wouldn't object strenuously to playing this is someone had decks and wanted to, but I doubt I will really dive into it as I don't do a lot of solo gaming and I don't see my gf playing this one in lieu of Arkham as the continuous deck-building would be a bug and not a feature for her. In other words: textbook 5 and I doubt it'll get back to the table.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

It provides one of the best [color=red]solitaire[/color] experience (one or two hands), both epic and tactic... pure fun! High replayability increased by customizing the player deck, also making it stronger or weaker. Six new scenarios by [i]NinjaDork[/i] available on BGG file-section.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Update: I have played the game a lot (by my standards). Usually solo with two-player rules, i.e. two decks. However, I do not think that the game deserves a higher rating than 7: all the problems that I described in the initial comment  - thin theme, poor scaling, poor scenario design, imbalance in usefulness of player cards, opaque rules - are clearly there. The number of plays reflects the fact that an individual game can be very short. However, I have to admit that with several expansions the game is sufficiently diverse and customizable to keep my attention. (Of course, it also means that I have spent far too much - expansions are overpriced.)

------
Update: I changed the rating from 6 to 7. The game is markedly better with 2 or 3 players, although it may be a bit too easy for 3 players. More interesting combos can be pulled off. The decks are sufficiently diverse that each player can contribute in a distinct way. Most importantly, the game feels like a coop instead of a solo puzzle where you have to negotiate with other players to be able to do what you want to do. There is enough hidden information that the more experienced player cannot dominate easily. 

---------
 
The game looks gorgeous, has opaque rules and glaring gameplay issues. In other words, it is a typical FFG game. The game has the potential to be superb, however, the potential is not realized in the core set and the chances that the expansions will change this are virtually zero because the problems are too fundamental. 

The game looks like most other FFG games, that is, it looks great (rating +2). It plays quick (rating +1). I also happen to like the Middle Earth theme (rating +1). Unfortunately, the theme is not well implemented and is rather thin (rating -1). So, Eowyn the princess of Rohan and Denethor the Steward of Gondor have started new career as messengers for the King Thranduir?!! Moreover, most of the time you do not feel like exploring Middle. The biggest immersion killer is the fact that locations exist in multiples. Unfortunately, the game has more serious issues than poorly implemented theme. Firstly, the pacing is wrong (rating -2). The quests are brutally difficult in the beginning: you must have luck in drawing cards and you have to take great risks or the game is over. However, once you have managed to get a decent number of cards on the table it often gets too easy. Secondly, the players' cards are very unequal in power (rating -1). Some cards are so good as to be nearly broken (e.g. Steward of Gondor, Northern Tracker) while other cards have very limited use (e.g. Rain of Arrows). Thirdly, the game does not scale properly (rating -1). It is much more difficult solo than with two players and I suspect that it is too easy with four players. Also, you can theoretically play with 1-3 heroes per player but you want three in practice - you very much need the extra starting power and additional resources. (I started my first âEscape from Dol Guldur" quest solo with one hero. That was a really quick game! No further comments - I do not want to spoil it for you - try it yourself. ;) ) In short, the game is not great but there is some entertainment in it.

RATING: 9
If viewed as a thematic game, this game fails on a number of counts. The whole game feels like it's in the wrong order, the best days for the fellowship were at the start and the darkest days were at the end, in this, you often have to hold on for dear life in the first few turns but coast across the finish line. Fortunately I'm a Eurogamer, so can forgive many sins in the pursuit of a good game. The gameplay is addictive and I love the teamwork in the LCG format. I think that the game would possibly work better with a different theme, but it does make it very accessible.
