=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I don't rate many games a 10 - and I NEVER thought I would give a 10 to a collectible card game.  I was a Magic collector/player when it was new and fresh, but after I burned out on the never-ending Magic franchise, have not returned to CCG's since.  I have little patience for deck building and hate the normal pay-for-power CCG structure, so the LCG concept is the only way I could have returned to deck-building card games - bravo FFG!  That being said, this game is AWESOME!! Great solo and team play, theme perfection true to the Tolkien stories and world.  Truly brilliant how each Quest is a mini-story, with its own unique rules, special events and cards that create a very thematic and diverse library of ways to play this game that revolve around the core mechanic and cards used to construct decks that adapt to each unique challenge.  And the game just keeps getting better and better as they explore more of the Tolkien world, adapting the books directly into the game as saga expansions that allow you to play the characters from the stories, completing the very same quests out of the books.  This is the BEST deck-building CCG style card game I have experienced and I look forward to each new quest as if it is the release of a new adventure to experience.

RATING: 10
SOLO PLAY:

1 Player Minimum
4 Player Maximum
This game is amazing!
After 10 games, at least winning one time with each of the pre-made decks I am hooked. Now I am making tournament decks with at least 50 cards. Creating decks with 2 spheres to see how they interact together. Great game. Great for solo play.

Addition: The advantage to playing 4 players vs 1. You have 12 heroes with special abilities instead of 3. Huge advantage in my opinion.

Addition: Seriously can not play this enough. The scenarios are varied and the play is fun and challenging.

Game Terms:
EASY MODE: -Add one Resource to each Hero's Resource Pool. -Remove all Encounter Cards with the Difficulty Indicator (gold band.)
TIME x: Remove one Time Counter at the end of the Refresh Phase.

4.25
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Pretty amazing game.  I've only played solitaire, and every time it has been a cinematic experience.  Somehow, the quest cards and game mechanics make it quite easy to imagine the story/scenario you're playing out with these cards.  It really does feel like an adventure.  And some of the quests are absolutely infuriatingly difficult.  I've pounded the table more than once after an hour investment only to barely lose in the end.  Building the right deck becomes important fairly quickly in the scenarios, and it can be fun to try out the nearly infinite possibilities.  On the other hand, losing a lot can turn some people off, especially those of us with jobs and families who can't make this our life aim.  Still, one of my most prized games, especially when I want to play a game by myself.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Components: Gorgeous art, graphic design. Good iconography. Like most games in this genre, the text on the cards is way too small. Flavor text is cool, but I would gladly lose it to double the font size of the text that matters. I can imagine this will only get worse as I get older.

Experience: Jury is still out. Like Lord of the Rings and The Lord of the Rings TCG, questing through regions is fun, and brings with it an impending sense of doom. At times we felt so close, but then the forces of evil mounted, and eventually suffocated us.

Whereas the TCG brought the idea of Twilight as currency, exertion (wounding oneself for an effect), and each player playing as both the freepeoples and minions, this game introduces the staging area, and how its threat level slows down our progress, giving the sense of a dungeon level that we must clear before we can proceed. That's a fun mechanism. Not much else is new here, as most of the other mechanisms just flow naturally from the source material.

The rules seemed mostly straight forward, but in execution they were more fiddly than I had anticipated. We had to constantly step through the phase sequence in the back of the rules, not only to determine which step was next, but especially to know when we could play actions or not. There's a lot of terminology to learn. In the base set, the keywords don't seem to serve much purpose, and various complexities in the rules (e.g., behavior of unique cards) are mostly not applicable. Through repeated play, this problem would go away.

We felt like we were winning a war of attrition against Ungoliant's Spawn, but then a nasty Shadow effect all but wiped my party. From that moment on, we were certain of defeat, yet still had to play out three depressing rounds (a la Risk) waiting for the game to end, which wasn't much fun. In the TCG, Frodo could often find a way to escape such odds and make it to Mt. Doom. But in this game, where the only thing that matters was Attack Strength vs. the spawn's Defense Strength, there was no hope in sight.

First Played: 2014-07-15
Last Played: 2014-07-17
Plays (2):
1 player: 1
2 players: 1
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
2 Core Sets
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Expansions: Khazad-dum
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
If you love Tolkien's work, do yourself a favor and get this game.  The artwork and flavor of the game just exudes Middle-Earth, and it is truly a delight to play.  The core mechanics are pretty easy to pick up, and yet the depth of the game is staggering, with all the card combinations/strategies you can employ.  And the best thing is, it is challenging!  It wouldn't be fun if winning was easy, right?!  Just like Frodo's journey was no walk in the park, completing scenarios in this game really give you a sense of accomplishment, given the many perils you'll encounter and have to overcome.  Did I mention the card art was out of this world?!

Gandalfâ than actual pleasure of playing it, but after this martyrium there is sweet price indeed.

RATING: 7
6 might be too low, but the description is about right.  Mainly, my beef is with it being a co-op.  I want to build a deck so I can try to beat my buddy with it, and so we can talk about how cool each other's combos and stuff were afterward.  Isn't this sort of like an arms race where only one side shows up?  The challenge deck doesn't design new combos or react to what I'm making.  Nor can it appreciate a clever play or deck theme.

I love Lord of the Rings.  I like designing decks.  I want to love this game, but I'm just not sure the co-op concept makes any sense to me.  OK, true, some people might also feel it was weird to have (say) an Elf Deck battling against an Ent deck or Ranger deck or something, but we're sort of used that by now aren't we?

RATING: 7
Played one, two and three players. Very clever cooperative game with a heavy Tolkien theme that seems to come alive for me.  Much more going on than in most coops and requires heavy cooperation to win, while eliminating the "I'll play for both of us" problem many have. I'm constantly amazed at the game mechanisms that create a story while you play, and am looking forward to playing more. 

Update: the mechanistic nature of the game as well as various timing issues get in the way of the story, which I'm finding a bit frustrating. Still enjoy playing but I'm hoping the scenarios get better as we get deeper into the game. I've heard they do, so fingers crossed.

Update again: Iâm finding the Arkham Horror LCG to be fantastic and havenât played LotR since Arkham came out. Still plan to get back to it eventually.

RATING: 5
(My comments based on Solo play)
I've heard lots of positives regarding this game, but I have to admit: I just didn't *get* it.

Positives: It is wonderfully strategic. It is great that you can customise the cards used within the game in order to best tackle the scenario. 
Definitely less daunting to new players if you separate all the cards into their respective decks. You can safely return 75% to the box as they won't be used in the starting scenario.

Personally: This was my first deckbuilding game. Sadly, I suspect it has revealed that deckbuilders aren't for me. The thrill of deciding which cards to include in your hand just wasn't there.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I owned this game a while before I actually figured out how to play correctly (the first few times were attempts before I had more experience as a board gamer), this has been the most difficult game I have ever had to learn up to this point in my life.  The amount of cards in the core set isn't overwhelming, but the rulebook is pretty lengthy, and I feel it doesn't easily summarize all the little details and questions that would come up when trying to play for the first few times.  I'm not sure how it could have been written better, but I just feel like that was part of the reason I initially gave up.  I would play, and have a question, and spend five minutes searching the rulebook for the answer.  Sometimes I found the answer, and sometimes I wouldn't so I would just guess what to do so I could try to keep playing.  To anyone trying this game for the first time, I would highly recommend watching the "Watch it played" series on how to play, it helped me immensely.  My final score is based on both how much fun I've had playing, and how frustrating it was to learn.  I would score it a little higher, but I can't ignore how difficult it was to finally get to enjoy.

RATING: 7.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
When the game first came out, I looked into it, but passed it over based on reviews and the FFG video.  A couple of years later, after getting into Netrunner (my first LCG), I decided to check out some of the other LCGs to see if they were just as awesome.  I was drawn to LOTR because I can play it solo.

I picked up two core sets, because I wanted to have at least two decks put together without swapping cards around.  I really liked the gameplay.  It feels like a puzzle that I have to solve, but the theme really comes out in the quest cards.  Through the game mechanics, it feels like there is a troll guarding the raft.  Then I'm on the raft floating down the river, while hordes of enemies gather along the banks chasing after me, peppering me with arrows.  Eventually, I'll get off the raft and have to battle all of the baddies that kept up with me.

I've acquired the other cards, but haven't really played around with them yet.  At first I looked to the internet for decks, now I am starting to build my own.  I have also started playing solo with two decks.  I find it very interesting to try and build two different decks that compliment one another.  Unlike other games of this ilk, where sometimes I have taken apart decks without ever playing them in order to build new ones, I can get instant feedback by playing the game solo at home.  I don't have to wait until I can manage to get out and find someone else to play against.  I was was going to be stranded all alone on a desert island, I think this might be the game I'd want with me.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This game immediately became my wife's most-requested game. In 9 months, we have played more than 100 games, outpacing Pandemic by a mile. We love it. The quest-to-quest variations in mechanics and win conditions is what makes this game, and requires us to re-build our decks with good frequency. It also makes for some very thematic moments. The only thing that keeps this from getting a 10-rating is the cost. The base game comes with 3 scenarios. So in order to get that replay value, you've got to keep spending money. Lots of money. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Lord of the Rings: The Card Game is my all time favorite game. Here is my top five list of reasons why:

5. The Lord of the Rings theme. I admit it. I am a sucker for Tolkien. In my youth, I read the trilogy every year and it is still my favorite book. But more than that, the adventure based game transports me to Middle Earth. I really feel like I am in control of Aragorn, Gandalf, or Frodo because the theme is so powerfully meshed with gameplay.

4. Great artwork. The card art is original and beautiful. It is new LotR art that somehow feels as though it always existed in Middle Earth canon. Great art helps players immerse themselves in the theme. 

3. Replayability. Playing against the same adventure with the same deck over and over again is possible because of the randomness inherent to drawing cards. You can play against the same adventure seeing new cards each time. Or you can build your deck specifically to defeat the adventure, tweaking it by a card or two each iteration until it is a finely tuned adventure winner. 

2. Deck construction. There are multitudes of strategies available. I can play aggressively, defensively, go for the quick win, or play with a long threat reduction deck. I can build a deck around Hobbits, or men, or build it around powerful allies. I love being in control of my own success or demise. Each expansion adds more cards and combinations to the player pool without ruining game balance. 

1. The solo game. This game works so well as a solitaire game that I forget sometimes it is actually a coop. Often, in other games converted to solo play, I feel constricted by rules modifications. In LotR, the solo game is actually my preferred method of play.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Having played the game over half a dozen times at this point, both 1p and 2p, I feel I can finally make some comments about it.

It's an interesting game with some interesting mechanics. I like the deck construction aspect, and the threat level forces you to balance the numbers when it comes to your leader selection. The mechanics themselves are mostly sound, though it does feel strange that you can Quest or Fight, but can't do both. I like the idea of making Questing optional so that you can focus on combat without eating a bunch of threat level points.

As far as game play itself, things are a little shaky. There are only 3 scenarios, and as soon as things get remotely difficult, playing one-handed is simply going to be an exercise in futility. That means either running two decks or finding someone else to play. And, if one player has a "combat" deck, you're going to have to play the "quester/healer" deck, which isn't much fun.

The rules for deck construction are probably too difficult, and I quickly opted for the 40-card variant that I think was posted here. It makes more sense, and it's more fun when all you have are the core cards.

Anyway, at the end of the day, I guess I like it but I don't love it. I probably won't buy the expansions but I'll play it from time to time, at least until I can defeat the more difficult scenarios. If I ever reach that point I'll probably trade it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is by far my favorite coop/solo game. I would go as far to say that it's one of the best coop/solo games out there. But fair warning this is not a game for casual gamers because it's complex and hard. I prefer playing this game with 2 players or if I'm by myself then 2 decks, but many solo gamers play with a single deck vs the quest. 

This is an LCG (Living Card Game) so it is encouraged that you buy the deluxe expansions and adventure packs in order to have a larger card pool to create your deck/s. For some people this might be a negative. The deluxe expansions are required for their smaller corresponding adventure packs because they come with the cards that are meant to be mixed in with them (you'll understand if you play the game). There are also saga expansions that follow along with the books. You can find out more about the different expansions at Fantasy Flight Games.

It can take a long time to build a workable deck, but that's part of the fun. Hall Of Beorn and Tales From The Cards are great websites for deck ideas. I would recommend keeping track of your deck creations by typing them out. Also this game can be very difficult but it gets easier after you know how everything works. However be prepared to lose a lot in certain quests. I like to look at the quest cards before I begin to make sure I am not required to bring anything. For example: cards to help lower my threat level or cards with the ranged keyword to attack enemies that I otherwise could not.

All and all If you like a theme rich, deep, challenging game that makes you think about your actions then this is definitely a great game to check out. If you have any questions try Google searching for answers. Or you can try asking people on Board Game Geek or the Lord of the Rings: The Card Game forum. Both sites have friendly people who are willing to answer questions.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
After my first couple of plays with this solo with the pre-constructed decks I rated the game about a 7, but with a few more solo plays it started declining to somewhere around a 5.5.

However, subsequently playing it 2-player adds a 1.5 to the rating - the game is clearly intended for 2.

Then, once you have a few expansions, the deck-building aspect really makes the game shine lifting the rating by another 1.5. So be warned, if you don't like deck-building or don't want to buy additional decks to enable the deck-building (and for additional adventures) then this is not the game for you.

I'm still really enjoying this. Also, as the card pool has extended I think solitaire is becoming an option again for me to get into. Udged up another rating point.

Note - the 3rd scenario, 'Escape form Dol Guldur', is stupidly difficult when attempted solo. There is no scaling to adjust the difficulty from being played 2-player (in which it is still hard). Don't let this put you off fro the rest of the game, the designers did get better at this kind of thing but some errata'd rules should have been fed back in to make this scenario more accessible single player - even the 'easy' mode card removals don't help much. I would probably knock 2 pts from my rating just based on the base set, because of this, but my rating is for the game overall.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9

This will be a 10 if I'm still playing in a couple of months.

Highly recommended.

RATING: 5
I though Lord of the Rings: TCG was adequate, but playing it reaffirmed that I have no interested in playing it over most other two-player card games. I would much rather play Yomi, Puzzle Strike, Race For the Galaxy, or Innovation. I would nod mind playing it again, but I am not going to go out of my way to do so and found that it largely lacked tension or anything particularly interesting going on once you get a hang of the system. 

I think my problem with it may simply be be a reflection of my problem with cooperative games in general, any "system" developed for a board game has to be simple enough that by its nature it will lack the depth you can get out of a good strategic computer game thus, when push comes to shove, I will almost always end up choosing to play a good computer game over a cooperative board game. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Players take a party of heroes into Middle Earth, trying to complete quests while avoiding being thwarted by the servants of Sauron.  Simple, rather mechanical card game where players cooperate against a game driven quest.  Players go in armed with three heroes and a pre-constructed (or constructed) deck of cards.  Players step through a seven phase turn sequence; draw card, play cards, quest, engage, defend, attack, refresh.  The quest is the important bit, as you try to get to the next quest card - the rest is simply road blocks and mechanics.  Some nice ideas and plays smoothly enough.  As a 30 year LOTR fan, I didn't engage with the theme, and found myself thinking things like "was Eowyn even born at this time?", and why are two Dwarves both Steward of Gondor?  I'm not sure I'm a fan of the invented characters either.  Still, slap Lord of the Rings on it and they will come, and it certainly isn't awful, just feels clunky and dull.  Much rather break out the brilliant War of the Ring from Nexus, which is one of the greats and it nailed the theme perfectly.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
Great deck construction co-operative game.  the 3 included quests are perfect.  Passage Through Mirkwood is the perfect introduction to the game, Journey Down the Anduin is still fun and engaging many years later, and Escape from Dol Guldur is still one of the hardest quests in the game.
They cover the base mechanics of the game very well, and the included cards showcase the sphere colour pie adequately, Leadership focuses on action advantage, resource acceleration, and strengthening allies; Tactics is almost completely combat-oriented, utilising armour, weapon, and item attachments to help equip your heroes and allies; Spirit excels as threat manipulation, cancellation, and high willpower for strong questing; Lore's stats are average across the board, able to fill in easily for questing, defending, or attacking as needed without focusing on any particular phase, but instead concentrates on healing, card draw acceleration, and traps.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
After 6 two-player games (6.5): The more I play the LOTR LCG, the more broken it feels.  Aside from seemingly demanding deck building from its players, the effects of shadows cards and the regular up-scaling of threats from the encounter deck work together to make the success at the game feel entirely based on exceptionally good luck at card draws.  A built deck becomes completely useless when a single "When Revealed" card can eliminate half your allies, or when you are suddenly pulling card after card into the staging area to the point that the threat level can never be realistically dealt with.  You instead feel that all the planning you put into the game ahead of time is simply overwhelmed by the volume of threats, rather than being able to fine tune your strategy as you go.  The end result is that you feel that you are playing the encounter deck, rather than having any significant role in the game's outcome.  The theme is excellent, and some of the quests retain their flavor of playing through an adventure, but over time, aside from building a deck specific to each quest that may or may not win, the repeated failures make this game more frustrating than fun.  I feel played out at the end of an LOTR game, and rarely rewarded for the effort I put in.  

Original Review: (9.7) Each of the Living Card Games has a very distinct feel; where Warhammer: Invasion feels like an action game, and Call of Cthulhu is more thoughtful, the Lord of the Rings' cooperative play and the unfolding storyline of the quest mechanic helps it to feel like a role-playing game without a lot of cumbersome mechanics to worry about.  I'd have a hard time choosing between this and Warhammer as a favorite LCG, but LOTR is a perfect way to introduce new gamers to the feel of accomplishment you can get from a good role-playing session, even if it's in card form.  An excellent game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is the wife's and my go-to game on a lazy afternoon.  The ability to incorporate up to four Tolkienistas on a cooperative quest even more versatile in strategy and tactical deck building.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.75
I've played this quite a few times, and really enjoy it.  There's some good tension between sending your guys on the quest to advance and fighting off the various baddies that the deck spawns.  I like the variety in the quests I've seen: some are more exploration-focused, some more about combat, and others are your hunt-the-maguffin or escort missions.  The deckbuilding likewise is pretty interesting, since each faction has different strengths, and you'll need some more than others depending on the scenario.  Once you get more cards, you'll have some more choices as to what kind of thing to include.  Of course, they do that annoying FFG thing where they only include 1 or 2 copies of key cards in the core set, but I suppose you can always proxy them - it is a co-op after all.

The design does have a couple flaws.  I'm going to compare it here to 2 other card games which share some mechanical similarities.  One is, of course, Magic, which gets compared to everything.  The other is Sentinels, which is substantially different in many respects, but has some comparable patterns in how it plays out.
A co-op card game like this is interesting because of the uncertainty of what hazards the central deck will spit out at you.  All deck-based games like these have the weakness that the deck may produce a super-hard, unbeatable game or an easy one depending on the shuffle.  I don't know that this one is as prone to the problem as the others and don't consider it a big deal, but it's still there.
These games also have certain play patterns.  At the start, you have few resources and a hand full of cards.  As the game progresses, you build up your board state and become more powerful, but only get 1 new card a turn, so you deplete your hand unless you're drawing extra.  The critical point is at the start, since that's when you are at your weakest, and have to invest in things that will be useful later.  If the game throws too many monsters at you in the very beginning, you'll have to burn so many resources just staying alive that you're likely to sink into a downward spiral.  Careful planning and clever card play will only get you so far.    LotR is quite 'bad' in this respect, since your sole source of income in most cases is hero cards.  Each hero produces 1 resource, so this means that you're getting 3 bucks each turn for the whole game.  You never produce more outside of special cards, only 1 of which is in the core game.  The cards in your hand range from cost 1 all the way up to 6.  The 1s &2s are still useful, but if you want any chance at all of playing the big 6-costers, you'll have to save up for 2 full turns.  This is hugely restrictive, and means that expensive cards aren't likely to get much use.  
Magic is ruled by the 1-land-per-turn restriction.  You start with little ability to play cards, then each turn (for at least the first few), you get more resources, until in the late game you can play your big finishers.  You can't save over mana from turn to turn, though.  Sentinels is a little different in that cards don't have costs associated with them, you just play them.  Most heroes, though, still require multiple plays to build up to their full strength.  My point here is that, in other games, you have more of a chance to build up your production.  The fact that, in LotR, you start with 3 and can only go down from there (if one of your heroes dies) means that getting a foothold early is absolutely critical.  Pretty much everything about the game requires you to play more units, or 'allies', since you need to send them on quests, have them soak up hits instead of your heroes, and band together to overcome the defense on monsters.  The game is very demanding of manpower in this way.  If you have the chance to build up your army a little, you can parlay that into greater success.  If you can't afford them, or have to sacrifice them in combat as soon as you play them, you'll struggle to advance.  I've played many times, and the easiest games have been ones in which we drew, in our opening hands, that one card I alluded to earlier.  This 'Steward of Gondor' card produces 2 extra resources per turn, at a cost of 2 to play out.  That's 66% more production every turn after the first, on which it pays for itself.  There's a reason Sol Ring is so strong in Magic.  You don't realize how much that cost bottleneck limits what you can do in the game until it's lifted.  So, in summary, I don't really like this way of paying for cards, and things that get around that restriction are bonkers powerful.
Worse still, the 4 factions in the game can be mixed and matched, but only under severe restrictions.  Each hero is assigned to one role, and the resources they make are of that role's 'color', or faction.  When you're using those resources to pay for things, they can only be spent on cards from the matching faction (or the handful of neutral cards that exist).  Each card must be paid for with [i]entirely[/i] faction-matching resources.  (Picture trying to play a red/green deck where [i]every[/i] 2-drop cost RR or GG, every 3-drop was RRR or GGG, etc.  It just wouldn't work.)  This means that if you decide to mix factions, 1 of your 3 starting heroes will be off-color, so you'll be hugely limited in what cards of that faction you can include.  Even a relatively cheap 3-cost card (which you could ordinarily play on the 1st turn) will now require you to save up for 3 whole turns.  And now, your primary faction has had its budget slashed as well, and you'll have to save up longer to play costly cards, or just not include them.  There are 'song' cards which mitigate this by making one of your heroes 2-color, but my impression was that they were pretty weak, and you have to draw them early if they're to be of any use.  Plus, you're investing some of your precious early resources just to get back near the functionality that pure-color decks have to start.
The threat system is another minor annoyance.  At the start, you sum the threat values on your heroes, so the more powerful crew you take, the more likely you are to attract attention.  If you don't send enough guys on the quest, or get swamped with cards, your threat will skyrocket (the difference in your quest value and the combined threat of the central display is how much you gain/lose), causing more enemies to attack you.  This means you'll have to devote troops to fending them off &/or killing them, leaving fewer to quest, etc.  You're also on a timer, and threat ticks up by 1 every turn no matter what you do.  Now, you can attempt to do a stealthy run, where you use 2 or only 1 hero.  This will set your starting threat really low.  I admit I've never actually tried playing this way, but it seems to me that in most scenarios, this is going to be a huge mistake.  Permanently slashing your income by a large fraction is a massive deal, and the threat you'll save will likely be regained in a turn or 2 when you can't muster the manpower to stay ahead in the quest race.
Oh, and the deck-building rules are a little off in my estimation.  They want you to make a 50-card minimum deck, but you'll struggle to make 40 w/out including too much filler.  (This will change as you get more cards, to be certain, but you'll probably need more than the first set of packs to feel like you have some good choices.)

In general, this is still a fun game that I enjoy playing.  Trouble is, it's a pretty big money sink.  The club has the base set and the first several packs, but you'd have to play this one a [i]lot[/i] to justify buying all the expansions for it.  I can't, and don't know anyone who does, so it's not one I'll likely play much more.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
After two plays, I'm not impressed with the game; it's okay but nothing remarkable.  Add that to my lack of interest in building decks makes this a definite pass for me.

Also irksome is FFG adding in their fanfic characters as though they were canonical, and supplying somewhat-related quotes from the trilogy at the bottom to try and make it look authentic.  The whole feel of it is much closer to Dragonlance (or some other generic fantasy doorstop) than Tolkien.

The level of abstraction is also odd, resting uncomfortably between the gentle simplicity of Knizia's LOTR co-op (on one hand) and the sprawling simulationism of WOTR (on the other).  Both of these feel more authentic than the card game though -- I think the light theming of Knizia allows the player to project their experience onto the scaffolding of the mechanics, whereas the high level of detail in WOTR produces that feel just by following the rules.  The co-op card game has just enough rules to pull you away from the experience, but not enough to simulate what's actually going on.  The result is a very gamey feel that has nothing to do with LOTR.

Apparently this is doing quite well for FFG sales-wise.  More power to them, but I have zero interest in playing this again.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9

RATING: 6.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
-CCG like gameplay (check)
-Cooperative/Solo play (check)
-Large replay value (check)

So why am I only rating this a 5?  This should easily be a 9 for me based on the above criteria.  Where did it go wrong?  No where actually.  It seems that my habits have changed and I have been spoiled by tableau building card games such as Race/Gosu that I really abhor the time consumption of deck building.  It's quite strange as it was one of my favorite activities when I was into Magic: The Gathering.  I also can't really stomach paying $15/month + about $25 twice yearly.  I just don't like the idea of this constant money drain even though it does add a significant number of options.

Money and deck building aren't my only issues with the game however.  The game doesn't really scale well at this point in time.  The solo game with one player deck is the most difficult way to play.  Each player added makes the game significantly easier.  It's probably optimal as a two player game.  Beyond that, I really feel like there is some harsh randomness in the event/shadow deck which can really mess up your game.  Sometimes I feel the same can be said about other co-ops, but sometimes I feel there is a lot more randomness in this than other co-ops.  Finally, even with 3 Core Sets for maximum deck building possibilities, it just doesn't seem to offer wide variety at this point.  One of the Sphere's of Influence only has 3 different type of creatures.  In fact you can't even make a tournament legal deck of a single sphere and even when it get's to that point there won't be much deck building to it.

My final issue with the game is that with so many scenarios, it seems like eventually your deck is going to hit a scenario that just can't be beaten.  At this point you can make a deck that's a silver bullet but where's the fun in that?

I do think this is a great game for many reasons but it's just one that isn't for me due to the deck constructions and upkeep cost. If these weren't issues, I would still much rather play Netrunner.  Now that WHQACG is available, it's a good alternative to this for my tastes.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Cons:

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Game plays well as a 2 player game, and is girlfriend/wife friendly.  The variety in the base set is pretty lacking even in 2 player though, as constructing 2-3 sphere decks is almost strictly a disadvantage with only a single core set.  The 1, 3, and 4 player rules seem like they were not even playtested for balance.  I have never lost a 3-4 player game of any scenario, even when teaching people the game.  The 1 player game, however, is the opposite end of the spectrum, where only the 1st scenario is beatable without a ton of luck, and the Tactics deck will lose to even the 1st scenario 75% of the time.
In the end, wins and losses feel much more like they are determined by luck than anything else.  Making lots of wrong decisions will still get you a win in 3-4 player, and making 100% perfect decisions will usually still get you a loss in 1 player.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This game has been a revelation to me in that I never was a M:tG fan and had a predisposition against any sort of a CCG, LCG, or pre-play deck building -- yet after two years of playing, I love this game and rate it a 10. I never suspected that Iâd fall for the game the way I have to point of enjoying the pre-play deck building and buying so many expansions, but I do and I have. 

The brilliance of the game is how it succeeds in terms of richness of gameplay, cooperative interaction, and theme. The game is simply the best implementation, IMO, of what a gamerâs game, strategic coop should be. Building a deck that hums with card synergies engrosses me every play, and the way the game renders specific situations â be it going down the Anduin in a boat or getting shot at by guards behind a gate â is the definition of thematic to me. 

The way the victory conditions differ greatly from scenario to scenario keeps the experience fresh in ways that other games wish they could. And unlike other cooperative games where players are co-contributing more than co-operating, LOTR:TCG gives players plenty of options for playing cards to assist one another at every phase of the game while still leaving room for autonomy and individual creativity. I have a monthly cooperative game group and we're all-in on LOTR:TCG.

Overall, LOTR:tCG would be an 8 if it had been better calibrated for solitaire players like me. As it stands, Anduin is extremely difficult and Dol Guldur impossible.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
So, this game turns out to be totally addictive. Unfortunately, part of that addiction is centered around purchasing new expansions to get better cards for the players' decks.

The game was very hard to play using just the Core Set. Adding expansion cards helped a lot. So far, deck building in this game has been constrained by a lack of ally choices in Leadership and Spirit. My aforesaid addiction to purchasing expansions will no doubt solve that problem eventually.

In certain scenarios one player can find themselves having the same role every turn (defend/defend/defend or quest/quest/quest). That can get tedious. Also, we've found the game causing some tension between players over resource allocation, determining who can take the hit, and wanting to protect your characters vs protecting the other player's characters. That's probably both a strength and a weakness of the game. But since I value cooperation, I dislike the grasping, selfish feelings the game can occasionally engender in me when it starts to feel like my side of the team is getting chipped away. That may fade with time as I become more accustomed to losing allies/heroes -- or when I become a better person ;)

Tolkien purists may object to building decks that combine characters in ways that contradict the cannon. As, for example, taking a deck full of elves, horses, and eages into Moria, or playing characters together who never met. I couldn't care less about that kind of thing. I want a powerful deck with synergy. I enjoy using characters I remember from the books (and I grow fond of my heroes), but I don't care if the characters in my deck lived a hundred years and a thousand miles apart or never met.

All those warning aside, I'm thinking right this moment of when my next game can happen.  Addicting is a tame word for how much I like it. The game keeps the suspense going and doesn't take it easy on the players.  And, of course, the theme can't be beat.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Fantastic cooperative game.  Very difficult to beat at times, which enhances the overall play experience.  Ongoing FFG support adds new adventures each month.  

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Great game.  Extremely thematic, solid mechanics, and very diverse due to the scenario-oriented design.  Every scenario is a new challenge.  Possibly the best of the LCG's that I have played to date.

Rating based on core set play only.  I have the first 6 adventure packs but haven't gotten to them yet.  I really don't foresee finding anything in those packs that will dampen my enthusiasm for the game though.  In fact, I fully expect the addition of more cards and scenarios to make the game even richer and more exciting.

I love the fact that the art is hand-painted, as opposed to movie stills.  Great decision that makes the game much more timeless, like the books themselves.  I'm a fan of the movies, but I vastly prefer the hand-painted art to the movie stills featured in the older LotR card game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
What surprises me most in this fine card game is the dependable emergence of thrilling stories from its simple structure. The three very different scenarios in the core set showcase the versatility of the system, both in variety of play and in difficulty scaling. It did not need to be the most beautiful card game in print, but it is too. Production and play are so top notch that I cannot but find laughable the hype behind a much inferior [url=http://boardgamegeek.com/boardgame/133038/pathfinder-adventure-card-game-rise-runelords-base]other fantasy card game[/url] that was redundantly published two years after LotR. If Fury of Dracula is the best board game adaptation of a literary work, LotR LCG must be the best card game adaptation. It can be a tiring game; depending on the number of allies and enemies in play, a typical turn will involve many checks and calculations (reminiscent of Core Worlds). I also suspect the optimal configuration with two players is having one as a main combat deck (Leadership and Tactics) and the other as a support deck (Spirit and Lore), which can render the game less interesting for the supporting player. But the jury is still out about that.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Need more plays to assess.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
[b]Divested myself of all LotR:CG. Just too fiddly and too difficult (even on Easy mode). Shame. Art is amazing, encounter deck is clever.[/b]

Played 20+ times with 1-3 players.

Dec 2011: Two parts Magic the Gathering, one part Knizia's Lord of the Rings co-op. My first four games were all against the first quest, one game each with each sphere deck just to learn what each deck could and couldn't do. Very impressed with the game design. If they had included just 3 more quests in the box, or would sell a special quest pack so I could play more with the base game, I think this would be a 10 for me. As is, it's a 9, and I can't see any way this game would ever fall below 8 for me.

Jan 2012: I find that the hard challenges are quite hard, which, in theory is good. But it means I can never play this game casually or with non-gamers. I need people (with decks, preferably) who specialize in this game. That - in my opinion - is not a good quality in a game.

March 2014: Played with two new players in a 3-player game, and everyone had a blast. This is scratching my Magic itch, but without the money-sink and power-differential problem. This game is about to take a lot of money out of my wallet...

August 2015: As a solo game (the only way I play it), it's too fiddly, too difficult, and too time-consuming.

Rating history: 10|8|10|8|8..|6........|4.

RATING: 9
Great game solo and for 2. (can't speak of more players)
I like it that diferent decks play really different. Most scenarios have a different flavor and the special rules for each scenario transport the theme greatly. 
What I don't love as much:
- deck building can take some time and if you want to play another deck than the last time you have to plan some time.
- Some scenarios aren't that great. If you want to win the possibilities are too restricted. Some Scenarios aren't well designed for single-handed sologames. They are too hard or just don't transport the special theme of the scenario. Some adventurecards are too strong. They make the scenario a hit or miss - if I encounter this special card I will die otherwise I will win.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Pros: Beautiful artwork; complex, but not convoluted rules and structure; don't need a ton of table space to play (at least solo or coop); strong replay value; good solo game; interesting mechanics; living card game format allows for less "luck" in buying cards and forming decks; deck building is fun

Cons: LCG format can still be expensive to build up a strong collection; Luck of the draw is too often the reason for a win or a loss (although deck building strategy matters most); uneven difficulty based upon solo vs coop and across varying "official" difficulty levels of scenarios; some quests very frustrating to beat (this could be seen as a pro too)

Overall: I think this is a great game, especially for someone who can't always get together a group on a regular basis to play, the game is more than adequate solo.

RATING: 6
[i]July 2012[/i]: Rating of 7. Fallen out of favor and put on my trade list. It's a pain to keep up with the new cards every few months.
[i]May 2011[/i]: Rating of "8". Very good, fun game. Regret not buying the game sooner. Awesome value for the money. The theme and gameplay are compelling and could see the rating increasing to a "9".

[u]Pros:[/u] 
+Oozes with Narrative flavour. As with many the other thematic games I like (Arkham Horror, Thunderstone), I have a great time even when I lose
+STUNNING & FANTASTIC art on all of the game components. Even cardboard tokens don't feel like cardboard game chits
+Easy to learn the basic rules. Was able to get a good handle on the rules within a couple of games.
+Great potential. Looking forward to new cards, heroes, etc. With FFG, there are sure to be expansions. 
+Good amount of replayability

[i]Cons (and rebuttals): [/i]
-Few scenarios (but great replayability)
-Quite a few amiguities in the cards and rules (which are mostly addressed via the unofficial FAQs here on BGG)
-Compels completists and tourney players to buy multiple sets (but no one is holding a dagger at your throat to buy more)
-Poor card storage (e.g. No dividers)

RATING: 7
Relatively easy to play, but difficult to win. The game is rather convoluted, but it is those convolutions which make it the game that it is and separates it from other card games of this type. As such, I think you either like it or your don't. Oddly enough, I say that, but I think I'm in the middle. I like the theme (of course!) and the flow, but really didn't care for some of the mechanics and the way the game forces everything to get to a situation where players will die 75% of the time and it is only on the best of luck on the next few card pulls that will determine whether there is a reprieve. I honestly didn't feel like the decisions I was make was having the kind of critical impact that engages me in a game like this. That aside, the game is easy enough to play that I would try it again if asked, but I wouldn't invest in it myself, especially considering its LCG thang, which I've sort of told myself I wouldn't sink into (I've already got X-Wing to dump all my cash into!)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Playing [b][i]Lord of the Rings LCG[/i][/b] feels like you're going on a quest through Arda. That's what I wanted from this game and the game delivers. It's great in groups, but best (for me) as a solitaire game. It's been my favorite solitaire game from the time I first quested with the starter decks in Mirkwood; the expansion packs have only increased my enjoyment. The quests are thematic, the gameplay is evocative, and the art is fantastic.

When the game was first released the rules were a bit vague in places, but this has largely been corrected through FFG's FAQs. Specific quests don't always scale to different numbers of players, but this just makes some quests more easy or difficult--not a big deal in a cooperative game. You probably would want to buy into the quest packs to achieve serious replay-ability; the added player cards and new quests really opens up the game. Quest variability, while a good thing for overall game variability, does mean that some quests are really good while others are just okay. And because this game heavily depends on the thematic material, I don't think I can recommend it to somebody who is unfamiliar with Tolkien's world.

[b]Passage Through Mirkwood (1):[/b] This is a great introductory quest. The difficulty level is perfect; you'll probably lose your first time, but after you learn the game you will win every time. It's thematic and made me imagine I was entering Mirkwood. I particularly like the random objective for the 3rd portion of the quest.

[b]Journey Down the Anduin (4):[/b] Some people say this quest is too difficult for a Core Set quest. Perhaps this is correct because it seems to be a popular belief as evidenced by numerous threads discussing how to beat this quest. I, however, think this is a perfect 2nd quest. It is difficult, but you can regularly win with cards available from a single core set and the difficulty makes the victories sweet. It also shows you something new in the quest formula that hints at future possibilities. The difficulty level, fun story cleverly translated to gameplay mechanics, and overall tough choices on when to advance the quest make this my favorite core set scenario.

[b]Escape from Dol Guldur (7):[/b] This remains the most difficult solo quest. I wish this quest better scaled to one player, but I also enjoy the tremendous difficulty. It's not impossible for one player to win with just the core set, but it is unlikely and difficult.

âsâ

RATING: 4
I'm moderately enjoying it, I really do think it's a great concept and I like the attempt to put adventuring and locations in the game instead of just fighting.  Unfortunately it is brutally procedural, especially for such a short game.  There's so much procedure I have a hard time getting into a rhythm with the game.  That is critical for me with solitaire games, otherwise it's just an extended bookkeeping.

Also, the whole character defends and uses shields but is then exhausted and needs someone else to attack monsters just doesn't really make any sense to me and seems artificially limiting.  All characters feel like attacking or defending wall cards from MtG or something.  There's tons of just getting as many shitty units, sorry, "allies," to be suicided on the tough monsters...  not terribly heroic, that.  Aragorn: "random guard guy!  Go defend against that orc group and die while I go around behind them and beat the crap out of them!"

This is one of those games I want to see the next iteration of, because this one is just a little lacking of something.  

Edit: this game is FIRED from my collection in a world where Pathfinder exists.  I know this game is harder and not exactly the same type of game, but man is Pathfinder more fun.

RATING: 6
I've been enjoying this game quite a bit. I think once i start using deck building options and go through the more advanced scenarios it will be even more enjoyable. I like that there is no real deck building mechanic during the game. I also like the cooperative element, it is sort of what I like from thunderstone minus the deck building which is a mechanic I do not enjoy much. Look forward to more plays.

This is sort of what I wish thunderstone was. Coop card play vs a very strong game senario. This game is a lot of fun, particularly after exploring various deck building options. It really does bring me back to playing games like Magic when I was in junior high and it is simply a well made game that is a lot of fun with the right players or solitaire.

RATING: 8.5
First time I have bought or played a Card Game. Three things interested me in this. (1) it is co-op (1-4 players), (2) it can be experienced solo, (3) it is Middle Earth!

OK, I am a board gamer, not a card player, so this was a stretch. But I took the plunge early Jan 2013 and bought it, and tried it out. Result....I enjoyed it. It was everything I was hoping. Challenging, enjoyable, Middle Earth richness. Tried it with my 21 yo son, and he enjoyed it as well. It will get many plays from me and my wife. And I have already started down the expansions path....I think they reeled me in on this one.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Most cooperative games seem to use the same formula; having a scenario where semi-random threats are appearing in a never ending fashion. This game is no exception to that. Personally, I found this to be one of the stronger games of that genre because of the theme and the strong deck building aspect. When we play, we usually choose two spheres and build a deck around it and then play the scenario and then maybe make adjustments.

Some plays can leave you a little sour and that is especially true when they are stalling. With the releases of more adventure packs I suspect the game will be even more fun.

I donât have experience playing collectible card games because I usually shield away from them because of the collectable nature, but because I can build a deck right before I play, the non-collectable aspect and it is cooperative makes me interested in digging deeper into the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
It is easy to get discouraged with this game, particularly as you are learning how to play. The game punches hard, and you are frequently overwhelmed before you can get your feet under you. There's really little to do except shrug and re-deal. Push through the pain and you will find a richly-themed game, and rich theme is where it's at when I play solo. (Partner play is fun, too). Each scenario is a puzzle solved by deck-building and tactics. When you've beaten a scenario there isn't much incentive to return, unless you like deck building for its own sake (I don't) or you want to improve your score (I record them but don't put much stock in them). Particularly enjoy playing through the Saga expansion, with scenarios directly inspired by the books.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Highly thematic but not as deep in gameplay. It felt overly complicated, lots of phases to basicly just make
two tests; one for the will power within the adventure and one for the fighting strength when facing enemies.
The decisions you make like "will I block with this character or should I use him to attack?" are comparable to MtG.
So it didn't felt that unique as I expected based on reviews. Still an OK game underneath all this chrome.
Strange: "if you buy another base game you can play up to four players" -> you can already do so with one base
game. There are enough cards (factions) in it. The only thing that is missing are the threat-counters. Not fair from FFG to urge you buying a whole second game for basicly just the counters you will need... however I wouldn't play it with more than two player due to expected downtime.

UPDATE
Dropped this for a year and a half, after trying the base game and finding it wanting. After a few games with multiple core sets and expansions, have raised my rating. It's a lot of fun getting together with a like minded friend and working out the arithmetic.

Solo? That's a different experience. It sucks. Most scenarios are  unplayable with just one hero deck, and if I have to play two, well, why not just call any other game a solo game?

Older comment below...

I have to admit that I simply don't get it. Turns a rich literary achievement into a dry, card-pushing exercise in basic arithmetic (though something similar can be said about much contemporary "thematic" fantasy).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is a game that can really morph into a hobby. I love it, and I have picked up quite a few packs for it.

Basically, I have been out of Magic the Gathering for years and years. But I always loved deckbuilding and playing. 

LotR: LCG scratches that deckbuilding itch, and the fact that it's cooperative suits my personal tastes extremely well. Everybody who likes Magic that I've played with has gotten into this. 

That said, it is very challenging. It is also pretty fiddly, since there are so many keywords and things to track in the middle of the game. But the fact that it's mainly restricted to 1 or 2 players mitigates the boredom one might feel while fiddling with stuff. 

If you have a gaming partner with the appropriate Magic-like disposition, this is a fantastic game with wonderfully crafted scenarios.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
My favorite adventure card game right now. 3 or 4 scenarios that you can play with 4 different groups of heros, so replay is pretty high even without buying any expansions. Can support 3 or 4 players if you buy a second core set. The theme comes through loud and clear, and the game's atmosphere strongly evokes the novels that inspired the game.

UPDATE: I'm really enjoying this game solo, it pops into my head unbidden, like a good book or movie will. Raised the rating to a 9; may go up when I try my first 2+ player game.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
So I've tried all the decks solo against the first scenario and I can't help but notice how imbalanced they are this way.  It's still fun even when you lose, especially when it's the final questing action when you think you've won and you draw the one card that assures your defeat - the Ungoliant's Spawn!  What were the odds?!
So now, I want to try it with 2  players and see how the decks mingle.  More Gandalf cards please!
---
It's frustrating that the cap for copies of the same card included in a player's deck is 3, but the base game only includes 2 (and sometimes only 1!) copy of several cards.  The expansion packs don't have this problem, so why does the base set?  Seems a shame to have to buy 2 copies of the base game to get as much out of it as possible.
---
Conceptually I love this game, but practically, it's falling flat for me.  The appeal of this game for me is in the deck building.  However, there are a few things working against this enjoyment.  First off, there aren't enough cards to really build interesting decks unless you're willing to invest hundreds of dollars on 2 base sets and all the expansions whose costs really add up.  But the thing that actually bugs me is having to break down and rebuild for each adventure.  A deck that would excel hunting for Gollum would likely do miserably at the Carrock, but I want my well tuned deck to be able to handle any adventure, in its own way.  I think this box will start collecting dust...
---
A recent play has rekindled my interest in playing this one some more. I've realized that the solo experience for me isn't where this game shines. I much prefer this game as a 2 player co-op. Each player makes their own decisions when playing their hands and both contribute to the win/loss. Also, by ignoring the mini expansions I think I can get some more mileage out of this game. 
---
Also, the Solo playing 2 players variant is great fun, though a little busy on the table.
---
I finally get it. Deck building for individual quests is fun, and not even that time consuming if you know your cards. Watching your machine come to life is very satisfying (when it works) and I can't wait to get more expansions an more quests. Reading strategy forums really helped me understand the deck building process a lot better.

RATING: 3
Or: âHow to make a mess of a fine gameâ.

The system works well, and it could have been a great solo diversion (fun, fast, just the right amount of luck)â¦ if only they balanced it right!

As it is, the solo mode is so difficult to win (except for 1 of the 3 scenarios included) that it all boils down to pure luck: good play is never really rewarded, except by the occasional fluke. 

The 2-player mode is probably much easier, but it is simply unacceptable to market such a product as a 1-2 pl game without testing and/or balancing it properly.

Unless, or course, they wanted the poor player to come back to it again and again thinking: âIt must be a great game, since it is so hard to win!â, and made it hard on purpose âa cheap trick (which will also probably help selling the expansionsâ¦)

If the expansions correct this, I could give them a higher rating. 
But, as it is, this box deserves a low ratingâ¦

RATING: 5
Played this for the first time, and not really sure what to think.  The concept, artwork, and idea behind it is great.  The missions/quests/scenarios feel very true to the Middle Earth world, and it is immersive in that sense.

In the game I played (4-player), the other 3 players all had pre-established decks and them made one for me to use.  Setup took a little longer than I would've liked... I imagine deck-building might be a big part of the fun for this game; to see if you can pull out the right combinations of cards to defeat the challenge at hand.

The scenario and cards we drew were rather difficult (one of us lost all of his heroes, and I would have been out due to Threat points if I didn't have Aragorn to reset it), but even having said that, we defeated the mission with only 4 Hero casualties (and, of course, many allies) out of 12 total...

And they said that was possibly the hardest game they had played.  (I heard another gamer comment that it is nearly impossible to lose)

This is a big gripe I have with games like this, especially co-op ones... the problem is that they always seem either too easy or too difficult, and it tends to have very little to do with decisions you make or preparations you plan.

PS. It does seem like it could be one of the better options available if you are alone and looking to play something solitaire. But as a multi-player game... I felt like my decisions were very mechanical and methodical (ie. it never really seemed like I had any choice but to play the way I did), and the victory felt like it was a foregone conclusion, despite the difficulty and casualties.

RATING: 8
Yera. 

"LCG" (Living Card Game) que yo llamo mas bien EDG (Episodical Desperring Game). 

Un juego de cartas deckbuilder basado en una licencia para sacar mucho jugo, del cual salen expansiones sin tino (como con xwing y otros, ni me molesto en hacer lista de todas, necesitaria media BGG para ello, y paso. Yeray es completista. pongo "tiene todo, o esta en proceso de ello" e ya. 

La mayoria de LCGs son competitivos (1vs1, siguiendo la estela de lo que seria el magic y juegos similares), pero ESDLA LCG es cooperativo, lo que supone tres cambios importantes. 

1.- se puede jugar solo asi que es ideal para foreveraloners. tambien se puede jugar cooperativamente entre 2 e incluso entre 3 con alguna ligera modificacion. (asi es como he jugado yo dos de las 3 partidas que he jugado a esto). 

2.- al no ser competitivo, no hay "nerfs" ni "bluffs" que esten hechos ex profeso para que los jugadores tengan que seguir comprando expansiones para continuar siendo competitivos en el juego versus/torneo. 

3.- es mas susceptible de ser coleccionable que los LCG competitivos. 

el juego en si? pues es un deckbuilder bastante competente y agradable de jugar, con una muy cuidada ambientacion (aunque tiene el, emho, defectito, de que los personajes que juegas no son protagonistas de la trama, pero los que si lo son quedan bastante bien integrados en su participacion en el juego. 

Es un juego dificil (dependiendo del escenario, pero el ratio W:L raramente supera el 50-50 de victorias) pero mas agradable de jugar y no tan frustrante como otros deckbuilders, alguna que otra regla no es muy clara tal como viene escrita en la documentacion, pero despues de un par de partidas hay poco margen al discurso o queja en este apartado. 

En general es un excelente juego, pero en mi opinion es una ida de olla. el juego "completo" con todas sus expansiones, aventuras y leches, se va por encima de los 1000â¬. me da igual lo bueno que sea, lo completo que sea, lo variado que sea y lo que mole. ese dineral por un juego de cartas es una animalada, aunque traiga 100.000 cartas. 

Le recomiendo a todo el mundo probarlo. comprarlo ya es otra historia. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
After 20 plays solo:

Pre-game deck building can be REALLY fun. That's where the strategy is, as during gameplay there are few if any strategic decisions to be made. Lots of tactical ones, though, to mitigate the luck of the draw.

First major strike against this game is that some scenarios are just impossible to beat solo. They've got that video game feel where the player is just trying to beat the game and then it's done. Lame.

Make no mistake, this is a full blown CCG with a huge, and growing, library of cards and card combinations. The ONLY difference with LCG is that cards are not sold in random packs. As a collectible card game, there's an inherent weakness in the game design - new cards are REQUIRED to keep the game interesting. "minor" errata to existing cards are sometimes published to support the expanding universe and maintain balance in the face of power creep.

Very punishing, frustratingly low win rate even on easy mode sometimes. Very much a puzzle game in that you have to 'solve' the different scenarios by building up your deck. 

Beautiful art and story telling in Tolkien's universe is what LOTR: lcg rests entirely upon. Sadly, this is not enough to be worthy of a place on my shelf.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The idea: take the mechanics of magic the gathering, a few hints of other good ideas from dead collectible card games, and smash them together into a cooperative game.  Add a very popular license and release it in a cost effective way that doesn't send recovering magic addicts running for a seven step meeting.  This isn't FFG's first LCG, but it IS their first to incorporate compelling solitaire play and a cooperative element.  Considering the current popularity of cooperative games and the CCG player's constant desire to "playtest" decks, this is a pretty smart move!  

As for the mechanics of the game, The combination of CCG like combos, hand/resource management, and the cooperative aspects is unique and very good.  Sure a lot of it is ripped off from MTG, but thats a great game only hindered by complexity and time/money investment, things absent from this game.  

After playing a couple more times, you start to see where the game shines.  Despite having several things you must be able to do each turn (quest, defend, attack) there are countless ways you could get there both in choices and also in deck construction.  In my mind, this is the game's biggest strength- not only multiple strategies to win but also multiple ways to implement each strategy.

Rated ONLY as a standalone board game, I would give this 7/10.  You can sit down with the preconstructed decks and have a very fun time as an occasionally played boardgame.  The different decks and different scenarios provide plenty of replayability for a "board game" type of experience.

One complaint I have of LOTRLCG as a board game is that it scales horribly.  Single player is insanely difficult, four player far too easy.  2 seems to be the sweet spot and 3 isn't too bad.  Cards from later expansions really work to fix this, and do a great job of it.

As a CCG/lifestyle game, I think the jury is still out.  From a competitive standpoint, the cards in the base set are not well balanced at all.  There is enough variety that several tournament builds will probably arise, however based on my CCG experience, I think the core set alone will end up yielding maybe one or two monster decks.  Of course, the expansions will either balance this out or make it worse, depending on the foresight of the designer and the level of playtesting from FFG.

UPDATE:  The expansion packs have really brought out the beauty of this game.  The additional scenarios and villains have increased replayability immensely and there are so many different types of decks available now I don't even know what to build.  Just an incredible game and deserving of its high rating on boardgamegeek.  This is the "I hate CCG" guy's CCG, the "I can't afford Magic" guy's impulse buy.  A great game.

 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.9
I have everything up to and including Race Across Harad.

Fortunate to own the Aragorn, Gimli, and Legolas alt arts as well as the three Fellowship event playmats.

My opinion on why this game does not rate above "9" for me: As much as I love playing this game, the concept, and the innovation seen in the quests and player card mechanisms, I believe the game is still hampered by flaws in it's original design.  

The biggest flaw in my view is the lack of framework card draw.  Other LCGs preceding and of the period this was released had a 2-card draw each round, where LOTR only got 1 per round.  If the deck minimum had been set at 30 or so this might have made sense, but with 50 cards and a game lasting maybe 10 turns on the longer end only draws you 16 cards (Opening hand of 7 plus one draw each turn).  

While this makes Lore have amazing utility, it is crippling to games with 1 or 2 players, as the top priorities in deck building will have to be combat and questing (not necessarily in that order).  This is not taking into account "jank" or trick decks that exploit a card combo.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Second copy
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Players will customize their decks of cards beforehand and then use them to team up against the game in this co-op CCG. I've never seen this concept before, likely because it is a bit strange. CCG players tend to enjoy the process of deckbuilding and tweaking their decks before the game to beat their opponent. In most cases they must make a well-rounded deck that can handle various types of opposing decks they will face. With this game though, before each scenario, a player knows exactly what cards he/she will face. Customizing against an "opponent" who can't respond to your changes seems almost like cheating. At the very least, being good at the deckbuilding aspect makes the actual gameplay less challenging, which is an odd dynamic. A top-tier deck in a good CCG is one that is difficult to play properly, not just to build. 

All that aside, the game itself has a few good things going for it. As a co-op should, it strongly rewards discussion and planning among the players as a group. Because each player has his/her own hand of cards, sharing information and ideas is important. There is also a strong sense in combat of dividing up the enemies so that the more combat-oriented players can take the brunt of the fights. That part feels very thematic. Because the cards played require payment, it can also create some difficult choices about how to spend your various resources. However, there is relatively little hand management in this game.

As a Tolkien fan, I love the theme of the game. The artwork on the cards is excellent. Quality of components and graphic design are also top-notch. It is clear that the designers used the books as their source material, and the tone of the art and flavor text evokes LotR the book much more than LotR the movie. 

Ultimately, this game suffers from the same problem that many other co-ops do: randomness. A favorable draw from the game deck can result in weak monsters and a cakewalk of a quest. An unfavorable one can destroy you in a matter of turns. These are outliers, to be sure. Generally, a particular quest feels about the same difficulty level each time played. But the thrill of winning due to having created a killer deck before the game (or due to this inherent randomness in the game deck) seems cheap somehow. I am willing to play this, largely because I like the theme and the feel of the game. But I recognize that I have no interest in customizing a deck to beat an opponent that doesn't exist. And by not doing so, I am really missing out on where the real "game" happens: before the game even starts.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Deck building  game aimed at scenario play as opposed to vs play. Great all round but steep learning curve.

RATING: 6.5
LotR LCG ... an enigma of sorts. I've played it over 100 times solo, all with cards, and made a lovely progress sheet because I wanted to play it all - and got rather far in a rather short time:

https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1FXc6V-Mg5XzPV_UIz-5rRFdB29AyCr6D2_1psmhtIBE/edit?usp=sharing

...but then I got frustrated by some unfair quests and event chains. I should have heeded the advice of more experienced players and should have played two-handed, with two sets of heroes, from rather early on. That opens up some strategies, too, when they help each other out, and actually enables some cards. And it makes it less horrible when a chain of event straight away takes out a hero after a turn or two.

It tempts me to play again. But I'd need to get into everything again, too, the rules and the cards and the strategies and everything. It's not like I have too few other solo games that I really want to play, too. So it sits unplayed for now. Even though it really is a lovely game, and an engrossing one - a play a couple could easily play for a really long time without getting bored.

RATING: 10
This is an enjoyable game that my son and I enjoy playing together.  The rules are not overly complex, so it is somewhat easy to get started.  Like the rules, the game itself is not really that complex, which is nice if you are looking for a little bit lighter game.  Those who like more involved and complex games will probably not be as interested in this one.

It is really a two player Co-op game (although, you can play solo, too).  The game comes with 4 different hero factions -- each with their own strengths and weaknesses.  It also comes with 3 quests (scenarios) -- although one of the scenarios is extremely difficult to win.  These scenarios determine which enemies and challenges will be included in the encounter (enemy) deck.

There is some variety in the base game, but really, we found that we needed an expansion deck after only a few plays.  This is my first exposure to a game like this, so I discovered that this is the way these deck building games work.  Nevertheless, I found this fact to be a little disappointing, as I am used to base games to go much longer before the need for an expansion.

Essentially, if you like lighter two player co-ops (perhaps light to medium), and you are okay investing in future decks, this is a game that you will probably enjoy.

UPDATE:  Upped the rating to a 10.  This has been the game my son and I have played the most for the last couple of years.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
Deck building is fun and the mechanics overall interesting. 

Surge events on encounter cards are the stupidest thing in this game. They turn the game from 'I lost because I played poorly' to 'I lost because I drew crappy encounter cards that added even more encounter cards that added even more...'. Luck is NOT the way to add primary difficulty to games in the modern day.

Luckily, some scenarios come with less surge event cards, and those are relatively fun going, and while the luck factor is still there, at least you keep drawing a steady number of cards.

RATING: 5
Good solo play, but works much better and is more interesting as a cooperative (we tried 2-player). Trying the first scenario for a few sessions to iron-out the rules and see what kind of problems we encounter.  

The second scenario is a blast.  The game is difficult, but it is part of the fun.  You are constantly trying to tweak your decks to defeat the scenario.  Each game plays out slightly different due to randomness of the encounter deck, which is very good thing.  There is tension and tough decisions to be made almost throughout the entire game.  Each turn, you wish you had more resources, more characters, more will/attack/defense.  So many things to do and not enough time to do them all.  The threat mechanic is great and forces you to really push forward. 

I bought all the expansions currently available after a few games with the core set.  Great replayability and theme.

---

Rating based on Core game plus the first six saga boxes, plus the first five cycles. 

The Core set only is perhaps a solid 7. Core + Shadows of Mirkwood is an 8. Core + SoM + Dwarrowdelf = 9. Or something like that.

---

A very addictive solo/coop deckbuilder that has grown on me. The one caveat is that because of the relatively large role chance can play in a single game, it's a little bit like doing research -- you have to do an experiment (a player deck/heroes/adventure configuration) several times to get a good feel for what works and what doesn't. 

On the question of chance, you have Treachery card effects and Shadow effects that can be quite dramatic and reduce your chance of winning significantly in a single draw. Configurations of the Encounter deck that result in an unmanageable flood of enemies are also possible. On the other hand, most cards are not Treachery cards and don't have Shadow effects, so the outcomes vary between the very good and very bad, with fewer in-betweens. The result is that a single play session is not guaranteed to be very rewarding.

This swinginess is definitely more the case the fewer cards you have to choose from for your player deck. Once you've gotten some expansions and have a larger card pool to choose from, you'll find ways of managing this high uncertainty of outcomes. Indeed, this is one thing that gives the game depth and makes it fun -- the cards allow you to change the playing experience dramatically. The different spheres play differently and allow different strategies for achieving victory. Even then, the beginning of the game can be very important. Someone on the forums had said that whether you win or lose can depend in large part on the first 5 or so cards in the encounter deck, and I think that is largely true.

LotR LCG is also more a strategic game than a tactical one. It makes more of a difference how you construct your deck than how you actually play it, and this also means that you have to spend time "metagaming" and experimenting with different combinations of cards. Granted, the tactical element is there, and there are many meaningful decisions to be made during play. In this regard, the game is much better than Dominion, for example, where there is almost no thought involved in playing your hand. The metagaming component can be viewed as both a positive and a negative feature of the game, since it gives it longevity, but requires persistence and many plays, and usually you have to do some work before jumping into a quest.

The gameplay isn't as deep and rewarding as some other recent coops such as Mage Knight, but then again, a session of LotR LCG is several times shorter and you have the metagaming aspect. I also think the designers could better use the opportunities for narrative that the mechanics of the game and the distribution model allow.

These gripes aside, this is a very solid game, whether you are a fan of the LotR setting or not (I wouldn't call myself a fan, but I appreciate the richness of the world and some of the themes). I keep returning to the game and thinking about it, so my rating has grown with time from a measly starting 7.

Definitely more fun with a larger card pool to choose from and more adventures.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
