=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
The Lord of the Rings: LCG, what can I say? Aside from War of the Ring, this game does a pretty good job of grabbing you in its theme & lore and making you feel like you're going on unique adventures with tons of varied heroes at your disposal and tough challenges and frightening enemies to tackle. That is of course if you're willing to shell out some good amount of cash for the game. One Core set is sadly not enough to really get into the meat this game has to offer, which is customizing and building your unique deck to face the dangers the game throws at you. The game can be quite punishing with what's included in one box.

This game's difficulty is not "unforgiving" per se. It is actually very tolerable to a point. But sometimes it can become unnecessarily hard. I have been able to beat many of the scenarios, but the literally speed ramp up in difficulty from one scenario to the next can be unforgiving and God-awfully swing-y at times. Some Enemies can utterly destroy one or more of your heroes if you're not careful and your threat meter escalates at an alarming rate. Not to mention enemies attack first and may get bonus annoying effects. But in the grand scope of things, being able to overcome this obstacles and beating a scenario feels like a great accomplishment. Not to mention you got through the game with a deck you created. Gives you a great feeling. On the flip side, if you get destroyed, you may want to tweak or total re-do your deck which can also be quite the fun endeavor, patching up the weaknesses you noticed while playing.

I've played both solo, two and three player. It works really good with either, but best at two. Some scenarios are literal "hell on earth" in solo while sometimes, a three player game will feel like a cakewalk. Hence why two is the best player count for this game

My main gripe with this game, and my gripe with any LCG type game is the game is addicting and you're pretty much going to pay if you want to improve your decks beyond what 2 or even 3 core sets can offer. 2 Core sets, 1 Deluxe expansion and all its cycle packs will run you about $180(less with deals, buying online etc.) You'll get a lot of play and customize options, as well as some unique quests that feel different than each. There are big box sets per LOTR movie (So that's 8, including The Hobbit) and then the Saga big box expansions, each of which has 6 cycle deck each. Granted you can buy and expand at your own pace. There is no point going full throttle, because scenarios are easily replay-able and you can slowly acquire expansions that suit your needs. Each expansion adds a unique new keyword, mechanic etc. If you like it, buy it and it's cycle decks, if not simply skip and move to the next. Also one of the best ways to help with costs, is find a friend or two, teach them the game, and if they really like it they can help with expanding the game with you to take away some of the costs. And of course like any LCG, there is no collectability aspect to the game, so you want need to spend about 60 dollars on a playset of one card, but 60 dollars to get a good pile of cards enough to make 2, maybe 3 decks :)

Overall the game is fun, even more so if you got a person or two to enjoy it with. I
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 3

The hero mechanic isn't my favorite, but I've felt the same about my limited exposure to games like Marvel Vs. and the WoW CCG. With my limited experience, it seems like it will be really hard to make a usable multi-sphere deck out of just one core set. We'll see how the expansions and more experience change that.

I'm really hoping to up my rating on this one with a few more plays. If I can get my wife into it, that will probably bump the rating up a bit too. It did seem like it would be better with at least 2 players.

-- 7-10-2011 --

After some deck customization, a couple games with my wife, and one solo attempt at the second scenario, I've dropped my rating from 6 to 4. This game is just... no. It's so horribly dry that I don't feel the theme at all. Maybe (big maybe) a few more plays would let the mechanics flow more easily, allowing the theme to shine through, but I have to force myself to play trying to get to that point. It's just not even the tiniest shred of fun for me. Le sad.

RATING: 8
This game is HARD! But allows for a lot more stategy - the random element is with the cards you draw into your hand, so allows a lot more tactical manipulation than I found with Arkham Horror LCG, where the output randomiser was too unforgiving (to my mind). If I lose in this game, most of the time I have felt it is because I have made a bad decision somewhere, rather than just because of bad luck.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
There's very likely fun to be had in this game, but I wasn't able to find it readily. The components are beautiful, and the rendering of theme is excellent--but I just couldn't get the flow of the game, and taking turns just seemed like a chore. I had no particular investment in the adventure, and the drama escaped me. 

Some caveats--I like the concept of deckbuilding, but most often get bored when it comes time to the actual mechanics. Also, I got this as a solo game, and only played it as such. There may well be more to it when playing with other people. 

I may give this a go again some time in the future--but for now, happy to let this one go.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Have had fun with the first few learning games.  In subsequent games we have attempted deck-building against the second scenario, and had a very hard time, becoming frustrated.  Looks like, with only one base set, we shouldn't attempt to build full 50 card tournament decks, but keep them smaller.

Deckbuilding has improved by not following the 50card deck rule - we have 40-43 cards in the deck.  Finally got our first win on Journey Down the Anduin - very happy about that!

Having a resurgence of interest after playing with Russell & Ray.  Doing custom deckbuilding with Tina.  Really enjoying it again!

Received two additional core sets in July 2012 "Priorities" math trade.

Getting a few steady plays in with Tina, and doing a bit of soloing.

I've got some mixed feelings about this one currently.  I really love it, but it's not such a great fit for the amount of time and frequency that Tina and I currently have to game.  It's very rewarding to modify a deck until it is successful against a specific quest.  However, in most instances we don't have time to play a quest multiple times, so often we end after getting beat up by a quest, and have to try and remember how we should modify the deck at a later date.  Games that are more rewarding for once-in-a-while play, like Pandemic, may be a better fit for our evening gaming, even if I technically like Lord of the Rings LCG better.

Playing once in a while by planning ahead and having our decks ready, and it's going well.  I just designed a pair of dwarf decks that we will start from the beginning and work through the quests with.

Current style of playing in summer 2013: pick a quest, then design a deck specifically for the quest.  Since each quest is so different, it can be frustrating to just build a deck and throw it against any quest, even though that's initially how we hoped to play.

Fall 2013, started the Hobbit Saga quests with Dwarf decks.  Thematic to the max.

Nov. 13, 2013 - first hobbit box completed.  Fun quests.  More deck adjustments required between quests than we might like, but it's rewarding to defeat a quest after first losing.

Mar. 21, 2016 - Just sold the collection via LotR:LCG subreddit.  Enjoyed our time with the game, but it just was never getting to the table any longer.  Probably don't need to get sucked down the rabbit hole of buying LCG's ever again, as my collection has thousands of plays available just in standard games, without "subscribing" to games for which expansions are necessary.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I played this game some time ago and I have a kind of mixed emotions about it. I do think that the game has some very good points, like the idea of being involved in a mission and having different way of wining, the artwork is amazing, but it just doesn't feel like a fun game. The rating that I give to this game is more related to how I approach games in general that maybe with this game itself. From my experience, and taking into account how difficult this game is, in order to have success in this game, you need to prepare the deck very carefully, you need to have under control every aspect of the mission that you are playing and then the cards that you draw, and the enemies cards, need to be balanced for the players. Many times you have the feeling that the mission have been prepared that difficult to be played in a tournament or something like that, where the players need to replay the mission many times until having the perfect deck and knowing how to be successful. I think that there will be plenty of players interested in that kind of approach, which is fine, I do not have any problem, but my way of playing board games is just playing a game and trying to win with what I have around or defeating my friends or whatever, but not doing a study and many deck configurations and trying over and over and over again until being in a position where wining is possible.
I have played the game with generic decks, balanced, but not particularly prepared for a certain mission, and it all depends on what cards do you draw as starting hand. And then there are some missions absolutely independent on that. You are going to lose no matter what
Positive:
1. The game concept is very good
2. Artwork
3. Many missions available
Negative:
1. You have to do a study and a deck preparation before every mission if you want to have success
2. Not fun to play when you now that you are going to lose no matter what

------- Preplay thoughts

Crap another LOTR game, they have to stop damn it! Please please please let them get this one right...

Edit - Hmm it sounds pretty good overall, likely a 7.5 or 8 for me from all the info I have. It mostly all sounds good, seems to have decisions to make more so than some others you could compare, luck is the sticky point but with this kind of system I'm not sure how you could ever lower it. I'm not crazy about the co-op format either like many however I already own a great 1vs1 LOTR card game in ME:CCG so do I really need another?  Probably not so in a way this is kind of good and maybe it can be easily adapted for 1vs1 as well. I do already own a good LOTR co-op game though, which with exp can be played 1vs1, heh, some overlap dang I just can't resist a decent game with this theme...

I [i]never[/i] play solo games ever but might be tempted with this one, largely due to my love of the theme of course.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Love the game, although the time it takes to construct decks properly and tweak them to complete different quests keeps it from being a 10. I do enjoy that I can design and build decks here and there when I don't have time to actually sit and play a game, but I am also often daunted by the prospect of resorting the cards and building new decks in order to move on to another quest.

The gameplay itself it tight, thematic, challenging, and exciting. The risk/reward element of the game is fantastically balanced and only dampened by the fact that for many quests you HAVE to know the makeup of the encounter deck in order to properly weigh the risk of certain plays. For example, on one quest I took three heroes that all had 2 hit points and the quest had a card that dealt two damage to each exhausted character. Since I had just quested with each hero, they all died in one go on turn 2. It was a little disheartening to deconstruct the deck I had made and was excited to try just to attempt the quest I was on (I was trying to play the quests in order at that point). It's a fun challenge to check out a quest deck and parse out what sort of deck you need to build to defeat and then see how successful you were at deciphering the needs of the quest, but it can also be a big deterrent to actually sitting down and playing.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
This game does alot of things right, but it can be very irritating to loose to bad card draw from your own deck and/or the encounter deck, which unfortunately despite how much I like the rest of the game, this kind of kills the it for me.

Also requires a lot of deckbuilding/tweaking in between each scenario, so much that as much time is spent tweaking decks as is spent playing (this is good for some, bad for others).

I feel bad rating it so low, since at first I had a lot of fun with the game, but it's just too frustrating to play, and there are other better games out there now that while they don't have the extensive deckbuilding of this game, they are much more fun to play (Mage Knight, Warhammer Quest: ACG).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is my most-played cooperative game thus far.  I liked playing it with incremental card gains, acting like I didn't own any newer sets (even though I bought them all up front).  I also play it solo now and then, but I prefer having a partner.  Sadly, my wife isn't into the TCG/LCG kind of game and my TCG partner hasn't been around much anymore, so this is stuck on my shelf for now.

My one major complaint about the game, at least back when I bought it (maybe they changed it?), is that the base set didn't have three of every card!  Their ploy worked on me (I bought 3 of the base set) but man it still makes me mad thinking about it even to this day.

2017-12-28: Played again this Christmas.  Man, I think I will always love this game, rating up from 9 to 10.

RATING: 9
I hesitated to buy this as the previous LCG I bought, Warhammer Invasion, really doesn't get much play and I wasn't too happy about cherry-picking expansion decks to get better cards. However, I'm really glad I came off the fence for this one, hooked really by the theme. With it being a coop, it doesn't feel like you need the 'best' cards, you can have fun exploring how cards from the different player and encounter decks come together. And the scope for this is huge.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I think the LCG concept for a coop/solo game is genius, truly. The gameplay is also engaging, addictive and not too complicated. One thing that I think is a little off in this game is the balance with each number of players. It definitely becomes easier the greatest number of players you have.

I also have a tinge of regret that FFG did not choose another theme for this game. Don't mistake me, I absolutely love everything LOTR, but I already have many games with this theme and there are so many other cool themes left unexplored in games!

Anyway, I'm hooked and look forward to the expansion packs!

***UPDATE***
I feel the game is getting old playing with the same few decks and does not have the staying power of most coops, so I'm lowering my rating from 9 to 8. However, this is likely due to the slow release of the adventure packs.

When I heard about the release of the Star Wars LCG, my dedication to this game was shaken. I'll really have to play both before deciding which one to I will truly invest in.

***UPDATE***
The game seems strangely empty and hasn't been able to hold my interest. Sad. Down to 6.

Lord of the Rings is fantastic for exploring with a second person as the deck tinkering is discussed between both players because of the cooperative nature of the game.

The quest mechanics are thematic. The four different player factions have their focus which allows very fun deck interactions. And if the players conspire, powerful decks can be made to complement each other. Fantastic!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Great game.  I've played solo and multi-player up to 4 players, all with one Core set.  It plays fine, though 4-players through the second scenario was very doable both times we played it.

I'm not a Magic player and I've never played more than a handful of any other CCG/LCG, so I was unsure of whether or not I would like this.  I love it, and I've played it 14 times in the last 2.5 weeks, so that's saying a lot.

I like the game system and the game play.  There are interesting, non-trivial decisions to make almost every turn, and nothing is guaranteed in this game (the last time I played we lost ~8 allies and 2 heroes in a 4P game just while setting up the last stage of the second scenario).  I really like the way the spheres work together.

I've not done any deck-building yet, and I don't know that I'll be doing that much of it in the long haul.  I' simply enjoying the game as it is.

There are only 2 criticisms I can make against the game:

1. Nothing in the game evokes Middle Earth or the Lord of the Rings for me.  Yes, there are cards named Aragorn and Gimli and what not, but it just doesn't do it for me.  This could just as easily have been a Zombie-pocalypse game.  But I'm a hard-core Tolkien fan-boy, so I knew going in that it had little chance of holding up for me in this regard.

2. With a game like this one, careful wording of the cards is a must.  Terminology should be chosen and adhered to diligently, and I just don't feel they did that here.  This is especially disappointing considering how many LCGs they have in flight at the moment; you'd think they'd have figured it out by now.

Overall, it's a great game.  Go watch the video tutorials and if it looks at all interesting, go grab a copy!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I liked this.  Reminded me of a much richer Death Angel.  I will most likely be picking this up.

RATING: 7.5
I am a huge LotR fan.  Huge.

The fact that I just could not get around the mathy, weakly-themed mechanics of this deck-builder is a personal tragedy for me.  I wanted to like it so badly.  I purchased multiple expansions to see if that would help, but ultimately, I could not get past the feeling of being bored while playing it.  I am certain that someone will enjoy it more than I will.  :(

I've sleeved all the hero cards in FFG premium limited ed. LotR art card sleeves (The same One Ring design that is on the backs of them).  

Update (10/16):  After a few years of gaming under my belt, I am determined to give this another go, and perhaps a more fair shake with regards to my expectations of it.  

I have purchased the core set and a bunch of the Saga exps., which (after some research) I understand to be more fun and thematic,. and which don't require as much of the fiddling with your deck that the other expansion cycles do.  

Still, my hope is that making it fun for me and learning the game better before introducing the tougher scenarios and deck building elements will foment a greater appreciation for this entire game.

RATING: 8
Fantastic, and dripping in theme. A warning however: You need to deck build, and expect to lose a lot. The goal is to deck build, tweak your deck between plays, and enjoy the metagame all to get your best deck design and best gameplay methods out there to face the quest...which you still will probably lose. This is a game where you can do everything right and still will lose more often than not. The idea is to make sure you do everything right so you can take advantage of those times lady luck will make it *possible* for you to win.

RATING: 4

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The game mechanics are solid and engaging. I'm not a huge LOTR fan but I did enjoy the movies. I enjoy the theme and I think it works well enough with the mechanics. Die hard fans who care about details will probably be annoyed at some of the thematic stuff, but I don't care that much. The art and general atmosphere are appealing to me.

The game flows well and there are lots of hard decisions to make. Characters must be tapped in three separate phases and generally can only participate in one, being unavailable until the next round when untapped. They can advance the scenario which is the real objective, they can be used to defend against enemies, or they can be used to attack. Note they can not defend and attack. Figuring out which characters will do what each round is the bulk of the decision making. On top of that you have a hand of cards some of which you can play in a given turn using resources collected each round by your heroes. Managing your hand and the special abilities of the cards you have in play round out decision space.

The game is hard! At least there exist many scenarios with varying difficulty levels. Some decks might be more-or-less suited to a particular scenario. Co-op games need to be hard, otherwise they're no fun. You should never have an easy time of things and it seems that the win-to-loss ratio in the game favors the loss side which is good.

The final element that I haven't explored too much yet, but that I'm very excited about is deck construction. I haven't put decks together since MTG! I never felt the need to do it in Blue Moon, but this game is screaming for custom decks. I think playing solo makes the need for deck building even stronger so I'm really looking forward to exploring options.

The game certainly has luck which seems to be the main complaint of detractors. I don't think that argument makes a lot of sense though. Co-op games with an automated response need to rely on random elements if they want to keep information hidden from the players. Pandemic has this same "problem" but I don't think people complain about it as much in that case. A card game with a shuffled deck will also have this issue to varying degrees. Since this game has deck construction bad card draws can at least be influenced directly by the player.


Note:
Bought this at Gottacon 2012. $28 in silent auction.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I'm still trying to find out how I like this one. I've heard people say they like it solo, but the game forces you to build your deck to play alone or play two hands from the start. I think that two hands are an awful lot to manage (I'm still not into the game enough to break up the heroes from their core decks and build a deck for solo play). I like the flavor text from the actual novels on the cards. The mechanics work well, and the art is great. I just have a hard time playing it solo, and that's the reason I got the game. It's a really advanced game, and I wish I'd known what I was getting into before I bought the game. I wish they had like a stepping stone game or set up (kind of like Seasons has you start with the same cards before you start playing games with drafting; I'm sure there's stuff online, but I'm worried I'll find out so much that it ruins the game for me, like relying too much on a walkthrough to beat a video game). I feel like this game is overwhelming and can feel fiddly. But it also somehow feels less like fan fiction (Eldritch Horror) and more like one of the lost tales that Tolkien left unpublished. Kudos for that, and it's the reason for the high rating despite the flaws.

Update after 6 months with the game:  I'm hooked. It's my personal favorite game. I've cracked into the preconstructed deck building world, but it's because I'm excited to see where the game will take me. Feels like the books in all the right ways. I'm so happy for the LCg model. It's like an hbo series in a way.

Update again: great game, but I seem to end up net-decking, which defeats the whole purpose of deck construction. What do I play this for after all? It's a great game but I'm not so sure where I stand with it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Took a while to buy this game but finally got it for my birthday. Wasn't sure if I'd like it or not. However, I love it! It's quite hard to start with but you get used to what you need to do with your heroes very quickly.
Given that I've posted a session report (and I've never done that before), I'm really enjoying this game. Great to sit down with at the table when the family is watching TV or such and play out a scenario or two.
The scenarios are what keep it interesting. With only 3 in the box and 1 each expansion it needs lots more scenarios. Otherwise, I'd rate this a 10.
3 Jan 13 - Not getting it out much these days but still like it.
Nov 16 - Have rediscovered this game. Getting into deck building and tuning with two spheres. Fun. Go to Beorn's Path for help on deck building. Still need new scenarios though. It is text heavy to read and fiddly. So don't know how long I'll keep going with it but enjoying again so far.

RATING: 9
One of my favorite games that I own. I love building decks and running through the many quests that this game has to offer. It works perfectly with the Lord of the Rings theme of having a small group of heroes traveling around middle earth and running into all kinds of enemies and misfortune. Also, the solo/coop nature of the game is great for me if my wife isn't in the mood for board games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A great cooperative concept with a good amount of depth and strategy. Out of the box, it struggles in the area of card distribution (with 1 or 2 copies of some of the best cards, encouraging you to buy a second core set which comes with a lot of waste). Scenarios range from casual fun to extreme difficulty, meaning my casually playing family does not enjoy the full range of the game together. The potential for a great game is there and will hopefully get flushed out with the expansions.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Best Tolkien game for now.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
For being a card game I would hard pressed to describe just how great of a job TLotR: TCG does immersing you into the world of middle earth. A great game solo but best with two, the depth of customization and story telling in second to none. The primary drawback being that amassing a decent collection takes some serious $. 

I love trying out new hero combinations and tackling new and old quests alike. I recommend solo be played two handed (not ever a problem for me with any game) as the interaction between players really makes the game shine. More often than not I am playing this with my wife or with my good friend who also has an excellent collection.

RATING: 8
Having played a few of FFG's LCGs these (including AGoT:LCG, Warhammer Invasion and Death Angel), I feel that this is, by far, the best of the Living Card Games. This game achieves what Death Angel could not, an interesting streamlined set of rules for co-op gaming.

I especially like the fact that the decks are so easy to customize and tweak.

RATING: 6
This game hates me and so far I hate it.  I realize I have few plays, but those plays its been an awful, frustrating, annoying experience. I certainly dont mind losing a game - see Space Hulk Death Angel/D-Day at Omaha Beach when I can see some light at the end of the tunnel.  This just kicks your ass then pisses on your face just for the fun of it.  It literally hates the player.  

I bought this for solo play, maybe coop is better, I dont know and Im running out of patience to find out.  

I would venture to guess this game is better than being punched in the sack with brass knuckles, but its about as much fun.

EDIT 04/26/11 - played with a different pre-set deck and had a much better experience.  Re-rated to a 6, and will continue re-rating as I play more.  Going to play the rest of the pre made decks, then construct my own.

EDIT 04/29/11 - Starting to like this game, starting to see and understand how it works.  Beat the first quest with Spirit deck this evening with a final score of 31.  Looking forward to trying other decks and building my own.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
I bought this game so I would have something to legitimately play single player.  Based off of some BGG lists I came across it was ranked very high for single player play throughs.  I enjoyed the first play through and got wrecked by the game.  This is something I actually enjoy because most games just aren't that difficult.  My problem became only being able to win based on luck, or if you invested more money into the game.  If I am going to love a game, you need to be able to beat it consistently with skillful play with some randomness.  Not get beat by card draw, in a single player game.  The theme is fantastic.  **Small Spoiler** The first mission is literally walking down a road, which I thought was fantastic and very faithful to the theme of the game.  I love the deck building mechanics and how they all can work together, but I don't like needing to buy 4 base sets of the game to have the "best" starting deck.  This may be the first game that I give up.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
Played this one quite a bit now and I have to say that I do enjoy it.  It plays well as a 2 player game and is interesting solo.  

It's biggest problems are it's player scaling (gets much easier the more people playing), and the fact that it is an LCG.  Not as annoying as a CCG model to be sure, but still danged irritating in many ways and nothing more than a huge money sink (like the fact that you need multiple core sets to really have any "deckbuilding" options :gulp: )

(*Update* My interest in this is starting to slip and I'm considering selling it.  It seems as though without large numbers of expansions the game will rapidly grow stale, and it suffers from the same problem as all CCG or LCGs, namely you have to find people who are "into it" in order to really play.)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Love how the scenarios are tied into the movie. As a pretty big fan of the LOTR movies, it's always fun fighting for Middle Earth and fending off orcs and spiders while keeping the fellowship alive and moving forward. Replay value is high since there are endless possibilities with aspects such as deck building, expansions, saga expansions, etc. It's also not a steep price to pick up one or two expansions to extend the game for another 3+ rounds of fun. 

This game has a relatively steep learning curve to begin with, but with tutorial videos it's a whole lot of fun battling alongside heroes and hobbits to defeat Sauron.

RATING: 9
This is a great cooperative game- you really feel like you and your buddies are part of the Fellowship on a quest. A must buy for any LotR fanboys/fangirls out there. Would be a perfect 10 if not for the fact that you need to buy 2-3 of the boxed expansions, 10+ Adventure Packs and 2x extra Gandalf cards to get the most out of the base game and add some much needed replay value. Steep learning curve is offset by really good youtube tutorials. 

Edited up to 9 because the "Against the Shadow" cycle calls for new decks and new strategies that makes the game much more entertaining.

RATING: 6
Again, I just don't get the popularity of cooperative games, hence the average rating. This one is good, overall, and both the characters and the structure of the quests are very well done. There is actually enough going on here that you have to make some decisions how you will combat your enemies, keeping in mind how far you are away from your goal. The graphic design is good, but the game is a little too "brown." The gameplay is fairly quick, with little room for analysis paralysis. My only complaint is that ultimately you are only competing against a stack of cards, so that seriously reduces my enjoyment of the game.

RATING: 7.2
Fantastic deck building game. Great game to play with friends, especially if one does not have a desire to play competitively against friends and would rather play together in a competitive environment against a common goal. The Living Card Game format fits this style of game perfectly as each month new quests and cards will come out to build encounter decks and fellowship decks. Playing alone makes the game more difficult and often times frustrating. The quests were obviously made to be tackled as a group although the first two are beatable alone. The deck building will only get better with time as more expansions are released and I look forward to playing it in the future. Great game and definitely worth the purchase.

RATING: 7
This is a fun game that I usually play solo.  It is more fun with 2 or more people because of some of the card interactions, but you could also play for 2 people solo.  It can be very difficult, but the challenge is what keeps you coming back for more.  The supplied starter decks aren't great by themselves but by mixing them, I have been successful with the first 2 scenarios.  The third scenario is very difficult.  Play for me is usually between 45-120 minutes, I take my time. I also enjoy the deck building aspect of the game.  For those not interested in this, there are plenty of suggestions for good decks for particular scenarios online.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Have only played solo thus far but bought it mostly for solo play any ways.

I made a bunch of mistakes for the first few play throughs but by the 4th or 5th time I started to get the hang of it.  Means it may take some re-learning if it goes on the shelf for a while.

Turned out to be pretty fun.  It's the first collectible card game where I've actually wanted to try out some deck building.  The starter set seems to have a lot of replay value compared to most starter sets for collectible/living card games.

In order to combat "bossy" players, common in co-op games, players aren't supposed share which cards they have.  It's an interesting mechanic that I think could work well.

The game's starting to grow on me.  Ranking it at a 7 right now because I can't fully judge how good the replay value is but if it sticks with me for a bit longer it's going to have to be adjusted to an 8 or 9.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 4.5
[2014.Jul.03] Still consider this more of an activity than a game. (Rating unchanged.)

[2013.May.21] Like many other Fantasy Flight Games productions, The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game is gorgeously produced. Unfortunately, it is not an Eric Lang game and it shows. There are too many random elements in this cooperative game that prevent any real control or strategy on the part of the players. Simply put, game turns consist of doing the best that you can with the cards that you happen to have your hand at that moment. In my opinion, it is more of an activity that you participate in, than an actual game that you play. Could have, should have, would have, but in the end didn't.

:star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar:

RATING: 6
LIKE:

* I'm a big fan of the LOTR universe/theme.
* Tokens were appropriate and good sized.
* Instructions seemed quite clear for the most part.
* While the play is cooperative, there is limited ability for one person to play the game for everyone as the cards in hand are secret.  Still susceptible to one person taking control to some degree of played characters.
* Lots of randomizing effects for which you must be prepared.

DISLIKE:

* Text is small and sometimes quite crowded.  
* Still mixed feelings after one play.  I'm not interested enough in the game to buy it right now but I'm happy to play copies belonging to other people.
* Starter set should come ready to play with four but only comes truly ready to play with two.  I know FFG needs to make their money, but this feels like outright milking of a popular theme and I'm hesitant to buy into this.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
The game art is beautiful and immersion in the theme of Lord of the Rings is great. Just found it a bit hard to play solo with the base deck. The ideal is to build customized decks of two spheres to make it more dynamic and interesting game!

RATING: 8
This is my first encounter with this kind of deck building game. I have played Dominion, but I think it doesn't compare to this.

I was initially put off by this game. I didn't seem to like playing with cards solely and the game seemed somewhat confusing to me. I shelved it for a couple of months. After reading a lot of amazing reviews on the game I wanted to give it a second chance.

Then it clicked. I like this game! I've only played the first scenario for like six times now, 4 with leadership mono sphere and 2 with tactics mono sphere. They are completely different, and I think that makes this game beautiful!

The art is also brilliant as are the card synergies and the different enemies you encounter. You are on your toes constantly.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
My quandary with LotR is my quandary with *all* self-designed Fantasy Flight games: an overemphasis on graphics design versus playtesting. For all their fetishization of visual aesthetics, most self-designed Fantasy Flight games fail to deliver elegant mechanics, unambiguous text, and balanced asymmetry. In these respects, I consider LotR perhaps their most startling failure. The artwork is undeniably inspired; the mechanics, text, and balance is undeniably insipid. I strongly dissuade all but the most stalwart of Tolkein aficionados from this decidedly disappointing (and costly!) investment.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
Probably much better with expansions, but as a standalone the first scenario is too easy and the other 2 scenarios' difficulty varies extremely depending if you get lucky for e.g. which of your 3 heroes gets taken prisoner in the 3rd scenario, while not having a lot of variety or customization options. While some people will probably disagree with me and say the LOTR card game system was never supposed to be base-game only, I feel like it still should be more complete as a standalone, even if only to draw people to buy more expansions.

EDIT: Agh I have no idea what to rate this game, having now traded it I keep wishing I could play it but remember the gameplay was often not as fun as the expectation. I really like the concept of it with the scenarios, customization options, and how they integrated staging area with questing/combat but 1. even after reading through the forums there appears to be quite a lot of junk cards in the base set 2. there is a huge amount of luck in this game. While some of it can be mitigated and I like some other games that have huge luck swings (e.g. Samurai Spirit), that there are many more unique cards and that the decks change from encounter to encounter makes it really hard to metagame without a huge investment, and there are some e.g. which hero gets captured in the 3rd scenario that you can't really do much to prevent the damage 3. I still remember it as being rather fiddly, and 4. lack of options without expansions. Maybe if someone ported the game system and reworked it a bit it could become a game I highly regarded.

Best With: 1

RATING: 6
Rating is given for the game as a solo game as described in the rules.  I feel that with the card selection that comes with one box, that the solo game is too hard and not very enjoyable.  Unfortunately, FFGs went for marketing rather than good game with the core set.  What I mean by that, the card distribution encourages a player to buy more than one set(or expansions) if they want to be able to win with solo.  I would have rather had them offer a good playing experience from the core set and beyond.

Now as for co-op or playing 2-handed solo....this has been very enjoyable, and I think will be the only way I will play it in the future.....or until I have tried a couple more expansions.  This I would rate more around the 8 range.

At this point I don't think a person could build one deck from 1 copy of the base game and have this one deck beat all three of the quest that come in the base game (playing them singly).  Which is very disappointing to me....but I guess good marketing.  I think it would be possible to customize a deck that is specialized to beat one of the quest, but this is too much fiddling for me.  I will build custom decks at some point, but I would like them to be able to work on different quest.

I'm still curious about this one.  I'm a little leery of the "living card game" concept....monthly updates.....sounds like that can get expensive.  I bought the basic set, and hope to buy a couple updates to see how the series goes.

RATING: 8.5
Definitely a good game. Mechanics are nice and make sense, and trying to beat all those challenging scenarios is a fun experience. I already own a few small expansions and it seems that scenarios are varied and interesting. What's even better, the game fills the deckbuilding void that I had, as I seemed to either not like the LCGs/CCGs that my gaming group plays, or the other way around, so being able to make and tweak different types of decks, and then actually play them whenever I want is what I needed. It does seem that some scenarios don't scale that well for one player, but then again it only makes them more challenging to win solo, which I don't mind at all. RATING: 9
My goto for when I'm solo and need to play something.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Currently my favorite game of all time.  It has much of what I like most in games: resource management, deck construction, a great theme, co-op play, painful choices, incredible artwork, immense amounts of replayability, the ability to teach it as you play, and expandability without breaking the bank.  Also, every time I lose a scenario I want to play it again.  Heck, even when I win a scenario I want to modify my deck to see if I can do even better.  

I know that some people wish this would have been a PvP game instead of cooperative.  I agree it would have been great that way too.  However, as a person with a very limited budget, I really appreciate that it is cooperative.  I have played and enjoyed more than one CCG that I initially loved, but within a couple years become bored with the game.  This is mainly due to the fact that I can't remain competitive against opponents who are able to drop a couple hundred dollars every few months into another booster box that will give them cards which easily trump most things in my deck.  The cooperative nature of The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game eliminates this CCG "problem" for people with limited funds.     

Because of all this, and more, I can't imagine it ever leaving my top 10 games of all time and it certainly will never rank less than a 10 for me. If you have never played this game, do yourself a favor and give it a try!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
[thing=77423][/thing] sacrifices some realism* for some tense decision-making, and, yes, it does seem a bit discombobulated without a map/board, but, in the end, I'm fine with that. There's also the whole deck-building thing which I really hadn't explored in any game except [thing=53953][/thing].  However, in that game, you build your deck as you play, while in [thing=77423][/thing] the player deck is built before the game.

*Otherwise known as: "What?  If I quest, I can't defend?  And if I defend, I can't attack???"

RATING: 7.1
[b]European Chain of Generosity[/b]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Definitely my favorite LCG from Fantasy Flight. Excellent solo and team co-op, but extremely challenging. It's a little tough to introduce to new players, but if you can find someone to play with regularly, it's a lot fun. While it can be very tough, there are numerous variants and tweaks you can play to make the game more accessible. The game does a great job of immersing you in the world and quests through gameplay and flavor texts taken from Tolkein's works. I'd recommend to any player whether you're a fan of LOTR or not.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.7
In a way, the game-play of this really reminds me of the LotR board game.  The mechanics, theme and difficulty are nearly identical.  It can be amusing at first to build a powerful deck and collect new heroes and adventures.  The art is gorgeous especially since they did something completely original rather than steal from past artists or the P Jackson movies.  The game is also extremely fast/easy to setup and take-down.  But that's about it for me...

The biggest problem with this game is how much lore and consistency you've got to give up to make any kind of story work.  You'll find a lot of places, events, and characters in circumstances they have no business in.  That may not be a problem for some, but I just can't get past it.

The other problem is how much you need to spend just to make a real game of it.  The game ships with a paltry 3 scenarios, but the last one is nearly impossible without better cards.  This is a horrible decision from FF as the game screams, "money grab" right from the start.

I bought this, really wanting to build a deck with characters that truly make sense for the story, but I have to buy several different expansions for that to happen.  Seeing Eowyn at the ripe age of 7, running around Mirkwood with Denethor, of all people, just destroys this game for me (actually that sounds pretty creepy, no wonder Eowyn had men issues).

Another thing is how repetitive the scenarios become.  There's little variation and surprise to each one.  This is designed for munchkins and power gamers who want to grind through the same content with the perfect deck.  This is great for those people really into MMO raids, Pokemon, and Monster Hunter.

Until I played Pathfinder ACG, I didn't realize how much the the above issued bothered me.  I don't think I'll be playing this game again.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I have a spare unplayed coreset available

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
024.09. 09.fev.13 - BD: 37,95
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I wanted to like it, mostly because of the theme, but also because I simply wanted a good LCG, I can enjoy. However, I am very disappointed by this game.

The production value, as usual with FFG, is awesome and the art is especially gorgeous. 
But the game itself feels extremely imbalanced, dull and the mechanics never comply with the theme. 

1)
At least one of my 3 Heroes is basically completely out of the game, because he or she is solely used for their willpower. Once exhausted, that Hero can neither defend nor fight later on. This aspect feels extremely weird and unthematic. What exactly is that Hero doing, when exhausted for willpower?!?! Is he or she standing around, thinking really hard or what? I mean, I get that Heroes need to be strong mentally and physically, but still, their mental strength does not hinder them to fight and defend (at least in the books and movies everybody fights on a quest). So, this mechanic really sucks. 

2)
Another aspect that feels really weird and unthematic is that your Heroes are rather weak. Their hit points range from 2 to 6 or so and their defenses and attack values are not especially high either. Heroes die very quickly, and they have their hands full even with a couple of orcs. Remember the movies? When did the Heroes really had their problems with a couple of orcs??? Never! I am not saying, that orcs in this game should only be cannon fodder, but why do I need two (actually even three) Heores to defeat an orc? This brings me to another annoying game mechanic.

3) 
Your cards, Heroes included, can only be used for one action each round (this is why you need two or even three Heroes to defeat an orc). Once exhausted for willpower, that Hero cannot defend or fight in the same round anymore (and you need to exhaust them for willpower, because enemies increase the threat value, which is bad and because this is the only way you can advance and eventually win in this game). Once exhausted for defending (implying that you did not use that Hero for willpower earlier), that Hero cannot attack anymore (oh, and here is an exception to the mechanics, because only one hero is allowed to be exhausted for defending against an enemy. WHY?! no one knows. in all other instances there is no limit to how many cards can be exhausted). And attacking is only possible, if your Hero did not do anything at all before (was he or she just standing around, while all others were busy thinking really hard or defending against enemies, just waiting to attack?!)

4)
The resource mechanic seems a little dull. It also seems to me like it does not work really well. Most cards cost way too much for the little resources you get each round. And if one of your Heroes dies, you will get even less. And if you play with different types of Heroes, i.e. with different resource symbols, you will have even less resources to spend on cards. Feels extremely underpowered for real Heroes.

5)
This game feels very imbalanced, due to most of the above reasons. The core set seems unbeatable at times and that sucks the last bit of fun out of the game. Yes, I know, many say that co-op games need to be challenging, but come on, I would like to feel like there is a chance for me to win without buying a bunch of expansions.

Unfortunately I cannot recommend this game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
8/4/2013 - RJ and I played Passage Through Mirkwood.  He played Tactics with Beorn, Legolas and Thalin.  I played Leadership with Theodred, Gloin, and Balin.  We won in turn 3.  Our final combined threat was 32+36=68. No heroes fell.  Our combined damage on heroes was 14.  We had 5 VP's, for a score of 77.  I said "If we were maximizing VP's, we shouldn't have had Beorn sentinel defend attacks in our last round, we should have let some allies die (chomp blocking)."  My son said, "We should get some more allies in play next time we play."

8/10/2013 - Charlie was racing Matchbox cars, Mom was designing jewelry, James was down for a nap.  What time is it?  Time for RJ and I to take on Journey Along the Anduin!

RJ (7 years old) is a lover of Tactics and a hater of taking on damage.  I like the Leadership and Lore decks solo, but go Spirit when pairing up with Tactics.  RJ chose Beorn (defender), Legolas (attacker) and Gimli (wildcard).  I went with Dunhere (to pick off enemies in Stage 2) Eowyn (obviously) and Eleanor (manage "when revealed" + wildcard).

Opening hands were amazing - 2 Blades of Gondolin for RJ, 2 Unexpected Courages for me.  I had two Northern Trackers, RJ had some good events (Goblin-Cleavers, Quick Strike, Stand Together) but he lacked Allies.

Here comes the Hill Troll! :angry:  

Beorn took one for the team, ending up with 5 damage.  However, we were able to load up damage in turn 1, and in turn 2 able to use Goblin-Cleaver and Quick Strike to finish him off. :arrrh:

Our plans came together nicely.  Eowyn and Gimli were consistent questers, and we supplemented their Willpower with discards and some Allies (early Wandering Took, later Northern Trackers).  Legolas was a monster!  He attached both Gondolan Blades and I sent him an Unexpected Courage.  He was generating 10 attack and 8 progress (with lethal attacks) each round.  We blazed through Stage 1.

Early in Stage 2, we had 5 locations in the staging area. :sauron:
The Northern Trackers were the key to resolving this difficulty.  In 2 turns, the 2 Trackers had the locations cleared.  Eleanor had attached the second Unexpected Courage, and was protecting the Tactics team from "when revealed" effects frequently.  Legolas, Eowyn and Gimli led the team past Stage 2 in short order.  Off of the raft, and into the Ambush!

Dunhere came to the rescue with both Goblin Snipers, knocking them each off before they got off any damage.  In fact, after a massive attack by RJ's heroes (and lone ally Bifur), a single Sniper in the staging area was all that stood between us and the path to the Golden Wood.  Dunhere rode off to staging, and returned with glorious Victory!

Our final "old school" score was
72 threat + no death + 14 damage - 10 VP's (Gladden Fields x2, Hill Troll) = 76.  I didn't count, but I think it was 5 turns.
:A::W::E::S::O::M::E:

1/27/15 - SNOW DAY!  RJ and I, with Charlie's help and support, took on The Long Dark.  RJ went with a mono sphere Tactics deck with Bard the Bowman, Elladan and Elrohir.  I had a mix of cards maximizing card draw, shadow cancelation, and questing, with Eowyn, Theodred and Beravor.

We started with Massing in the Deep and Foul Air.  We set the stage for very lucky locate quests - I drew a PASS on my first try with Foul Air.  We played five turns - drawing mostly treacheries, two monsters that RJ engaged by never defeated, and two locations. Two Snowborne Scouts took out one of the locations before we even needed to travel there.  One Locate test took five tries, but Gleowine, an event (I forget which one) and Beravor kept me card rich.  Our questing was strong as we weren't really up against big threat in the staging area.  In turn five, we sent everyone to the quest, and finished strong.

10/3/2015 - Charles had been asking all week that we try LOTR: TCG rather than LOTR: The Confrontation.  He set up he deck with Eowyn, Legolas and his custom Charles card.  He took on Spiders and Flies, and after a rocky start (drawing Ungoliant's Spawn for his first round), he found his way down Beorn's Path.  Great fun!

RATING: 7.5
JCC oÃ¹ l'on se bat contre le scÃ©nario.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game is a cooperative adventure game in which the players attempt to complete a scenario, each with three heroes of their choice and a deck of allies, events and attachments to support them. Each round, players send their heroes and allies to quest or to fight with enemies that engage them. However, as the heroes and allies exhaust after questing, defending, or attacking, the players' options are typically insufficient to deal with everything at once. Therefore, players need to determine whether it is more urgent to quest and make progress in the scenario while the enemy forces gain power, or to take down enemies while making no progress, not knowing what will come next.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Although Iâm not generally a fan of cooperative games, the idea of a combination with deck construction is appealing and demonstrates that FFGâs greatest strength might be the willingness to try something new every now and then. The implementation is slick, although nothing in the game system itself feels as fresh as the Call of Cthulhu or Warhammer LCGs did for me. A personal highlight is the elegant way the adversarial deck is constructed depending on the adventure youâve decided to tackle.

What came as a bit of a surprise, especially when considering the excellent and new art that the game is blessed with, is how little the theme did for me. This might be an effect of too much rather than too little personal love for Tolkienâs work - to me, Eowyn and an errant halfling on a quest along the Anduin feels like fanfic. It never happened, and whatâs more important, it never could have happened in my Middle Earth. For me, the game would probably have been more immersive with a completely generic fantasy background like the Runebound world.

That the game gets a rating of 7 in spite of my personal peeves about coops and Tolkien worship is testament to its quality, and if you donât share these peeves, this is highly recommended.

Update: The 7 only applies for the 2 player game. With more, it gets a bit slow and the usual problems of cooperation games without traitors or hidden information get more noticable. Furthermore, the scenarios apparently are a lot easier with more players, which could and should have been balanced better.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I'm going to be in trouble once I pick up some expansions.  This will get expensive, but I'm looking forward to trying to build the best deck to beat each quest.

RATING: 7
+ It plays solo (although it plays better with a friend)
+ Gorgeous artwork
+ There is deck building!
+ It's not a pushover game
+ The scenarios are varied and interesting

I have grown to love this game more and more for many reasons. But the main one is, I used to love Magic but those days are gone. I still love creative decks to play with though and this game gives me that outlet. Right now the options seem thin or predetermined a bit, but as they add cards the choices grow. And I enjoy a good challenge.

If I had any real knock against this game it would be that it seems like it is tough to create 1 deck to do well in all scenarios...especially solo. So I think what is needed is a prime deck with a larger sideboard to adjust per scenario.

RATING: 8

I love the LCG aspect as well.  Overall, the theme and the mechanics provide a very enjoyable experience that's only dampened by the crippling difficulty.  But that being said, the difficulty provides a lot of replayability as you try to overcome the game in feats of wonder with your deck building and strategic skills.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
My first LCG, and got it because it plays well solo. Which it does, but the secret is that you have to play two-handed (i.e., with two decks simulating co-op) to really get the most enjoyment out of the game.

I love the idea of questing, the deck construction aspect, and the mechanics. I've bought a lot of the expansions despite not being particularly interested in the LotR theme, which should tell you how good a game it is.

I'm working my way through by playing the APs and expansions in order, using only the cards available at the time of release.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This was the game the demonstrated to me that I don't really like deck building outside of the game itself. I loved the theme and thought the game was very interesting.  Plus, I love co-ops.  However, I still ended up trading it away due to the fact that I just don't like deck building outside of game play.  I know that this is unusual, and I probably would have liked it a lot more when I was younger and had more time.  Now, it is the social interaction with other players that is the main reason I play, not the mental aspect of making a great deck.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Has quickly become the favourite game of my wife. I also love this game! Our main game to play together.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I rate CCGs and their expandable cousins (LCGs, etc.) on this basis: "I will likely never invest in one again, but assuming that someone else hands me a deck here's what I think of the game."

I didn't love this after my first play, and I'm kind of glad of it. Unlike other LCGs, which I don't need in my life, this one being full co-op means I can happily play a friend's copy and never invest in any cards. I usually rate collectible/expandable card games a 2, as I have no desire to play them again in large part because of the infrastructure and investment involved, but this one's a bit of a different animal. My 6 is based solely on its gameplay, which ranges from okay to fun.

I like the shadow mechanic for modifying monsters, and I love that it's co-op with deckbuilding. My first play was a four-player game with one core set, which I understand isn't the full experience -- 30-card decks, not 50, no deckbuilding, and mono-sphere decks. But it was enough to give me a taste. I suspect it will improve with a second game, and improve again with some deckbuilding.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Addictive game, love the art, love the theme, the customization, difficulty level is varied.  This game offer endless possibilities.

RATING: 6
At 22 games in, I must be enjoying the game to have kept going that long with only a few wins with no real sign off improvement. I play mostly solo with a single deck (usually Leadership).

The thing that I notice most is how very swingy the game is. Sure it's a card drawing game so there's bound to be elements of luck, but I regularly lose to a bad run of draws -especially if they come early. In this context, "bad run" typically means either a run of Locations with no Monsters, or a run of Monsters with no Locations. This is particularly an issue in single-deck play as each deck is sort of a one trick pony. Or it is for casual play. Deck-builders may have a different experience.

I need to try the various Easier Variants or dual-handed play to see if it helps before I invest in a second core set and the saga expansions (which were the reason I thought about playing in the first place).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.8
It is astonishingly good with 3 or 4 players, and fun to solo: great expansions; wonderful art direction; excellent rules. Easily the best Lord of the Rings game ever made. FFG's LCG concept is a winner.

One of the best things about the game is the fact that the experience is customizable: our group has many different types of players, who like to play very different types of games; decks can be built according to player preferences, which is a huge plus.

Further, the scenarios are quite challenging, taking considerable time to master (Along with the stock scenarios, I have both Khazad-Dum and Dwarrowdelf: these are well worth it). Scenarios also play quite differently with different numbers of players.

Some players hold the opinion that the game is "unbalanced." This is not the case; it is challenging; it takes time to master. Currently, I win 90% of my single-hand games, although these are almost always interesting and challenging. My current deck drops to about a 50% win rate once the challenge level gets into the 7-8 range.

The expansions are excellent and keep coming.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Very good gameplay.  Solo play is really challenging.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Beautifully thematic deck building co-op game with the benefit of being able to play solo. Quests and spheres of influence really bring customization and theme together, where you feel like you are genuinely on a quest, with each quest being varied enough to be distinguished.

The phases and rules will likely confuse many players to begin with, so it's worth watching the FFG videos and playthroughs to get an understanding; however, this is a treasure of a game I will always regard as a favorite.

RATING: 9.75
I suspected I would be hooked on this game the first time I played it. I was introduced in 2015 by my friend Chrispy. It wasn't necessarily love at first sight, but as I kept thinking about the game in the days following I knew I was going to have to buy it. I enjoy that I can play it solo and do a little deck building (a nice escape into nostalgia for my old MtG days) but I really enjoy playing with one or two friends. The cooperative discussions about how to overcome the challenges of the quests, and how to tweak the decks between plays are my favorite moments. I am glad there are a lot of expansions, because this is a game that I feel like I just want to keep playing. It's telling that the box and the cards have been permanently out on my gaming room table for months on end.

It is a short game, 30-60 minutes, and readily teachable to others who may be interested.

RATING: 7
I hated this game for quite a while but I've finally learned how to enjoy it. Now I pick my hero's based purely off theme and story rather then building them to beat a specific quest. Now Im able to just enjoy the story as it evolves. 

Update: I love the storytelling concepts in this game but the actual gameplay experience is too difficult and mathy for me. Unfortunately the storytelling doesnt flow naturally, you must go out of your way to make sense of the random cards and build it into a cohesive story. There are too many other games that capture the spirit of adventure better than this. I may buy the hobbit set in the hopes that they reset he difficulty but with the rediculious difficulty levels common in the game the experience just drags on too long! 

Update: in the end I decided not to throw away the game just because the difficulty balance is tuned too much for hardcore lifestyle gamers. At this point I just change some rules slightly to make the scenarios fun or simply avoid the poorly balanced ones.

RATING: 8
The fantasy adventure theme of Descent, but shorter.  The teamwork of Arkham Horror, but easier to teach.  The variable player strategy of Race for the Galaxy, but interactive.  This is the tabletop game experience I've been looking for.

And not only can it be played solo, but a solo deck must be tuned to meet the challenges of different quests, so it's a gratifying experience that I am hopeful won't get stale after a handful of plays.

Feb-10-2012: Every adventure pack for the Mirkwood cycle presented a unique challenge and some great new player cards.  This game has so far stayed as interesting as I had hoped.  Still going strong!

Jan 2013: Down from 9 to 8.  This one has seen less and less play.  I simply do not have the time to rebuild my deck and revise my strategy after every loss.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Great co-op deck-construction LCG that is a lot of fun solitaire and with more players. I was really skeptical about having a game where I need to buy new cards to get better decks, and then also buy new cards to get more opposition from the game. It feels counter productive but when I played the game I didn't mind and the deck-creation aspects are really nice.

Like all other LCGs it's still hypocritical in that you need to get 3 copies of the core game in order to build great decks from the start.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Excellent game when you start collecting several expansion allowing real deckbuilding (as expected from LCG)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
[microbadge=1714]

[u]01/24/2013[/u]: Hmm.  This is a tough one for me to comment on.  I think it's my second most played game at the moment?  The theme is fantastic, one of the strongest themed games I own.  The inner workings of this game amaze me.  How all of the different decks of cards not only interact with themselves but with (and against) each other boggles my mind.  The replayability is quite high, especially if you decide to continue purchasing the monthly expansions that are available.  Solitaire play is easily the most challenging of any game I own.  The card quality and artwork are top notch.

However, I had never played a CCG or LCG prior to this journey I attempted...and I struggled.  A lot.  Just read some of my play log and you'll see the frustration in many of them.  The one thing I learned about myself after playing this game - I'm not a CCG-style deckbuilder.  To play this game, you really need to know all of your cards.  And know how all of your cards will or will not work together.  And then you have to take the time to put the "right" cards together in a single deck.  Only then will you be able to play.  You will realize that your deck isn't going to win and you'll have to tweak it.  And probably tweak it again.  And probably again.  Eventually, you will win, and it will feel fantastic.  And then you'll decide to start over with a different set of heores or a different combination of spheres.  And the process will repeat.

Yes, you can just keep the single, pre-constructed decks alone and play with them, but I don't think success will find you often.

As you can tell, my "problem" with this game is me.  Not the game.  I'm just not a deckbuilder at heart, I guess.  I could just go on the forums and build other people's decks, but 1) that feels like cheating and 2) I don't have most of the cards other people do because I only own one core set and none of the monthly packs.  That's really my negative about this system of gaming...you really should buy the expansions to get the full experience.  I've gotten lots of plays of this amazing game, but that's because I'm so bad at it.

If you enjoy CCG-style deckbuilding, adding this game to your collection should be a no-brainer.  AND, if you need or enjoy playing alone, this has it all in one box.  Well...plus several expansion packs.

[u]10/15/2013[/u]: The second game to leave my collection.  An excellent game that, ultimately, wasn't for me.  It's in a better home now.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Much like any card game, Lotr:LCG has a problem with a few cards that are absolutely obsolete. It also seems to have a few issues with power creep - making the a bunch of the core cards loose value over time. However, this is a minor problem when considering the good sides of the game has.

After 45 plays, this is ranking really high in my favorite games. The setup time is extremely minimal - if you have your decks (quest and player) built, it takes about as much time as Race For the Galaxy to get going (just hit the cards on the table, shuffle and play), takes a really suitable amount of time (30-45 minutes for the tighter quests), has tons of bang for buck (with 2 Cores and an Expansion, the game is currently at 2â¬ per play, and decreasing) and this can further be enhanced with more expansions and the Nightmare mode (yet to be tested).

The biggest gripe for me is (and this isn't a huge deal, even less than with Netrunner) is that you really need two Cores to be able to tackle the harder adventures. Luckily this also allows for a 4-player mode and gives you even more tokens, that WILL come in handy. 

A really good game, one of the best I've played, co-op or no.

Comparing to other Co-ops I've played:

Arkham Horror: swifter gameplay, less time for setup, more strategy, about the same difficulty, less players, both have tons of theme, you feel more powerful in this game, you feel less personally invested in this game, LOTR is the better single-player game, Arkham has dice and I like dice. Both are beautiful. Arkham is more fun to pimp out.

Ghost Stories: LotR has better theme and integrates it better, Ghost stories is harder, both set-up quickly and play relatively quickly, LotR is more varied, LotR is better with other players (less quarterbacking), both can be brain burners, both are stunning visually, Ghost Stories is a lot easier to teach and get new players to try it out, Ghost Stories has a better manual (imho).

Pandemic: Lotr setup is quicker, both look nice (though LotR is nicer by a good margin), Pandemic is easier to teach, Lotr is a lot more varied, has less quarterbacking, expands better, is harder and more strategic. I really don't feel for Pandemic.

Mage Knight: I think Mage Knight is the closest comparison that I can give to LotR. Both are card driven, require long-term planning and resource management, though I think LotR is harder. Mage Knight has more rules, but I think it has the better rulebook of these two (especially if you count the extremely good tutorial videos). Both are really stunning looking. Mage Knight has you invested in your characters story. Mage Knight has a longer setup and a longer playtime which does prevent it from hitting the table as often. It also takes a lot more space on the table. Both are really good single player games and I love every minute of both.


(260415) I still like the game a lot, but it doesn't hit the table that often. The rulebook still seems like a mess and I'm glad that there are videos online that teach the game (looking at you Rodney and Ricky). The deck building isn't as immersive as it is in Magic or Netrunner, but just as necessary. Perhaps this is because I don't have as many cards available?
I really like playing the game, but only when I have a new adventure at hand, and I always feel somewhat hesitant in picking up new content, since the game isn't on the table that often.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[size=10][u][i][b]r{Initial Thoughts}r (after 5 plays):[/u][/b][/i][/size]
* Excellent LCG (Living Card Game) with an equally excellent theme
* Rules are relatively straightforward, but card synergies leave much open to debate
* Good as a solo affair, but more engaging and rousing as a multiplayer experience
* Line between an LCG and CCG (Collectible Card Game) seems like it is blurring
* Good for fans of the theme and former [b]Magic[/b] addicts 
* Initial rating: [b]9/10[/b]

[size=10][u][i][b]b{Further Thoughts}b (after 25 plays):[/u][/b][/i][/size]
* Playing monosphere decks gets a bit "samey," and not too up on deck building
* Losing some luster as a solo game, and can't find too many multiplayer opportunities
* Trying to keep up with the myriad of expansions is like trying to race the wind
* Further rating: [b]8/10[/b]

[size=10][u][i][b]g{Advanced Thoughts}g (after 50 plays):[/u][/b][/i][/size]
* Still need more multiplayer opportunities, as less than 5 of my plays are with 2+
* Feels like game has defintely crossed the line from LCG to CCG
* Still enjoy playing the game itself, but keeping myself from buying all the expansions
* Advanced rating: [b]8/10[/b]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The best co-op card game. I love LOTR and this game did not dissapoint the frnachise at all. As with most CCGs/LCGs, there are a lot of small questions relating to card effects and interactions but it doesn't detract from the game. The quests are challenging and the quality of most of them is excellent.

Edit:
This game suffers from one major flaw, decks must be built per quest otherwise it's just too challenging (read:impossible). I like this game a lot but playing some recent quests with my favorite decks and getting destroyed first turn or losing on a card draw after an hour of playing killed it for me.

RATING: 9
Fantastic game that is really fun to play solo - looking forward to playing this a lot!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Play and manipulate cards to complete quests in Middle-Earth.

Plays: More than 200.
Type: Thematic cooperative game = a theme-driven game where you play together against the game. Deck building pre-game.
Complexity: Medium strategy game.
# of players: 1.
Playing time: Depends a lot on the scenario.
Player interaction: Best played solo. Otherwise cooperation.
Randomness: Low â card draw, but you decide what cards go in your deck.

Replayability: Very high. The possibility to play every scenario with a different group of heroes and different resuorces makes you want to play again immediately. Often you want to play again with the same setup as well, just to see if you can beat the scenario if you do things slightly different. Deck building increases replayability even further.
Fun: Itâs fun to try to come up with the deck and the plan to beat the scenarios. Playing the scenarios can also bring a smile to your face when good things happen, for example when Gandalf comes up just when you need to get rid of a particularly nasty enemy. Itâs less fun when the scenario is just destroying your heroes, but if youâre playing solo thereâs no problem to start over.
Memorability: Medium. This creates a story about heroes questing in Middle Earth. Itâs not deeply immersive, but definitely good. Youâll not remember the details, but more of the general feeling of each scenario.

Thematic integration: Good. The game does a good job communicating the theme. The art is evocative, your favourite characters are all here and there are lots of Tolkien quotes on the cards. Itâs as good as it can possibly get in a game that is ultimately about resource management âunder the hoodâ.
Components: Excellent. The art is great and the cards are of good quality.

Who will like this: Gamers that want a game to play solo and like the theme.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This one is sinking a bit for me; I've fallen behind in the sets, and deck construction becomes a more time-consuming task as more cards are released. Still, a lot to like here, both solo and in a group. I think it's thematically successful, punishing without being unfair (for the most part), and lovely to look at. It's fiddly, though, and lengthier than it should be at times. I hope it makes a comeback for me.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
One of my favorite solo games. This is an excellent, often very thematic experience, especially if you are a fan of Tolkien. The sheer amount of available content provides tons to explore. The game can be brutally difficult and unforgiving, and that's not always what I'm in the mood for. Also, I've found myself less and less enthused by the deck construction element of the game; I'm more likely to get something else to the table these days. So, that brings my rating down a notch.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Fun,but to easy. I am having to add extra layers if difficulty which make it amazing.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The LotR LCG is a quality deviation from most of FFG's library.  Where most are competitive and involve taking a specific side, LotR lets the player choose a subset of the fantasy world for their team and play cooperatively against a stack of encounter cards and a short narrative.

This game is best played with other players familiar with text-heavy card games; otherwise you'll find yourself just managing the other player's actions and diminishing the enjoyment for everyone.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is a great game to play as a co-op campaign with one other person. Like other collectible card games, it does require some commitment in learning the card pool and what is possible to add to your deck. However, it's not as bad as Netrunner in that aspect since you can ask the other players for advice.

If you buy a second Core Set you can expand the game to 4 players, but I think it's best with 2. The game is easier with each added player, and playing only 1 player is very difficult unless you play two-handed (using two decks at the same time). 2 decks is a good balance of difficulty for most quests.

One issue of early LOTR LCG releases is card balance, with some cards being vastly better than others. An example of this is the Steward of Gondor which nearly doubles your resource generation at a tiny cost. So you can get the feeling that some cards are too good to ignore and that limits the deckbuilding. However, this is not as much of a problem in later sets as the cards have become more balanced over time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
