=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I've only played this solo, and aside from Dominion, I'm not a fan deck building.  So factor that in to my opinion.  

This is nice little game.  The base game comes with 4 starter decks.  Each plays very differently from one another, so once you've become overly familiar with one deck's play against a particular quest, you've got an instant re-boot just by selecting another deck.  And how long does it take to get "overly familiar"...I'd say 10-15 plays or so.  So with 4 decks and 3 quests, that comes to 120 - 180 plays.  Not bad!

Now about my score.  This is a very thematic game.  The cards within a pre-determined deck speak nicely to one another, and the adversary decks that get put together for a given quest our very cool, doom-filled, and thematically aggravating!  My main beef, and the reason I don't rate the game higher, is that honestly I don't find it to be a very strategic game.  Tense, yes.  Tactical within a given turn or two, yes.  But when people say that this game is "hard" they mean "hard" in the same way that rolling a 1 or 2 on a ten-sided die is hard.  Just my $.02, and remember, I'm not someone who enjoys the fiddling with decks part of CCG / LCGs.  I get it, that is where the strategy is going to be.  Even so, though, rest assured, if you are NOT in to deck building, this is still a very engaging, thematic game.

PS - The "Watch It Played" videos were invaluable for my learning the game.

Update:
Lowered to 6. After the initial burst of enthusiasm about this game, I haven't touched it.  Nothing was pulling me to play the game, and I came to think of the theme as, well, not so well done.  I want my LotR literary, and finally never felt like playing this one with friends.  So, it doesn't do what I want a game to do.  Still admire the mechanics. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Played it as single player and it's hard and random but has my fave story as its theme.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
In this cooperative card game, players are going on quests with characters from Lord of the Rings. First, you get 1 resource per hero, and with these resouces you can play allies, attachments, etc. Each round, you then have to decide which of your characters to commit to the quest, then defend or attack against enemies. The trick is that your characters can only choose one of questing, defending or attacking before their card is exhausted for the round. 

The time pressure element is measured by "threat". If you don't proceed along quests very well, you gain more threat, and the game ends for the player if you exceed a certain threat. 

The quests have different levels of difficulty. I'm having fun trying to survive the more difficult quests and like the puzzle solving aspect of that. 

The mechanics are borrowed from Magic:The Gathering, but it's a fun fresh cooperative game each time.

It's also a much better game than The Game of Thrones:LCG, by the same designer. I'm having fun experimenting with the four different themed decks and looking forward to more plays. You can play it solo, or with more players, where you can see interaction between the various decks, so there is more variety. 

However, there are all sorts of rules questions, which take some time to sort through. You will need some patience to get through all the different rules for different scenarios.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
High learning curve to begin with and some very frustrating/random events, which can cause a world of pain to new players. This game takes a lot of patience early on and I would suggest playing some games with people who already have the core set/decent cards before making a purchase. The core game as a standalone is great in terms of presentation and the cards themselves. However some may be disappointed with the lack of replay value with the core card pool. If you are willing to spend a bit of money on expansions the game really starts to open up and can be a lot of fun. If you love lotr and it's expanded universe then this is a great hobby game to get into. Just don't expect the core set to be a great standalone product as it's basically the gateway into the game.

RATING: 8
Man oh man where to start? First of all I must admit I am a Tolkien fan (not saying huge because I know how some fans are but in any case still a fan), so any opinion of mine going into this will be completely biased, but then again I don't see how anyone can dislike this game. The base game: It has a really good replay value, lets get that out of the way because I have read my fair share of reviews on this game before purchasing and that seemed to be the main concern, that the game is only enjoyable if and when you buy a ton of expansions. No. Just no. If you want more quests, just go to the forums and search for custom scenarios. I downloaded a few and printed them out, sleeved them and they do increase the replay value, but still I believe the main three scenarios still contribute to that a ton. Other issues people had was how tough the game is. Simple solution, easy mode. Just start playing easy mode and work your way up to standard, that's what I did and I don't see any shame in that at all. Anyhow lets get to the game itself. It is extremely thematic, I mean every time I start a scenario, every time I read the flavour text of a quest I feel completely immersed in the experience. I read a ton of flavour text when I play this game because it is fun, it just makes the already awesome challenging gameplay that much better. The artwork is just spectacular. Everything about this game is good, just brilliant!

With a saga expansion under my belt, I can say this game has drastically improved in the thematic sense, something I did not think was possible. It amazes me every single time I play through a quest how masterfully some mechanics have been designed for certain story elements. They fit in so well that the gameplay is silky smooth.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is a game for which you need to adjust your expectations. The point is not so much to win the scenarios as to customize your deck to do better in the given situation. Love the theme and the artwork, and even the underlying mechanics, but the game is so hard that you often don't feel like you had a chance even if you had made all the right decisions.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
This game is just not for me.  I realize many people enjoy what this game offers, but I was unhappy with a number of elements of this game that left a bad taste in my mouth.  These include:

1. I thought the game would provide versatility in player number.  But really if I wanted to play with four players and have the requisite 50 cards decks, I would need to buy two base sets. This was not something made clear.

2. Adding to the above, if I wanted to play a 2 player game and construct a deck with multiple factions, either the other player is forced to use the unused factions, or if I want 3 factions, the other player is out of luck.

3. Only the first quest is playable single player.  THe other two are so difficult it ruins the game.  Even using pre-constructed decks by other people who we "crushing all the quests" led to loss after loss.  Losing the game after turn three 5-7 times in a row just leads to aggravation.  It's the same feeling I get when I am stuck at the same place in a videogame and have to play the same scene over and over again.

4. I don't want to buy expansions just to get to the playable material and the 2 expansions I did buy with the base set didn't add all that much (except another quest).

5. Most of the game seems to revolve around the deck construction element.  Once constructed it's about seeing how that deck plays out.  There's very little in game decision making that needs to take place.  If you lose, you go back to deck construction and try again.

I do like the mechanisms of the game and the way it flowed.  I really did want to like this game.  But now my eyes just pass right over it in favor of the many other better games I have.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This popped up on my radar and I hesitated for a while.  After FFG revealed the 3rd preview, I added it as a pre-order and began tracking its' progress.  It quickly became my most anticipated game ever.

I love LotR.
I love CCG's.
I, by necessity, only buy solitaire-playable games at this point.

This game is AWESOME!

It captures the theme for me.  Most every play could easily have been written as a story about Middle Earth.

After 26 plays, 25 of which are solo, I do not think this plays like a puzzle.  Nor does it feel like the game is playing me.  A good part of that has to do with the theme.  It also has to do with reflecting on poor choices I made that let the situation get out of hand.

Is there imbalance between the decks?  Yes.  Legolas and the Bad-Ax boys are terrible on their own.  They kick backsides and take names when used with another deck.

Is there luck involved? Yes.  It's a card game.  Luck happens.

Does it feel like unlucky situations can be overcome? Yes.  And, even when things go terribly wrong, I can't help but feel the evil forces of Sauron winning this battle.  Gotta get a new group of heroes and create some threat of my own.

Can you play with 4 people with 1 set?  Yes. I played one game with 3, using a piece of paper to keep track of my threat.  What fun! In fact, it appears to scale really well.  I thought we'd rock on the Mirkwood quest, and it actually got tricky and required some careful cooperation to win.  We all had a blast.

Are there any broken cards?  No.  I consider myself to be a decent CCG analyst.  Having played through the first two quests, I have found the cards to be well balanced.  There is one broken situation that could possibly happen (2 crows left in the encounter deck during the quest phase with Thalin participating in the quest), but good luck trying!

At first I was perturbed because FFG did not include 3 of each card in the box.  However, after reading others' comments on the geek and more consideration, I have decided that I cannot fault them.  The game stands on its' own.  The buyer is not compelled to dive into the expensive and time consuming world of customizing decks.  And if you do?  Just buy a 2nd set!  If any of the CCG's you love had done this, you would have been ecstatic!

Why this is a 10
+ I do want to play this most all of the time.
+ I love the theme and its' implementation
+ I can play it by myself, but it also works great with 3
+ I love having the ability to manage my own luck in a game
+ gush, gush, gush - BLECH!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I have played this a lot solo and co-op with the wife (one of her favorite games).

I never really played games where you have to build and plan a deck out in advance of actually playing (e.g. Magic).  I wasn't sure I would enjoy it or not - but its actually a lot of fun to do that.  You can spend hours fussing and planning over how you want to build your decks.  Great for obsessive types.

If you know you don't enjoy deck construction games like Magic the Gathering, then you're probably going to want to skip this one or rely on a friend or use pre-made deck lists others have made.

Key Points:

- adjustable difficulty level
- tons of replayability
- tons of different content available
- approx 1 hour play time per scenario
- expensive (to get enough cards to build decks)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Wow... solo mode single-sphere is a bear! Solo dual-sphere is a much calmer and less luck-defined experience. The game takes up a decent amount of table space (for a card game) and is slightly fiddly. 

Co-op is a bit easier - multiple spheres really help out. You really feel like you are helping each other survive - which is feeling absent in most other co-ops.

The game is a bit hard to learn/teach to those with no equivalent experiences in some other CCG or LCG.

Generally amazing art, very solid game play, great theme. This is going to be quite addicting...

6.æ°é¬¥ æµè»åæ»æï¼æ¯å¼µæªå¨æ½ä¸å¼µçèèæ¾ï¼ä¹å¾ç©å®¶å®£åé²ç¦¦æ¿æªæ©«ç½®çæ©«ç½®ï¼ä¸é»æä¸é»ï¼å®£åå®å¾æªç¿»çï¼å¦ææä¸æ¹æå½±ææå·è¡ï¼ç¶å¾ç¸½æ»æåæ¸é²ç¦¦åçºå·å®³ï¼è¶éçå½ä¸éå°±æ£æï¼å¤çå·å®³ä¸æå³éï¼æ¯äººæå°±æé æå®æ´æ»æåçå·å®³ï¼è¦é¸æä¸é»è±éæ¾

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
200+ plays. What I thought was a clean set of rules (on the reading) turns into an FAQ mess through all the card interactions, however once you get past that and print off some of the excellent aids to help ... there's good decisions to make on what cards to invest in and when. Then it's choosing which units will travel through your quest (but which are then unable to defend against baddies), which do you leave on guard against potential upcoming baddies (the turn of a deck), and which to then leave available to whack the baddies back in return. All of which disguises the fact that your result will probably reflect the luck of the cards, but at least you'll have enjoyed the struggle to do the best you can with what you get. This is good fun with another gamer (definitely not a spouse game) who's into the theme and the CCG genre (ie comfortable with card effects), otherwise it's going to be tough to get to the table. The scenarios always have tight spots where you think all might be lost, and it can be an amazed satisfaction afterwards if/as you get through it. The more you play, the more important it is to keep cards as specific answers to specific upcoming events rather than play them out just because they're good now and you have the resources available to spend. Which also means knowing and tracking what's left to be dealt with in the encounter deck. There's a bunch of scenario / deck combos to work through before you need to invest more. A keeper if you have someone to play it with.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
Not my wife's cup of tea, but rich in theme.  Nominally good gameplay as co-ops go.  Now that my son and I are playing every Saturday, I find it rich and engaging.  I think about it all week.  That's a sign of an immersive game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
What I like:
- Pure co-op with pretty good theme and pretty art
- Fan-designed and official expansions available if needed
- Each sphere has a very different flavor

What I don't like:
- I think you have to enjoy deck construction to really like this game
- Gameplay can be a bit repetitive and a bit random
- 2nd scenario is BRUTAL, and the last 45 minutes of your game might just be postponing your inevitable doom

Not being a deck construction guy, it's hard for me to treat deck construction as being part of the fun of the game. To me, constructing a different deck for each scenario feels a bit like cheating. Also, beating a scenario may require taking advantage of little quirks in the rules or the scenario elements. That also doesn't feel like a fun part of the game.

The game also feels a bit like a video game, where you play a scenario repeatedly (often losing), learning how to construct a deck (or at least play your deck) to win. I have not felt that with any other co-op.

The BGG 2.9 weight seems about right. It's substantially more complicated than Knizia's Lord of the Rings boardgame.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

150.00 (Base box 2x + cycle)

RATING: 7.5
I played it quite a few times now. I bumped it down a bit to 7.5 because I like the Star Wars LCG better. It's a good game and I will keep it as my only solo player game for me to bring along on travels since it is Compact. I'm curious to try out the quest packs. 

I have no bested the Mirkwood (DL1) and Down the Anduin River (DL4) comfortably enough to take on the third and last quest of the core set. After that I will move on the Hunt for Gollum. 

I have committed to purchase one quest pack per month up until I find loose interest (if ever).

Neat game but the theme doesn't come across at all to me since it's just playing cards and whilst the artwork is fantastic, it doesn't really work as such. It's a neat solo playing card game (problem resolution exercise, which is something I enjoy doing).

Nice fame but gave it away. Not.good enough for me to sit down and play on my own. I rather do something else when on my own...

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
EDIT:
This has dropped significantly for me. I think it may have worn out its welcome. It is just an extremely hard game and it wears on you after a while. I do really enjoy this game and I still think it is the best FF LCG but we are taking a break from it.
LotR is my LCG. There are many FF LCGs that I enjoy playing or can appreciate are good, but LotR is far and away my favorite one. I love that it is a co-op game instead of a head to head. My fiance and I like to play a lot of 2 player games, since we are both avid gamers and sometimes it's hard to find others to play with. It's really nice to take a break from always beating each other up or going head to head to work together to complete some quests. This game is HARD, but boy is it satisfying when you win. And the idea of it is so unique. There are not many other collectible games like this that are co-op. Pick it up and give it a shot if you never have. I can't recommend it enough.

RATING: 9
I love the artwork and presentation. I think some of the designs are the best I have seen in any game. I love using the characters and attachments too. Overall though, I  have had to make a lot of simplifications and changes in order for this game to run properly. The more I play, the more the unnecessary complexity grates - shadow phases - the way each location has different rules - and actually progressing through locations, keeping track of the sequencing of events etc. Still - there is some kind of magic there...

Completed Saga Pack 1

RATING: 7
Remarkable card game that is complex enough to get the brain working overtime. Wonderful strategic workout that is far less luck dependent than one would expect. Plays well solitaire and travels well on business trips. 

The expandability of the system through low cost add-ons means the adventures can go on for a long time without getting stale. Accommodates user made adventures very well. Solid, knowledgeable and passionate community. 

Very solid 10 and one of my best game purchases ever (computer or board).

============================

Adjusting rating. Loved the basic box and got many good hours with it, but once I tried to keep up with all the expansions, things got a little unwieldy. Attempts to play with 3 players were always a little chaotic and started to find it annoying to keep track of all the modifiers flying around. I may pick this up again one day but for now it is off my radar when I choose something to play.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
The game is really nice looking, you can see that they put a lot of energy into the design and even into the originality of the quests. You must work together, from 2 to 4 players to complete a quest, but it is not easy as you need to build decks to fit specific quests, otherwise you will get slaughtered. The main problem is that it seems that the actual play through of the quests was not tested very well. They rush out new expansions before they can really ensure that they play properly and therefore you are always wondering what to do in certain situations and have to make a lot of house rules. Improve the game play and this could be a great game, not just a good one.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I wanted to like this so much, but it didn't deliver. I got the base set and two big expansions straight off the bat. For a single player, there just aren't a whole lot of options. Most scenarios are soul-crushingly hard. I like a challenge, but this game steps on your throat from the get if you don't know the ins and outs of building decks (and I don't). It's been gathering dust, but I decided to throw money at the problem and buy more expansions to give myself greater flexibility in the decks I build. I haven't broken into them yet, but I'm hoping they give this game a new life for me.

Edit- after adding 2 APs and another big box expansion, (DR)I've finally come around. It's a lot more fun when you have a fighting chance. It took a ridiculous amount of money to get to this point though, so I'd caution a solo player that he'd better have deep pockets before breaking into the game.

RATING: 6
This is a cooperative LCG where each player has a unique deck and, together, the party advances to different locations, fights various enemies, and tries to work toward some sort of common goal.  I guess it's okay for what it is, though I'm really not sure how well the concept of cooperative play meshes with an LCG.  There didn't really seem to be that much tension in the game, and I didn't see that many opportunities for longer-term strategy, though I admit my one play was in a super easy scenario and I didn't construct my own decks.

(1 play)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Bottom line: TLotR: The Card Game is a well designed and illustrated game that I ended up not being very willing to play due to its frustrating difficulty.

I love the Lord of the Rings theme and the game & artwork capture it well; however, the game captures the hopeless situation of the good guys too well.  My wife and I love challenging co-op games, but we found this game challenging to the point of frustration.  We enjoy playing The Forbidden Desert.  We often lose, but we always have some new idea to try for the next session.  With LotR:The Card Game we often felt we couldn't have played it any better which dampened our enthusiasm for the game.  Consequently we played LotR:The Card Game less and less and we eventually traded it.

RATING: 10
This has turned out to be a fantastic co-op game. My wife always enjoys it which is always a big plus for me. 

Extremely challenging at first but you get better with repeated plays. The final quest in the core game is painfully difficult and agonizing (It's awesome!). 

Deck building is necessary for having success beyond the first quest. The good news is if you don't like deck building just look on the site for some Deck ideas and your ready to go. 

The game can be played solo but requires serious deck building to have any kind of success beyond the first quest. Balance seems off as well for solo. The game seems geared specifically for two players.

My favorite co-op to date. This game is going to hit the table often.

edit: having all the available expansions has boosted this up to a 10 for me. It's also now my wife's favorite co-op. edit: ok, its hard keeping up with all the expansions, but you can get many plays out of a single cycle. However the game gets increasingly better with the more content you have.

edit: I really LOVE the art in this game. It's incredibly good (most of it at least, there are the typical cheap rush jobs interspersed). My wife enjoys just looking at all the cards before we begin. I wouldn't mind some of it in a larger size or as my desktop background.

Edit: Yay a digital version is coming. Hope it's good.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The concept of this game is fantastic - I've been eyeing the WoW card game for a while on account of its raid-deck coop scheme, but have always been turned away by comments that it takes pretty serious constructed decks to go up against the raid. Enter FFG's LotR:TCG, a game designed explicitly for deck-building coop, in the fairly reasonable (affordable) LCG format.

So far, after a few solo games and one 3P, I think this game has a lot of promise. With just one core set, deck construction is pretty straightforward - grab the cards from two spheres, pick a major and a minor, and strip 10 cards from the minor. Done. It's still a fun process, though, and there's plenty of room for experimentation with hero selection and 12 Ma/Mi sphere combos. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Sleeved

RATING: 9
I love deckbuilding and I love Lord of the Rings lore. After playing warhammer quest adventure card game I played this. I found LOTR to have more depth and with an additional core set (or 2) and some expansions this game has great replay value. The mechanics seem complicated at first but then fade into the background after repeated play. +1 star for solo play, -2 stars for core set leaving out the rare cards and 3-4 player non-compatibility.

RATING: 7
2/16/12 - This took a couple games to grow on me. Once I started building my own decks this became a more enjoyable game adding that extra level of pre-game deck building strategy like Magic the Gathering. Some of the scenarios play in 15-20 minutes which is really nice because sometimes you just get utterly destroyed early so it's nice that it ends quick so you can quest again. This is my new favorite game!

7/15/12 - I've traded for more expansions but haven't really played them. The quests are very hard if you are playing single player unless you control a second deck. I used to enjoy building the decks but now I have to manage 2 which makes setting up take forever which is a huge deterrent when I'm picking out a game to play. I thought getting more expansions would make the game more interesting but it just made it more complicated, not in a fun way. I've downgraded the game from an 9 to an 7. I'll give it another shot.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
[Initial comments, June 2011, based on core set solo plays only]:
I'm in two minds about this game - on the one hand I love anything to do with LotR, and this game does the setting justice in the art, presentation, and the concept of the game itself, and I've become slightly obsessed with it, playing it more times in a month than any game before (with the exception of Magic the Gathering). So I'd like to rate it a 9 or 10 just on the basis of how often I want to play it.

BUT... it can also be infuriating and it's too easy for fun to turn to frustration in the middle of a game when a nicely balanced, tense situation suddenly goes disastrously wrong due to a series of bad card draws, and sometimes it seems no amount of clever play or planning can help (at least for now, until deck-building options increase).  But the frustration soon wears off and I want to try it again the very next day.

So I think it's probably a great game, but for now I'm reserving judgment on just how great, until the adventure packs start rolling and I can see how well the deck-building elements and diversity of quests work out.

[Edit Sept 2011]:
After buying a 2nd core set and the first three adventure packs, I'm liking the way this game is going. The variety of quests and the different approaches you need to tackle them is great and keeps the game fresh, even when one quest gets frustrating. I don't really understand the complaints about it requiring deck-building, or those who want to use the same deck for every quest - isn't the variety and the scope for experimentation the whole point of CCGs/LCGs?  

My attempts at deck-building haven't been terribly successful so far, but I'm getting a glimpse of how the increased card pool and flexibility of deck construction can help to mitigate some of the initial grievances I had with the game's unpredictability.

Rating up from 8 to 9 - it might go up even further, especially if I ever manage to play it as a 2+ player game.

[Edit May 2013]:
OK, after 2 years I'm still thoroughly addicted - the expansions are really keeping it interesting and my deck-building has improved so I'm getting a reasonable success rate. My first game to break the 100-play barrier and I can't see myself getting bored with it for a long time so I have to upgrade this to my first 10 rating.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Very enjoyable as solo play (haven't had the opportunity to play with others). I really got the sense of being part of a group of heroes from Middle Earth doing quests and vanquishing big baddies (and little minion baddies too). The travel phase feels a little tacked on, though. I hope FFG tweaks the traveling aspect, because encounter deck searching feels more like dealing with threats at a location than removing quest point buffers. Exploring locations needs more rewards. Another thing is that some cards don't have multiples, or not enough multiples, which forces you to buy more core sets or use proxies (and requires more bookkeeping). The core set only comes with three quests, which is a bit low in quantity as well as in terms of replayability. Quite frankly, I have no inclination to replay a quest several times in finding challenges based around pedantic deck tweaking or using other hero configurations other than the perfect (or near-perfect) permutation. That's just replaying for the sake of replaying, which is forced and artificial. However, there are several fan made quests which easily fill in the time-suckage (pleasant and fun time-suckage, mind you), and helps you to get more mileage out of the game, particularly if you're not inclined to purchase the monthly expansion sets. All in all, I recommend this one. :)

edit: after 1 year of play, starts getting a bit samey. the theme loses its edge. down from 8.5 when i first played it. But who cares! This is such an accomplished game. Tip of the hat to FFG for such a fine effort!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
An excellent and challenging co-op card game.  The theme and artwork is top-notch.  The mechanics are easy enough to pick up and remember.  All-in-all, a solid game.

Where it falls flat for me is in the challenge of the game and the intent of the design.  With the exception of a few overpowered decks you can build, Each adventure requires you to build a deck specifically designed to overcome it.  If you don't want to peek ahead at what's coming in a given adventure, this means you will need to replay the same adventure (often several times) in order to defeat it.  Some people appreciate and enjoy that level of difficulty and required deck-building as part of the puzzle of the game.  I do not.  I enjoy deck-building, but not over and over for each mission.

RATING: 8
A great solitaire game!

Beware the false economy of the LCG format. Although you won't be dropping hundreds of dollars for a handful of important cards, you can STILL be dropping hundreds of dollars.

The game is fun, brutal, thematic, pretty, and good solitaire. My beefs with it are that you sometimes have to build decks specifically to beat certain scenarios, so it's hard to just have "your deck" and take on what you take on.

The rules are a little....bulky? I've played a ton of this and I still need to the reminder text out in front of me to remember what I'm doing next. It doesn't flow in any way that makes sense in my brain. But still an awesome game!

RATING: 8
This game is absolutely awesome, obviously more so if you're an avid LOTR fan.

Each quest is so dynamic and different, which keeps it so interesting while maintaining the familiarity of your personalised deck.

Quests are really challenging and communication is so important to ensure the party gives themselves the best chance at succeeding.

My only slight quarrel is that there is a constant need  to buy expansions which is obviously expensive, but these are so interesting I'm sure you'll return to replay them.

I really can't recommend this game enough and hope the expansions remain available to buy for a long time.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A campaign which requires you to buy more adventure packs and expansions to continue the game. 

Each pack allows you to play a few times due to the difficulty of the game. Some scenarios are harder than others and may even require very good "luck of the draw" to help you win.

You are given freedom to build your deck between each scenario, adjusting or even completely changing your deck and heroes to cope with the scenario you just lost. You most probably won't know what's going to happen in the next scenario because most of the encounter decks are new due to the LCG system. 

Only occasionally you would build an encounter deck with previously used "enemy" decks.

Also the scenarios have different types of objectives, it may be just a battle to fight your way in/out, to capture/escort someone or plainly just to explore as much as possible to find something.

RATING: 8
This is a really well-designed game. The decision of questing, attacking, blocking, and using abilities with each individual character gives you a lot of options during play. I've often wanted a co-op version of Magic: the Gathering, and this provides all the great tactical decisions of Magic: the Gathering and makes the mechanics work flawlessly as a cooperative game. I only own the base game, and I have to say that the deckbuilding is not good given such a limited card selection, but the expansions should change that. Also, a lot of the cards in the base set seem quite weak, but that will similarly improve with additional investment.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Probably the best solo game I know of, or at least have run across. Also my first foray into the LCG model, and I really like it. The deck construction of CCG's interests me as it does most, but I just can't abide the random purchases. This solves that while still offering that strategy aspect of trying to construct a deck to handle whatever quest you are facing off against. It also plays excellently with multiple players. The theme is also fantastic and feels more than just slapped on, but actually drives some of the cards and mechanics. 

After playing more, this is merely the entryway to the great game. I've upped my rating to a 9 to represent the entire system. The box itself remains only a 8 though. The player cards introduced are generally pretty good and many are still very usable in the expanded card pool, but many are just garbage. And you really do need a second core set to get more copies of many cards including stalwarts like Unexpected Courage and Steward of Gondor. The pre constructed decks they include in the box are bad though. Deckbuilding is pretty much required. The quests included in the box are fine but largely underwhelming. The first one is merely okay and present no challenge beyond the first few games. The second one is pretty good and is a good quest to test decks again. The third one is extremely hard, especially for a solo player. 

Quests: 7/10

Player Cards: 9/10

RATING: 6
I've only played it the once, but that one time really didn't leave me wanting to play it again and again.  I'll give it another go, but I strongly suspect that my disinterest in the game will not be dispelled.

The problem with it is twofold; firstly it just didn't feel very interesting - although I would have to accept that this could simply be down to a lack of familiarity combined with the fact that we were playing the very first (and therefore the very easy) quest.

The second problem is more fundamental;  it managed to feel neither particularly fun nor particularly tense, but most of all it didn't feel anything at all like LOTR.  Compare and contrast with the War of the Ring - a game so dripping with theme that the box gets soggy.  In the LCG, you're concerned with entirely abstract matters like threat levels, wound tokens, questing points (or whatever they were called); it'd be a simple enough job to retheme the LCG to almost anything.  You'd possibly get away with not changing many of the names, as most of the people and places in the LCG barely rate a mention in the source material.

So it's not that the game is bad; it's just that it failed to engage me on pretty much any level.  Glad I didn't buy a copy.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.2
The Core Set has all you need to play, true, but consider it more like a "demo", and not a good one at that - the card pool being too limited, IMHO, to give a good idea of the game without frustrating the players. This is almost universally recognised, now, as a bad decision by FFG (and a reason for the low score given on BGG to the base game). Opinions vary about how much Core sets you need, but my suggestion is two. 

Whatever the case, try the secondary markets until you get three copies of each card in the Core set (which is the maximum number allowed in a deck for a given card). An alternative is to "share the burden" with a regular gaming friend willing to buy his/her own copy of the Core set to merge with yours. This will both help you to enjoy the quests contained in the Core and, should you decide to continue, with the first cycle of AP; some support cards are so good ("Stewart of Gondor" comes readily to mind) that you want to have three copies of them in your deck just to increase your probability to draw one. It is also a good way to learn which cards look essential but are actually turds - no matter how many combos you try with them. At this point you will understand why this is truly one of the best card games ever designed.

The game system is clean, easy to learn and difficult to master. Other strengths are the thematic cards and the quests: if you get hooked you will not have enough (the Core set offers only three quests). The storytelling factor is strong, and the art fantastic. This game simply oozes Tolkien, and should be a must-have for all who love his works even if they don't normally like card games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
You need to invest quite a bit of money to give some variety to your deck. The core game in solo mode is quite bad, but with a friend it can be fun.

RATING: 8
This ones tough. While I DO love this game and enjoy playing it, it can be REALLY hard to try and "keep up with" I am so behind on the releases. The good news is there is no need to keep up. Just play the core set til you are board and then pick up a pack. There is YEARS worth of play in this game. Play at your own pace and just enjoy it.

The game is hard and one must find synergies amongst the different cards to overcome the quests and monsters, yet it feels rewarding when one wins.

Since I play solo games mostly, the game rules work quite well.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I don't get to play this multiplayer as much as I'd like but the inter-sphere strategizing that takes place is amazing. Another interesting facet for me is that the top-notch artwork seems to borrow more from descriptions in the text than the way characters and locations were portrayed in the movies.

Pros:
+ Best solo play on the market, if you don't mind the difficulty.
+ Deep deck building possibilities.
+ Co-op card game, unique!
+ Great replay value.
+ Gorgeous artwork.
+ Lord of the Rings theme!
+ Standard FFG quality.

Neutral:
[b]o[/b] Encounter deck is very wishy washy, adding a heavy luck element to the game.
[b]o[/b] LCG format is less expensive than a CCG but still quite expensive. But you CAN spend what you want and still get a pretty full experience.

Cons:
- Storage and organization for all those cards can be a pain.
- Scales very, very badly. Solo is incredibly hard, 3+ players is incredibly easy. Many quests are nigh-on-impossible to solo.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
6/15/11  Have played two games with my wife - both have been really enjoyable.  

While at first blush the game has seemed quite difficult even on the introductory quest, my guess is that with experience (and more card options over time) that it will become easier to play.  Both our games have been very tense - I felt we had a chance to win or lose up until the very end (we won the second time, lost the first).

There are several aspects of this game that I enjoy.  First, the artwork on the cards is very nice and fun to look at while holding them in your hand.  While not of utmost importance to a game, games that look nice are easier to attract potential players to play with.  I find the "shadow" mechanism a neat idea as well.  Due to the fact that you are never exactly sure what you will be up against, you are constantly having to weigh decisions.  Do you quest with two heroes leaving one for defense?  Will the defender be able to deal with the threat or will the shadow card make him more than you bargained for?

It took a little while to get used to the fact that defenders don't deal damage back to the attackers (maybe thats due to my history with Magic) but its starting to sink in.  Its agonizing trying to decide who to send on the quest, who to leave to defend, and who to leave in reserve to go on the offensive.

Great card game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9.5
LoTR LCG scratches the deck construction itch within a story-telling narrative set in Middle Earth.

A self-contained experience that is playable straight out of the box, and allows for viable deck-construction providing a wide spectrum of different playing experiences that is expandable via Adventure Packs, Big Box Sets, and Saga Expansions.

Throw in excellent, thematic art-work, with canonical flavour text, quests that provide a challenging playing experience, as well as two different modes of play - solo and co-operative - and you have a deeply rich, thematic, cerebral experience.

RATING: 8
As a solo card game it is hard to beat, there is so much depth to it that if it hooks you there are hundreds of hours of play time just in this box.

The art is rich and the game play is very smooth. My main complaint is that to get the most out of it you need to expand it, which could cost a lot of money and for gamer's on a budget that is a real issue. I picked up a few packs at the start when it first came out but quickly found that to unlock the true deck building options I would need to keep buying packs as they came out.

I would not hesitate to recommend the core game to anyone as it is excellent and if you do fully invest this could be a 9 or a 10 for some people.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Super solo game
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This game is quite fun. It is co-operative (or solo, that distinction is fuzzy for this sort of game). Each player has their own heros and deck of cards (you can construct your own like Magic and CCGs) which they play against a deck which forms the quest.
Essentially each round you divide your resources between questing, defending against attacks and killing bad guys. You have to quest to advance the plot, you have to do the other two to survive long enough for that to matter.
The central mechanics are very straight forward but there are sufficient phases and different classes of cards for the CCG style element to come into play. A caveat, this is defintiely CCG co-operative and not deck building (like Dominion). You come to this with a deck you have fine tuned and then you play that deck as is.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Played a couple of time but was put off over the requirement to deck build each scenario.

RATING: 7
This is a good game, but it has some fairly sizeable flaws.  If you are using the standard decks that you are supplied with in the core set then you'll really struggle with some quests - one of the core decks (tactics) is arguably useless in solo for all but the first quest.  There is a lot of luck involved, some plays you will get a nice trickle of locations and bad guys, other times you'll just get flattened with location after location or swamped with a few 'special' guys in a row. On the plus side it's quick, good solo, and pretty addictive.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
After my first play of this game, I was very impressed. I won the first game so my initial rating of 9 was solid, but I thought it would go down.

I have played a few more games, all solo, and this game is still a solid 9 for me in that area. I still have 2 player games and expansions, not to mention actually building my own deck.

So far, i am loving this game and I don't think my rating of 9 will go down. I keep wanting to play this over and over.... that's a good thing.

Notes: the game was a little daunting at first. The unique style of LCG took a bit to get the hang of it. Watching a video here on BGG helped me understand the game flow. After that it was just a matter of doing and looking up as I went along. Well worth the effort.

11.15.13 I have been revisting the game in solo mode. this is still the wonderful solid game. I will probably get some more expansion desks. Still a 9 for me.

5.12.15 and I have started playing again. Beat the first two scenarios solo, but got a friend to help in two players to beat all three. Won the first scenario with two players and will finish the other two.

RATING: 6.5
I often feel like this game plays me rather than the other way around.  It's "fiddly," meaning that there are a lot of moving pieces to keep track of while you're playing the game.  I realize this is necessary so that the game can be flexible enough to keep adding new scenarios and new cards, but it's hard to be immersed while doing all of the maintenance and keeping track of how many Y's should happen when X occurs, etc.  Legendary has shown that it is possible to have a great deal of variety without being overwhelming.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
[b]Thoughts As A New Solo Player:[/b]
There are a lot of rules nuances and things to keep track of. I've played several games and watched several play-throughts and I'm still missing and forgetting things.  I had to write my own player aid to keep track.

It's REALLY HARD to get started when you are new to the game.  So much so, in fact, that it is actually frustrating me to the point of dreading playing it. Here's why:

To do well I have to build a deck and to build a deck I need to know the cards.  But to know the cards, I have to play them and to play them I have to build a deck (chicken and egg problem here).  The only other option I have is to use the 'decks' they mention in the rulebook which are not decks, they are just all the cards from the same sphere. Those 'decks' are designed to be played with two players (2 decks).  So as I play with those 'decks' solo (with only 1 deck), I lose over and over.... and am forced to play the same scenarios ad nauseum without success (no rewards or 'YAY!!' moments) just to get enough experience to see what cards I should consider for the first deck I build.  My only other option is to run two decks at once while learning but that just makes the rules nuances (mentioned above) harder to manage.  It really tries my patience...  :arrrh: :shake:


Going to try [url=https://hallofbeorn.wordpress.com/beorns-path/]Beorn's Path[/url] to see if it can find some fun in this game again ...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Played 8 games solitaire one handed. I've now transitioned to playing solitaire two handed.

I enjoy this game, but deck building is something I'm not used to. As a Tolkien fan, I want to play decks that are thematic. I don't enjoy building decks & heroes that don't fit into the canon. But I'm not in a hurry to spend a lot of money to pick through the expansions to get there quickly. I think I'll learn more and do better if I work my way through the expansions in sequential order.

I dig the art. Storage takes some work. The instructions seemed fairly clear. I had a few errors in play, but I think I've got the general play sequence down now. The procedural game play is kind of a drag, but seems necessary since there are so many card interactions. 

Enjoying it so far, but rating it a 7. I like the game play. I love the theme.  However, because the deck building mechanic, and the need to tailor decks to each scenario acts as a minor drag for me. Also wish it wasn't so hard or expensive to build decks that are more thematic to the literature.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.6
Solo Player Value = Excellent

Two Player Value = Excellent 


For Lord of the Rings: The Card Game I could write 10 pages of glowing review and still not give the game enough praise. The game is just that well designed.

So let me say this - 

This is the best deck-building card game currently in print.

That is a big statement and true in every sense.

In fact, the best thing I can say about this game is that I have created an entire Geek List just for it. You can find it here - 

http://boardgamegeek.com/geeklist/176849/lord-rings-card-gam...

This game is sheer beauty at every step. 

The design is fantastic with wonder cooperative game play against a brilliantly brutal A.I. 

The artwork is lovely. 

The theme fits perfectly and is worked well into the game. Truly an integrated theme.

I could keep going, but I am sure my point is made.

I can only think of three drawbacks for this game. First, this is a living card game, so continually buying the new Encounter packs is essential if you want to keep going. Second, this is a true deck building game and some people do not like the deck build aspect. Third, the game is really difficult. Be prepared to lose a lot. This is frustrating for some so they stop playing. But life in Middle Earth was never easy.


Pros - 
- Absolutely brilliant in every way


Cons - 
- Deck building, living card game and the extreme difficulty could turn some away


Overall Playability = 8.6 

Design = 9
Strategy = 9
Luck = 8
Artwork & Components = 9
Use of Mechanics = 9
Time of Play = 8
Fun = 9
Innovation = 8
Analysis Paralysis = 8
Theme = 9 


[b]-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------[/b]


Lord of the Rings: Card Game has numerous expansions.  To name them all is silly because there are so many.  This is due to the living card game nature.  New expansion and Encounters continue to come out on a regular basis.

Instead I think it is better to describe each type of expansion.  There are 3 types of expansions for this game that are actually part of the game and contain player cards.  While all 3 types are different they are extremely similar within their type.  There are 2 type of Expansions that exist sort of outside the game.

The first type of expansion is called an Adventure Pack.  These are small box expansions that provide a single new challenge or Encounter.  Each contains a new Hero and two new cards for each color Sphere.  These are part of a larger group called a Cycle, which is 6 Adventure Packs together.  Each Cycle is named for the general aspect of the story it encompasses.  

The second type of expansion is called Deluxe Expansions.  These are big box expansions and provide the player many new Encounters, usually 3.  Also included are many new Heroes and cards for each color Sphere.  These are stand-alone expansions that explore, in great depth, a single scene of the story.  The new cards are all based around that part of the story.

The third type of expansion is called Saga Expansions.  These are big box expansions that focus on moving the story forward.  Each Saga Expansion is actually 2 big box expansions.  Both together equal the Saga Expansion.  Each big box contains many new encounters, usually 3.  Also included are many new Heroes and cards for each color Sphere.  The new cards are all based around that part of the story.  

All 3 of those expansions in inside the game and contain player cards to aid the player.


[b]-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------[/b]


There is also a fourth type of expansion called a Print on Demand.

These are Encounters only, no Heroes or player cards, and are of extreme difficulty.  These are used for tournament play.

These are great additions to the game and good for testing your deck building abilities. 


[b]-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------[/b]


Additionally there is a fifth type of expansion called a Nightmare Deck.

Nightmare Decks are based on each of the expansions and are simply much more difficult versions of the Encounters already available.  These are Encounters only.  No Heroes or player cards.

The game is already very difficult and the Nightmare Decks are downright harsh.

These are strictly for the experienced deck builder.


[b]-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------[/b]


Got in 2012

2012 Plays = 172
2013 Plays = 74
2014 Plays = 58
2015 Plays = 12



Solo Game List - http://boardgamegeek.com/geeklist/171377/rygels-solo-game-list

Two Play Game List - http://boardgamegeek.com/geeklist/171377/item/3386906#item3386906

I can see this game lasting a long time.  With packs coming out monthly, and most likely big sets every 6-7 months, the card base will grow and so will the fun.

RATING: 10
Supports solid deckbuilding and the actual game is fun too - most decks don't seem to play themselves. The challenge is high, especially for solo, with only the first mission in the core set reasonable to complete out of the box without adding in cards from later sets. Some may not like the challenge but attempting to accomplish it for me is quite thrilling. I have not played in multiplayer yet, but the variety of outcomes by each encounter deck is sufficiently high to keep the game interesting. You can replay the same mission with the same deck many times and have very different experiences. But it definitely opens up as you expand to it and dip into deckbuilding - not recommended if you aren't interested in that aspect of the game.

Zamora. Con el primer ciclo completo del Bosque Viejo
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Here are my problems with the game. When playing solo you're almost expected to have two decks to make use Ranged, Sentinel, etc. The LCG model is streets ahead of the CCG one but it's still expensive, and content can be hard to find. FFG's core box is on the only borderline enough -- I partially solved this by having AHLCG-style decks of 33 with no more than 2 copies per card (unfortunately the box only gives you 1 of some cards). The difficulty swings around wildly and you often have to build your deck for the scenario (luckily, still fun for me).

As you can see, my problems are mostly exterior to the gameplay itself, which is amazing. And if you love this game as I do you will work through all that other stuff. Once you've spent hours figuring out and organising your cards and building your deck, the game is fast and relentless. And punishing. My problem here is that if you don't get your engine running fast enough you will be overrun. But it doesn't really feel unfair.

The choice between this and AHLCG comes down to theme, and maybe availability. I love both in different ways.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
not very accessible Narrative Co-op 

What a money pit! But I continue to gleefully throw money into it, when faced with a product as quality as this one. Such art, such comboing, such innovative use of the quest mechanic for vastly different game experiences.

At last, my competitive M:TG skills can be put to use serving the greater good! Saving all of Middle Earth! Best deck construction game out there, bar none, IMO.

I've only just completed the dwarves one (2nd cycle), so I have some great adventuring ahead. I play each one a bunch of times. My favorites so far were the river Anduin from the base set, as well as the climbing the mountain one in the dwarf cycle. Watcher in the Water story gets a special nod as well! Such fantastic stories created here.

RATING: 8

Swapped, because i didn't played it that much. For solo i like Mage Knight more.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
We picked up this game when it was released, back in 2011. The first impressions were terrible: really slow game play, to many things to consider, rules really bad written (not that they were obscure, but the information was - and still is - extremely poorly organized). We played a couple of games, and then we quit. We tried again the following year, and we quit again. During 2014, we tried again. The theme was so hugely appealing to us that we decided to enter this game in the our 2014 goals, and we forced ourselves to play more. The result was that we finally "broke the ice" and learned to love it. We played more than 100 plays between August and December 2014, so that I decided to start commenting on each of the adventures and what are the problems that could present.

Anyhoo, first of all: the game. It has a steep learning curve: basically you characters need to be exhausted to perform an action, but these actions are both questing (you send characters to the quest to score successes and progress towards the victory conditions), defending from your enemies attacks and finally attacking the enemies. So that you need to decide carefully who's supposed to do what. And clearly, you need a certain buffer of freedom since the encounter deck you play against has some bad surprises for you and you need to be prepared if something goes wrong.

But the game is also "constant": every time you play the quest X, you have to face the very same deck. This allows players to improve: you go on a quest, you discover how it's structured and what are the problems and the easy points and you can consequently alter the composition of your deck to make it more effective.

The core set comes with three different quests: A Journey through Mirkwood, Journey along the Anduin and Escape from Dol Guldur, in a rampaging difficulty scale.

[b]Quest 01 - Passage through Mirkwood[/b]

[b]The quest deck[/b]
The quest deck is created through the combination of the three following decks: Passage Through Mirkwood, Spiders of Mirkwood and Dol Guldur Orcs. So that you'll have some easy locations to explore (Mountains of Mirkwood, adding one card to the staging area after travelling but rewarding you with a "draw 5 keep 1 card after exploring", Enchanted Stream, not allowing you to draw cards, and the Necromancer's Pass, forcing you to exhaust a hero to travel there, are the most difficult locations; others have benefical effects, so really, the quest deck is easy on this side) and some very basic enemies to defeat (mostly spiders and orcs).

The quest is built upon three stages; after you pass the second one, you've to randomly select the third stage to end the quest (more stuff to explore or enemies to fight) and add a little more variety.

The quest is really easy, yet not so easy. It's a good introductory quest that should be played over and over again to understand the basics of the game (when to push on the questing phase, when to defend, when to attack, how to spend resources and stuff), and it's a good way to test new decks. It can be won in two rounds, so, when you manage to do that, you are on something.

[b]Enemy cards in detail[/b]
As said, it's easy but not so easy: there are a couple of cards that can mess up the things pretty fast (especially with a standard deck built out of the core set cards): Ungoliant Spawn has a nasty attack (5), a load of hits (9), a nasty shadow effect (+4 threat, +8 if undefended), a hideous when revealed effect (-1 Willpower to all questing characters). Not a game breaker per se, but there are some other additional difficulties (Hummerhorns, Chieftain Ufthak, the Dol Guldur beastmaster) that can be problematic, and if chained, can result in the game ending quickly. This just to say that the quest is a good quest, even tho it's on the easy side of the quest deck: you can play it several times even if you're not a noob any longer and still enjoy it.


[b]Quest 02 - Journey down the Anduin[/b]

[b]The quest deck[/b]
The quest deck is created through the combination of the following four decks: Journey down the Anduin, Sauron's Reach, Dol Guldur Orcs and Wilderlands. As expected, the difficulty of the quest rampages quite a bit. You keep on measuring yourself against the toughest orcs you met in quest 1 (Chieftain Ufthak and the Dol Guldur beastmasters) but now you have some even deadlier enemies to deal with. Hill trolls will provide quite a challenge: not only their attack is heavy (6), but they are also quite resistant to damage (3 armor, 9 hits: this means a single attack need to deal 12 damage to clear out a single troll), and when they attack they convert the excess combat damage directly into a threat increase. This means you cannot think about systematically champ blocking those dudes here, otherwise you'll lose the game for exceeding the max threat threshold. And there are two of them in the deck. Additionally, some more nastieness is coming from other enemies: Goblin Snipers (you cannot optionally engage them if there are other enemies in the staging area, plus if at the end of the round they are still in the staging area, then they automatically wound one character / player), the Marsh Adder (after resolving their attack, you have to increase your threat by 1) and some enemies featuring the "surge" keyword (after revealing those from the encounter deck, you have to reveal an additional card). Even if enemies having "surge" are kinda weak in this deck, they keep on pumping card in the staging area and this can result in some disatrous consequences, especially when stage 2 of the quest is to be resolved (see later). Locations coming with this deck are dangerous too: from the Brown Land that contributes with a +5 threat while in the staging area to the East Bight (only 1 threat, but you need 6 progress markers to pass it) to the Gladden Fields (+3 threat, 3 progress markers to pass, and at the end of the round, if it's the active location, then you have to raise your threat by 2 in stead of 1).
So, you need to pay attention to this one.


[b]Quest and strategy in detail[/b]
The quest stages' theme is really sound and well presented, with the first stage requiring you to get rid of a hill troll to reach a small raft to journey down the Anduin, the second stage where you're hunted by enemies following your tracks along the shores of the river and the final stage where you're ambushed by orcs and friends as soon as you reach the land. There are many difficult issues throughout the adventure:

- first of all, you start the quest with a hill troll in play, so that you need a) a heavy damaging combo with possibly a Feint card to elude the troll's first attack or b) a forest snare to immobilize the guy and nullify his attacks; other combos work well too (for instance, sneak attacking Gandalf or Descendant of Thorondor, or using direct damage cards to actually bypass the natural armor of the guy and start dealing quickly damage), but you need to have a plan and some cards to realize it very quickly, otherwise you can lose the quest during stage 1. Not to mention that, in case you have the second troll showing off during round 2, well, most of the times it's a good bye

- then, while journeying along the Anduin (stage 2) enemies don't engage you unless you optionally engage them (thematically, it's great: enemies cannot enter the river to battle you, but you can decide where to stop the raft and kill quickly a couple of them); this could sound fantastic, but actually it's not. For two different reasons: first of all, all the enemies in the staging area contribute to the threat you have to pass in order to place successes on the quest, and this stage of the quest requires 16 progress marker to be placed, which is rather a high number; then, as soon as you pass stage 2, you add two more cards to the staging area / player: these represent the "ambush" your enemies have prepared for you, so that if you have an overcrowded staging area, you'll be overwhelmed by enemies at this point. Even though many are easy, their mere number, and the eventual surges you had to resolve, could result in the situation slpping out of your hands. Additionally, some locations can clog the staging area even further.

So, to sum this up: you need some good combat combos, a couple of cards able to neutralize your enemies attacks for some time, a couple of good questers to move quickly through the stages of the adventure and in the end have enough allies in play to survive the horde storming on you as soon as you enter stage 3. Clearly, it's not the most difficult quest ever, but it's a real quest, that requires you to think about the deck you build and will probably require some tries to pass it.


[b]Quest 03 - Escape from Dol Guldur[/b]

[b]The encounter deck[/b]
The encounter deck is created through the combination of the following three decks: Escape from Dol Guldur, Spiders of Mirkwood and Dol Guldur Orcs. Again, the difficulty is supposed to rise a bit; not because of the quest per se (Journey down the Anduin is by far a more difficult quest), but because it's a quest with quite some different mechanics, and it requires some time to figure out how to deal with it. Anyhoo, let's look at the cards in the deck. Spiders of Mirkwood and Dol Guldur Orcs should be well known by the players because they were already used in previous quests from the core set; what's new is the Escape deck. First of all, there are many cards featuring the keyword "Doomed X": whenever a card with such a keyword is revealed, you have to raise your threat by X. Additionally, other cards have "surge" (hence, they trigger another card); in some cases ("Endless caverns"), you have both. Finally, this deck adds three brand new enemies: the Nazgul of Dol Guldur (someone you need to be ready to encounter)and the Dungeon Jailor (2 copies of him in the deck): not the strongest orc in the mix, but someone that becomes fastidious because he could (under certain circumstances) force you to reshuffle objectives (special encounters you need to control to advance through the quest) back into the deck. The new enemies are not particularly strong per se, but remember you have Chieftain Ufthak, and Ungoliant Spawn and Hummerhorns in the mix, so that if more than one of these cards is triggered at once, especially in the early steps of the game, well, winning becomes difficult.

[b]The quest[/b]
During this quest, players are asked by Galadriel to investigate in the surroundings of the tower of Dol Guldur, to find out what's going on there. While the party is approaching the tower, they got ambushed by a band of Orcs, capturing one of the Heroes and taking him prisoner to Dol Guldur. His companions need to venture inside the tower, using three items (the Shadow Key, the Dungeon Torch and Gandalf's Map) properly to find their way into the tower, rescue the lost friend and then leave before it's too late.

So that, immediately, at the beginning of the game, the three items ("Objectives") are revealed and added to the staging area, and three encounters are attached to them, representing their guardians or the places they are hidden into. Additionally, the Nazgul of Dol Guldur is placed nearby, yet not in play (for now, at least). This done, one of the Heroes is randomly selected and turned facedown, representing the prisoner, buried in some cell in Dol Guldur. The first step of the quest requires the heroes to claim one of their objectives (and place 9 progress markers on the quest) to move to stage 2. Stage 2 represents the core of the challenge: by placing at least one progress marker on the quest card, the prisoner is freed and returned to the game, but the Nazgul enters the staging area. He's strong (3 defense, 9 hit points) and with a terrific special attack (if you resolve a shadow effect while attacking with the Nazgul, you remove a character from the game); sure, you can leave him in the staging area if you're good at controlling threat, but he contributes with +5 to the total threat while questing, so that it's difficult to leave him forever. Passing to stage three requires the other two objectives to be claimed (as well as 15 progress markers) and then finally to pass stage three you need 7 progress markers and have the Nazgul defeated.

As you can see, no easy quest, with many factors to consider to find out the perfect timing for power questing / defending / attacking; additionally, remember that stages 1 and 2 forces players not to play more than 1 ally (in total, not per player!) / rounds, so that any strategy like "playing hundreds of champ blockers" simply doesn't work.

Some things to do:

- first of all, you need to quest quickly through stage one. Not too quickly, otherwise the Nazgul could become a problem, but quickly enough since the game is hard and you play with one hero less (this condition is a lot less problematic with higher player counts: 4p feels the lack on one hero not so devatasting, while playing 1p it's a matter of life and death)

- you need something to deal with the Nazgul (Feint, Forest Snare, anything disabling him from attacking too many times); direct damage cards work perfectly at this moment (sneak attacking Gandalf or Descendant of Thorondor, or using Swift Strike, or some Gondorian Spearmen, these cards here come in handy); possibly, try to eliminate the Nazgul during stage 2 of the quest, so that as soon as you reach stage 3, you can powerquest through that stage

- another thing to consider is the possibility of having location locks (i.e., too many locations in the staging area, hindering you from advancing in the quest and resulting in games lost quickly); for this reason you need some good questers and possibly at least one copy of Northern Tracker in play

Once you manage to do these things here, you have pretty decent chances to pass.

RATING: 8
Very enjoyable play, but I would really be most interested in this as a solo game and:
1) I generally prefer solo games where you only need to play one hand, and the scenarios just don't support that much - so much of good gameplay in LOTR is dependent on getting synergy with party-members.
2) Deck-building is shockingly poorly supported in the core set, and I cannot see myself investing the kind of money needed to properly get into this game. 
Still, if my wife liked it as much as I did then I would happily jump in. The art and production values are great, to my eye.

RATING: 5
My first take on a Fantasy Flight Games' Living Card Game, with the one that I believe is the best rated here in BGG. Its mechanics are simple and work properly, but the game lacks from a "je ne sais quoi". Probably it is that the theme, despite the nice artwork and flavor texts on the cards, doesn't really integrates well with the gameplay. Everything seems artificial and pasted on, and you don't ever feel inmersed in a quest in Middle Earth, fighting for the survival of the world as you know it. Instead of that, you just find yourself adding and substracting numbers to get some chips placed over a bunch of cards. Perhaps it is only that I'm supersaturated of colaborative games, or that the fantasy setting, and particularly in Tolkien's universe, starts to feel repetitive. Maybe it is that the game doesn't grow a high level of tension, because the quests are either very easy or imposible to achieve, or perhaps is that there is nothing really innovative or engaging in the mechanics of the game. It may be that, in theory, you can develop your characters during the game adding them cards, but it ends so quickly that this possibility stays in the paper. But most likely is a sum of everything I've said and even more things that I just can barely imagine.

RATING: 8

Now that there ARE many expansions available, I was able to trade for a lot and am enjoying it thoroughly without feeling limited or obligated as I did before.

This is a really good somewhat thematic resource management game system. It's all about risk/reward, the ability to craft a deck around specific scenario's challenge.

RATING: 8
My first real card game after PokÃ©mon back in 2000. 
Rulebook didn't feel very clear about the gameplay. This might have been due to my inexperience with cardgames. 

LotR - LCG is a complex game and I have the feeling that it's near unplayable if not played in easy mode. 
We might be doing something wrong though. ;) 
Since then, I've read many reviews claiming a single core-set isn't enough to get you through the game on your own, so it seems like expanding is the way to go. 

Co-op was also a new thing but the more games I played, the more interested I have become in the concept of games without player-conflict. 

Because of the difficulty, this game got shelved for a while. Now that I've become more experienced with board games in general (and Tolkien lore as well) I feel like picking this one up again. The co-op nature of the game, combined with the fact that the collection has been growing steadily makes me want to try this game more and really learn it. 

The art style of this game is superb! It's one of the things that really attracted me to the game, as the more grim style of the art felt more like the books than the movies did. 

Rating might go up, this one is based on just a single core play through. 

Includes the entire [i]Shadows of Mirkwood[/i] cycle.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This game has been a big hit with us.  I usually play with my boys (ages 10 and 13) actually.  I like the game for several reasons, the game play, the lack of downtime, the art, and the play time.   The game play is engaging and requires constant attention of all players all the time.  Many moving pieces have to be accounted for when planning out your charactersâ actions, such as exploring, keeping threat low, defending, attacking, and controlling the encounter deck.  You have to balance all these needs when deciding what to allocate your characterâs limited actions to.  That requires a lot of teamwork.  The different spheres of influence have different feels and each can really contribute to adventure.  There is not much in the way of down time.  Further, the games take between 45-90 minutes (averaging about an hour), which is great for us.

The deck building aspect is fun.  It is enjoyable to try and figure out the best deck to play for the different demands in each scenario.  It is also fun trying to find good combinations of cards, both in your own deck and with other playersâ decks.  

FFG did a fantastic job with the art, capturing the Tolkien feel.  I so much prefer this sort of classic fantasy art to what is found in WoW, Warhammer, Manga, or anything like that.  My boys love the game, and one of them is constantly asking me to play.

I like the living card game model quite a bit.  I like getting new cards and scenarios regularly to keep the game fresh.  I also like that each expansion includes a complete set of fixed play cards.  There is no randomness.  I have no interest in the ccg model.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5
summer, 2011:  Currently rating this an 8 after over a dozen plays, both solitaire and 2-player.  At first, I was a little disappointed with the "simplicity" of the game.  I just couldn't see the longevity of the system.  Build a strong deck, try and beat a published scenario, get frustrated with some bad luck, win after some good luck, get bored, wait for next expansion, repeat.  My opinion has evolved.  I am now buying a 2nd core set because I believe in the system that much.  The deck-building possibilities are not fully realized yet, but they will be - and they will be great fun.  Having new Encounter (read, Mordor) cards come out every month or so will be thoroughly exciting ("I wonder how my Leadership/Spirit deck will do against THIS expansion...").  Plus, playing 2-player really does lend itself to deep and difficult decision-making, classic risk vs. reward stuff.  A strong system.  I'll re-visit this rating in a year to see how I feel then.

winter, 2012: Upping my rating to an 8.5.  I adore this game.  Have been playing it obsessively single-player for the past 2 weeks.  Admittedly, the Mirkwood quests have been mostly lame - but the new heroes and player cards create wonderful new deck-building opportunities, and the Khazad-dum expansion brings 3 fantastic quests to the mix.  

Spring, 2014:  Into it again, and upgrading to a 9.  This is a fantastic game.  Bought the Black Riders saga set, now buying a couple more Dwarrowdelf adventure packs before I dip into Numenor.  I've probably put more hours into this game than any other on my shelf over the past 2 years.

Summer 2016:  Downgrading slightly to an 8.5.  I think I'm finally over my LoTR card game addiction.  My last time pulling it out was unsatisfying, as it felt like the scenarios were insanely difficult and I only won if my deck happened to "go off" in just the right way.  I think the power/difficulty curve of this game has just gone too far for solitaire players.  If I played 2 player consistently, I would still dig it.  But for now, I'm retiring my collection.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9

RATING: 1
A friend's copy with some expansions included. We played 2 decks he put together. 

As far as co-ops go it works. The fact the everybody has their own deck means that while you're working together and deciding on objectives, each is playing their own game and deciding how to meet those objectives. This was quite neat. 

Theme works. Not a huge fan of co-ops or LCGs as a product idea, but this was neat. Co-op with deck building? (in traditional CCG sense) Why not. 

Edit - not interested in playing it again (co-ops not my thing) and this one is a money sink as well. Whatever. Hence rating 2.0 (will not play again)

Edit - meh, why does this need to exist? (when I ask this question it means the game gets 1.0 rating) LCG the co-op whoop dee doo. Bollocks.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Provisional rating.

I'm not sure if I'm missing something but the game is highly uninvolved and merely an exercise in game mechanics. Draw cards, play cards, use heroes and other cards to deal with enemies and work your way through the deck. Rinse and repeat.

Can you truly call this a co-op game if it's mostly multiplayer solitaire?

The artwork is great but if the mechanics doesn't lend itself to the theme, what's the point?

As is typical of some FFG games, the base game isn't enough to give you longevity (three quests? Come on, would it hurt to add another 9 cards for six quests in total??!) and you'll need to either buy a second base set and expansion packs in order to expand your gaming experience. For example, Dominion and Race for the Galaxy offers better card-gaming bang for buck.

Will clock a few more plays before finalising review.

Update:

The steps of the game feels very clunky and procedural.

While I understand the 'tactics' behind combat (defending and attacking), it would seem more elegant to have combat as one fluid step, with damage resolved simultaneously ala MtG.

The game just gets bogged down in its mechanics: card flipping, token placement etc. If you want a game that captures the LoTR feel and spirit, look elsewhere (try the first CCG or even the Decipher CCG).

Nice game, full of Tolkien theme, mostly marvelous artwork. Unfortunately not very flexible gameplay. The deckbuilding aspect is not as developed as you might wish. Becomes a bit same-same after longer play sessions.
