One small thing, that is a personal nerd-choice rather than criticism, is that i LOVE the way Gandalf is a passing ally, who appears, drops some pain, and disappears. But those are infrequent. Most scenarios are enjoyable and provide a great variety of experiences.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I don't like the questing mechanic, as players tend to math out their willpower commitment. It boils down to a game of resource allocation, often making me forget that I am playing a Lord of the Rings game. I also don't like that each game starts out difficult and gets progressively easier, which is sometimes counteracted by having the players draw a stupid amount of encounter cards that deal random damage. Also defending with only one character, which is then exhausted without being able to do something, and then attacking back with different characters is a strange way to represent combat.

This game is also extremely luck based. In a 2-player game, you are drawing from three decks (the two player decks and the encounter deck), hoping that you're not getting crushed by too many monsters / treachery cards / locations. The shadow effect cards add a big deal to the randomness by sometimes having no effect but sometimes killing your firstborn. The location cards do nothing more than lengthening the playtime, showing a beautiful drawing with a completely unrelated travel effect that is there to annoy you.

Oh, and three scenarios in the base game (from which one  sucks and one is incredibly difficult) are not enough. I hate being forced to buy those stupid Adventure Packs for additional scenarios, when I am not particularly interested in deckbuilding. (Un)fortunately, it seems that I'm immune to this supposedly addictive CCG-like business model.

Overall this game is a big disappointment.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3.5
Procedural number allocation puzzle.  The paper thin theme exposes just how managerial the whole thing is, you might as well be allocating employees to odd jobs.  Where your "decisions" are based on sending them on gigs that they are best suited to be hired for.  In LotR:TCG if your employee, I mean, ally is good at questing, but nothing else, it doesn't take a CEO of a fortune 500 fantasy company to know that you should send them out to quest.

When you do get to actually use characters, their powers can be fun, but there are some obnoxious cards in the deck that cripple your powers.  I never understand why designers think it is a good idea to strip the fun bits out of your game.  It's like how every once in a while some schlub comic book writer thinks they are a genius by taking their superheroes powers away.  Yay.

For a game that is supposedly theme driven there is no story here, either thematically or within the game.  There is little difference between the beginning, the middle, and the end other than the order of particular cards that had come out.  Mostly, you do the same allocation over and over again.  The game works just fine, but it doesn't seem to need you as a player to be a participant, the choices seem to play themselves. Blech.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Wow..That sums up what I want to say about this game. I've always been a fan of card games, and of course, I'm a huge fan of the Lord of the Rings universe.  When the new game was announced, I was immediately interested, but wondered if it would be as good and in depth as previous card games (I was heavily into the Lord of the Rings trading card game).

To my relief the Lord of the Rings The Card Game satisfied.  It's challenging, it's coop, it's got deck building, it's got strategies and you're always faced with tough decisions.

As Drakkenstrike said, it accomplishes the task of emotionally attaching itself to you in the same way that the Lord of the Rings trading card game did.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A remarkably deep game in many aspects. 

First off, there is significant strategy even before you start playing, in determining the construction of your deck and the heroes to use with it. Which sphere(s) of influence will work best with this scenario? What did I do wrong last time with my deck that I can improve this time? What will work best with the heroes I've chosen? 

It's incredibly fun just sitting back and deciding how to assemble the optimal deck, and we haven't even involved actual game play yet. In fact, what makes this game so interesting is there are pretty much two game "modes" to it.... the first is the deck-building mode, the second is the game mode. Both are very fun in their own ways.

Now for the actual gameplay.... for a card-based co-op, there is a LOT to this game, both in depth and variety. Multiple scenarios, lots of difficult decisions, and lots of unexpected wrinkles thrown at the player. Do I exhaust this character to travel and maintain the threat level, or do I hang back this turn and try to finally vanquish this spider gnawing on us, delaying the journey and raising the threat? Should I sacrifice an ally to keep my heroes healthy? Should I spend my resources on this weapon here, or this other ally here, or save up for Gandalf next turn because I REALLY need to lower my threat level....

This has to be my best purchase of the year, and I know this game will get LOTS of play time.

RATING: 6
While clearly not a bad game, this just wasn't the game for me. Too much trial and error deck building made me feel less like a hero and more like a nerd who had repeatedly failed and learned what the game wanted me to do in a very linear way. The complete opposite of a sandbox experience. 

So many people look online for what decks to use. What is the point in that? The whole fun of the game is working out what works and what doesn't! If you deck build with decks that will win of course you'll be 'good' at the game because there's no skill needed past the point of preparing a deck.

After the first play I fell in love with it. It scratches the itch from Magic the Gathering I've had for years now. Building your decks, customizing your adventure, your experience.

Love this as a solo game and also surprisingly well played as a 2p game. Admittedly it seems tough at first and building a deck is not that easy with limited cardpool, but I guess that will go away when I get some expansions into account.

For a 1 hour game it brings a great storytelling, engaging gameplay, tough choices, deck construction and great tension. I never feel like I'm bored while playing.

Also love the artwork and am a fan of Tolkien's work, so I absolutely love this game.

RATING: 5
Based on ten solitaire game think it will be much much better as a co-op. V easy to play, well worn CCG mechanics against a system driven enemy.

Now played multi player and and just longer and more complicated. The interactions between players decks was interesting up to a point however it just feels like a more convoluted Pandemic - i.e its a reseting puzzle with loads of minute text on cards and the name of the game is using these details to solve a puzzle. If you like this kind of thing fine but to me its a lot of effort to defeat a random deck of cards - at least in DOTR there is a board, side quests and lots of minis to create some atmosphere. In Arkham you can choose which random part you'd like to chance - here its just straight off the top of the deck

Lots to admire and an admirable solo/coop version of a CCG. However, my 10 games (ceteribus paribas) have come down to the luck of the draw.

Even in a co-op this will be the case - though the ability of the players to make bad choices will add variability. Unless theres something great in the expansions i probably wont be playing this much further

I wonder why this was not implemented as player v player taking it in turns to be the bad guys? Please FF don't give this treatment to Star Wars LCG!


I hope the co-op side makes the game shine, otherwise why not play a computer game?

This will be interesting to see how it develops, especially the deck building side as I feel this was a very poor start. It needed more scenarios and also some multi mana decks out of the box

RATING: 8.5
Only a few plays until now (with a friend's copy; got the game for christmas), but the integration of the theme is so well done and the coop mechanics so engaging that it might quickly become a favorite. Update 06-24-2016 : With a few more games in, the cogs of the game start to disappear and concede the stage to the adventure. Every game is a story of cruel choices and dire consequences. And winning. Winning becomes meaningful again with the LotR LCG.

EDIT 2017-04-10 : Many more plays now (very few have been logged though), with much more to come. This game is like a good red wine, the more it ages, the better it becomes. The new cards and mechanics added with every new cycle keep the game fresh while also building on its solid foundations. You want a card game to last you a very long time ? Here it is. Just want to try the core box and enjoy it without having to buy a gazillion expansions ? Look for Ninjadorg's 6 quests here on BGG. They should be included in the box. They are THAT good.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Update.  Ok the game is absolutely worthless solo playing right out of the box with any of the decks.  Frustrating and stupid, but with nice, if frequently recycled, art.  Where the game shines is once you start trying to customize the decks to account for what you've seen in the scenarios (by failing horribly).  And especially once you start being able to build lots more variations as you add expansions.  Based on this I have to say the game design is terrible, not because there's not a pretty good game in there, but because it will have limited appeal as people buy the game and are disgusted with the stupid arbitrary mess--your decisions will be worthless in working toward the end-goal, and your only hope is that the scenarios cards come up just right...nothing is in your control.  The first people buying the game were mostly deck-constructors who were familiar with the normal FFG LCGs.  They were very comfortable jumping immediately into creating their own decks when they saw issues in the first scenario.  As more people bought into the glowing reviews, the more of these that went immediately onto trade lists and into math trades because the game (and the rulebook) didn't prepare them for the real process of the game.  Now this is mitigated almost completely by playing two players since you then have a good mix of character abilities even within the confines of the pre-packaged decks.  Anyone playing two players to start with would be surprised by how little control a solo player has with a pre-packaged deck.

So I'm going to leave the rating the same, with the caveat that the game is much better if you're willing and able to put in the time to construct your own decks (and use at least 3 gandalfs).  And it gets much MUCH better if you construct your own decks AND also buy at least a couple of the expansion packs for more building variety.

Upshot is 6 for most non-CCG players (and that's even a bit high probably)
7 for anyone comfortable with deck construction
8 for a deck constructor willing to spend another $25 for a couple more expansions.

preliminary rating based on just a couple solo plays with just the base set.  This game is painfully random.  It *may* work better if you mix a couple decks, but it seems like that might also dilute the resource acquisition too much.  The Tactics deck is fundamentally broken played by itself--unless your draws from the encounter deck are extremely lucky, you have so little willpower that a win is impossible.  Now, I was just playing a single Gandalf card in the deck (as per the rules) but maybe you can have up to 3 per the tournament deck building rules?

Anyway, I tried both the tactics and the spirit deck and neither worked--the spirit deck got close, as I had just a single token left to get to complete the final quest card, but a single bad shadow card took away one of my ally cards, which left an attacker undefended, which killed my final hero.

I'll give it a few more play throughs and adjust my rating accordingly if it continues to feel excessively random, or if it feels like a player's decisions actually have some bearing on the outcome.

If it weren't for the theme which I love, it would be rated even lower and auctioned or traded immediately

RATING: 10
  EDIT-After more solo and 2 player games, this game has only gotten better. I was especally surprised by the depth of possible combinations and the interactions with multiple playings, would like to have more regular expansion releases. 
SECOND EDIT--I have played through all the quests in the Return To Mirkwood Cycle and the game has not gotten stale or overpowered. The old cards from the core set are still heavily used, and evey new expansion injects fresh ideas and combinations into the system. To me the game is at the right balance--I usually win about 50% of the time with the right decks. How many games out there are just as fun solo as multi-player? This is only the second game I have ever rated a 10.

RATING: 7.5
Good game, but the choices are often too obvious. Pair the purple and red in the first deck and the other player select the best cards from the green and blue. The base box is relatively easy to finish, and the replayability fails. By purchasing expansion boxes, you can extend the limitations, but I don't feel that the quests provide the similar fun when replaying. I like the LotR theme, but this game disappointed me, I expected much more. The Android: Netrunner core box has the same price tag and simply overwhelms this game regarding fun and replayability. As for a cooperative game, I suggest another one.

RATING: 7
Review: https://boardgamegeek.com/thread/772773/7-out-10-two-reviews-price-one
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.3
This game has a steep learning curve. In the beginning I was losing half a dozen games in a row before logging my first win.
But this is good!
Because otherwise I would not have been motivated to play the game as often as I have done.
With time you get to learn the strengths and weaknesses of the different strategies. Deck-building is absolutely required and provides as much fun as playing the actual game.
What I really like about the design is the fact that the scenarios require different solutions every time. A deck that works for one scenario is horrible versus another.

LotR the Card Game has many parallels to Magic: the Gathering. The most notable difference, though, is that it is cooperative/solitaire. If you are a die-hard M:tG tournament player this might turn you off. But if you just like the deck-building and the Tolkien atmosphere you can't do better than this.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5

Very good theme and atmosphere, fairly engaging gameplay. AI provides a very challenging enemy - more involved then what appears at first glance.

Having now played several games co-op and solo, I definitely prefer the co-op game; solitaire is just so-so.

RATING: 9
One of the best games I own.  The only things stopping me from getting more into it are the time it takes to do the deck building and the money it takes to really invest in this system.

For the time being I am going to try to Hobbit Saga Expansions and see if my interest holds.

I just love the depth of the decisions that have to be made, the options the spheres open up, and the variety the scenarios offer. I have realized that games without scenarios feel very samey to me after a few plays.  The scenarios and being able to try different decks against them is a major plus for me.

Love the artwork and the flavor text as well.

RATING: 3
Gift from Magnus & Susanna. They played it once and didn't like it...?
It's a bad game. LotR is a great setting for a game and the designers could have made soooo much with it. They didn't. Game mechanics are dull and boring. Cards are average at best, most are dull and boring (again). It's super clear that Fantasy Flight only has one objective: they want us to buy endless amounts of extra stuff. You need two core boxes if you want to play with more than two players. You only get three intro scenarios in the core box. All is just prepped for us to spend loads of money on expansions (and there are more than 100 listed here on BGG). I hate games that require expansions to be played properly. I might just buy a few anyway, just to see if the game gets better. But until I do, my score will stay at three. With the core box only, it barely qualifies as a game.

RATING: 8

RATING: N/A
F
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Ah, the return of puzzles disguised as games! This felt exceptionally dry and whilst I can understand the purpose of 'questing' - to reduce the number of characters you have available and limit you from being able to build a massive army - it might be the least interesting thing I've ever done in a game.

I suspect that mixing the decks is the most interesting way to play. I hope it is as it was pretty dull playing with the starter sets.

Update: It *is* more interesting with mixed decks, and possibly easier too. We replayed the first 2 scenarios, that we'd lost so badly first time out and seemed to win both fairly easily. Questing is still boring and a really uninspired way to reduce the number of characters in play each round, but the game felt a lot more involved, as though the choices we'd made were actually having an impact on the outcome.

The shadow deck, whilst a good idea, is poorly implemented in scenarios where you have to kill a specific character, since that card can keep getting used as a shadows card and thus *never* come up, making the mission entirely impossible. That's pretty poor; why not just supply a separate shadow deck??

Rating up from 5 to 6.

RATING: 5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Nice art and components. The game is nice, but luck is a major factor. Half (or more) of the game consists in making your own deck: in fact, with the predefined decks you could only win in the easiest (introductory) mission.

Unfortunately, the game doesn't really have any replayability. It comes with 3 missions: one is extremely easy, one is OK and the last one is extremely difficult (I would say almost impossible with 1 player, very very hard with 2). One you've completed 3 or 4 times the second mission (the only funny one), the game is over, you need some expansion.

Sure, if you buy expansions you can buy some hours more... but that isn't replayability. Each set of cards is burned in less than 5 hours. It doesn't pay off.

Other issues: the game doesn't really scale well with the players. With one copy of the game you can only play with 1 or 2 persons, but with one is clearly harder than with 2. If you have 2 copies, you can play with 3, but then it gets much easier.

Also, it isn't clearer how you can modify the difficulty level.

RATING: 8
As LCG, the game tried to cover every possible adventures that can presented in the Middle Earth setting, some would be more enjoyable than others. I think most adventures has the cinematic feel and so 8 rating.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I'm impressed with how simple the cards are so far, compared to other LCGs.  I'm sure a few cycles down the line, cards will get more complex, but until then there is a good card base where cards are easy to understand.

Not sure how I feel about deck building though;  this seems like another game where decks build themselves.  If you want a Rohan deck, throw everything that says "Rohan" on it into the deck.  If you want an Eagle deck, ditto.

I'm also a little turned off by overpowered combos, but I have no problem avoiding them since it's a co-op game!  So far my random-deck variant is quite enjoyable and cuts out the requirement of building a deck before playing.

Still trying to get the game down to the supposed 60 minute playtime.  When I rush, I tend to forget important card effects, but sometimes the game can drag on a bit when you feel like every round is the same (you'll typically commit the same characters to questing every single round).

This might be the adventure game to stay in my collection!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
For those who like cooperative games it'll be a good one. Want to sell it, because co-op is not my cup of tea.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Very good game, quite addictive if you like solo play and/or cooperative play.
The thematic of LOTR is always present and the cards fit just perfectly the universe. If you are a LOTR fan and a card game fan, well this one is for you ;-)

With the growing number of expansions, deck building possibilities becomes infinite and the challenge never ends !

The only negative point is about the rules of the game. The global mechanics is fine, but it's just that some card or rules might sometime be ambiguous, which forces you to often check FAQ's or to ask in forums. But don't worry, there is a lot of LOTR lcg veteran in the BGG forum and they always kindly answer any question you might have ;-)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Maybe after some expansions come out I'll try it again and see if it gets better.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Rating based on a couple of two-player plays with the core set only. I liked this, but it's far more complex than other games in Fantasy Flight's living card game line, such as Call of Cthulhu or Warhammer Invasion, to the point of being a bit fiddly at times. I can see how following the progression of the adventure packs and tweaking your deck as you go could be pretty interesting, but I'm not willing to invest that much time or effort into this. I have enough cards to make a few interesting decks and will try this out with three or four players to see where this shakes out in my ratings. Update: This is definitely better with more players, and the replay value is incredibly high. A very solid game.

RATING: 8
I only have the base game.  I'm sure it gets more interesting as you add expansions.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
[-]Preliminary[/-] rating for a game that, as of now, seems impossible to defeat. I tried all decks separately now, but with none I came really close to victory. And if that's a toughness of 1, I don't want to know what toughness 4 or 7 means. I didn't play with the variant to neglect the shadow cards, but where's the fun in that? And also I doubt that would make the game any easier. If you play with the shadow-cards you can get lucky (one of the many times you have to rely on luck of the draw) to draw cards without a shadow-effect thus discarding them without them doing the harm to you they would have done as if it was a draw for the "Aufmarschzone". What really bugs me, is that you have to decide which of your characters quest, defend or attack, but the monsters do it all at once (well, they do two the three). In the "Aufmarschzone" they put a handicap on you advancing in the quest and still they have their defense values applied, even if you're happy enough to be able to attack them there (with a hero like Dunhere or maybe other cards)and once they engage you, both their defense and attack values count. And every measly forest spider is stronger than or equally strong to one of your few heroes. Also I dislike that you have to send your heroes on a quest before you draw a new card/new cards into the "Aufmarschzone". I appreciate that mechanism from a thematical point of view, sending your heroes and allies out into the wild unknown with dangers lurking out there you have no clue about yet. But in this particular case, where it seems like a fight against all odds, it turns me down even further. 
As of now the game seems unbalanced for the good of the game. It's frustratingly difficult so far.Basically you hope to get the right cards on the right time (getting only one card per turn is kind of irksome) while at the same time you have to hope the darkness draws a card/cards that don't seem fit. I'll see how it plays with two though and check again for my rating.
-------
Wheeeew- finally after the tenth game the first victory. I don't know if that's the kind of challenge I want.Especially since the victory was only a matter of luck. I drew Ungolianths brood as a shadow card. The effect of that wasn't nearly as devastating as having to fight her along with other spiders.  
-------
 Tried with two players now. It doesn't change a bit. This game feels like a video rpg in which you have to make your way to the supertough superboss about half an hour without the possibility to save the game. It's that frustrating, it's that hard. At no time during our session we felt like we were ever able to win this. I feel the the prebuilt decks aren't balanced enough, because there wasn't much we could have done different. It's all about when you draw what cards and what cards are drawn by the shadows. And I don't have much desire to be smoked by the game again, hence the lowered rating

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
So maybe I didn't quite get this game the first time around. I originally had some comments about it being too mechanical and not fun. After playing (and loving) Warhammer Quest: Adventure Card Game, I decided to revisit this game because of its similarities.

Well, the game is good. Like any LCG, it takes a little bit of work to get into, but the system is really pretty simple once you learn it. You generate some resources, put some cards into play, bring out some enemies and have combat, then do a cleanup phase and start it all over.

The solo game isn't bad, but the game seems best with two. That way, instead of trying to do everything with one deck, you can build two decks that complement each other.

RATING: 5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I think you will eventually need/want to get expansions for this. Frankly, its kind of addictive.
But the investment adds up (money, I mean), so be ready to commit. 

One thing I have liked but have not had the chance to do more with is that the newest expansions use more magic than previously.

Great art, diversity, creative quests, never a cake-walk. 

It's not a portable game unless you set out the deck you have built and just bring a single adventure with you (say when traveling).

You need to know deck building so if that's not your thing you'll get smashed because the game is hard with a capital "H."

Different quests introduce conditions that are at once fun, but on the other hand bulky. Sometimes I forget to enact an action for a turn or two and by then its too late to take moves back. Always makes me feel like I've wasted the game, and thus the time I've put into setting it up (mind you, once it is set up for a game it is easily re-set).

I could continue to invest but I've decided not to. I even have Adventure Packs, and some quests that I have never played. That means I have some card type I have also never seen (enemies, locations and so on).  

I've enjoyed the game but it's time for me to say farewell.

Good about the game: Small footprint.
Not good about the game: Complexity ramps up very quickly with each expansion.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I'm not a fan of LOTR nor am I a CCG player, so I'm not exactly the core demographic for this game. However, I'm really enjoying this game so far - I've only played the initial scenario solitaire with each of the starter decks. I'm looking forward to the remaining scenarios (even if they're harder) and expect I'll end up getting the expansions. Initial rating of 8.

10 plays: I can relate to all the comments and reviews regarding the difficulty of playing the second and third scenarios solitaire using monosphere starter decks out of the box - it's almost impossible to win. After winning 3 of my first 4 games solitaire against the initial scenario, I haven't won a game since. I'm not yet into deckbuilding, especially since this will be limited by the cards in the core set, but am contemplating playing two decks solitaire, as the game really seems to be designed for two players. Stays at 8.

20 plays: Still playing the core set, but have moved to "double fisting" solitaire. This is a more satisfying way to play using the core set and I've actually managed to win the second scenario. I've bought the first two expansions: [i]The Hunt for Gollum[/i] and [i]Conflict at the Carrock[/i] but am still concentrating on the core set for the time being. Stays at 8.

30 plays: Have finished all quests in the core set using all combinations of monosphere decks ("double fisting") and have now started playing through [i]The Hunt for Gollum[/i]. Stays at 8.

40 plays: Have just beaten [i]Conflict at the Carrock[/i] for the first time double fisting a Tactics and Lore deck. Looking forward to the rest of the [i]Shadows Over Mirkwood[/i] cycle and the upcoming [i]Khazad- DÃ»m[/i] expansion. Stays at 8.

50 plays: Have now played through the first four adventure packs. Whether the game goes to a 9 is likely to depend upon the greater variety and deckbuilding possibilities from future cards and whether new quests can keep the game fresh. Stays at 8.

60 plays: Have now played all [i]Shadows Over Mirkwood[/i] scenario packs. Thoroughly enjoying anticipating what's in store and listening to the [i]Cardboard of the Rings[/i] podcast. You guys rock! Rating increased to 9.

70 plays: Have started on [i]Khazad-DÃ»m[/i]. The ongoing release of scenarios is keeping the game fresh. Stays at 9.

80 plays: Have played through [i]Khazad-DÃ»m[/i] without much success. Will soon be starting on the [i]Dwarrowdelf[/i] cycle. Currently batting at 0.325. Stays at 9.

90 plays: Have now played through the first three [i]Dwarrowdelf[/i] adventure packs most recently culminating in a lucky win against [i]Watcher in the Water[/i] by correctly guessing the password for the Doors of Durin at the first attempt. Batting at 0.322. Stays at 9.

100 plays: Have reached the 100 game milestone and am still exploring possibilities with (and variants of) this game whilst still only scratching the deck building surface. Rating increased to 10!

150 plays: Have been working the COTR/10th Nazgul Progression Series. Currently playing through Heirs of Numenor. Still lots of replayability to come with the Ringmaker Cycle and the LOTR saga expansions. Stays at 10.

200 plays: This is the first game on BGG that I've played 200 times. Stays at 10.

RATING: 3
I can see the appeal for some, but not for me. For starters the very notion of questing was not fun or interesting for me. Seems like having to take a bet on how you could defeat monsters by tying one hand behind your back. I want to play cool characters to battle enemies or explore, not to tap them to randomly draw a card and see if I advance. That was the big downer for me. I also didn't really like the combat and engagement rules. The way that it played seemed like most of the challenge was early on in a play, as if you got past the early setup and got your engine working you could clear it easily.

The only thing that nags me a bit is the fact that the base box doesn't provide 3-of of all starter cards. Components are top notch, configurability is perfect, play time is in the sweet spot of 30-60 minutes and there is tons of fun to be had. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
(NH)
RATING: 9
GRADE: B+ 

Ratings feel tentative, but there's a lot to admire here.

The core system is an exciting start to what looks to be an expansive system.  The co-operative LCG is almost immodestly clever, and uniting it with the LotR theme is brilliant marketing AND evocative of theme.  Board games and C/LCGs have been maturing alongside one another for two decades now, exchanging ideas but largely functioning in separate worlds; this game feels like the true weaving-together of the two.  

As an LCG, the systems feel similar to the other FFG offerings.  It's logical despite being rather rules-heavy.  Artwork is great.  While CFarrel is right that the game clearly shares the DNA and bone structure of the ccg patriarch, LotR:TCG actually does feel like its own game rather than a half-cocked version of something like M:TG or L5R.  Old-time ccg players might find it irksome that defending characters do no damage in combat, but the combat system is otherwise cool.  When you have a bunch of allies and heroes with great attachments it does feel like you are fielding a potent fighting force.  

I like it as a co-op game.  In my experience cooperative games feel either thematic or puzzle-like (and sometimes both).  This game feels evocative of theme to me because time pressure is constant and character abilities feel right.  In a two-player game with single-sphere preconstructed decks, each player balances his particular role against the needs of the group.  One turn the fighters in the tactics deck might need to lend their modest contribution to questing; the next turn they may engage and destroy the heavies on the battlefield that would crush any other sphere's heroes.  The possibilities encourage much table-talk.

The scenarios are clever and somehow evocative despite being so tiny (just a couple phases, really).  There's plenty of game here, but this is where the episodic nature of the LCG could provide the most interesting flexibility in the system.  Here's to hoping FFG don't neuter this by deciding to only trickle quests out one card at a time.  

Deckbuilding has always been a solitary meta-game activity for me: you analyze your choices, put together a deck, run it through its paces with some dry runs.  It doesn't really make its debut until it gets some play time with another player.  The genius of Dominion, of course, is that it centralizes this meta-game aspect; it folds deck-building into the game play.  

In its solo mode, the LotR card game is unique in deck-building games in uniting the deck-building and gameplay halves, because once you're done building a deck you can play it immediately against the system.  Furthermore, because it can be hard to win with a single-sphere preconstructed deck, the system nudges you toward deck construction for solo play.  

Do the preconstructed single-sphere decks hum with Blue Moon-style mathematically perfect balance?  Does the game scale so as to provide an equivalent experience between solo single-deck play and 2-deck (2-player) play?  No.  But that's almost beside the point: with the core set you don't buy a single preconstructed deck.  You buy four, which means the game puts all the tools in your hand for you to construct and tune the gameplay experience to get out of it what you want.  

There's also always a vocal number of people who whinge about the need for multiple core sets of these games, but most gamers will find plenty to love in a single core set.  Yet the episodic story-style of the scenarios also makes the possibility of expansions exciting.  

If FFG can fashion nuance and distill strengths in future expansions, they'll have a legend on their hands.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A highly immersive thematic co-op.

The combination of excellent art, a well implemented theme and excellent flow of play creates a very fun game. In addition the game is difficult, as a good co-op should be, but not to the point of frustration. A typical session will keep you constantly involved and a mission won't play the same twice.

I really liked this game, to the point that I'm reversing my opinion on LCGs.. If every LCG base game is as good, complete and replayable as this, then I don't mind the million expansions but on the contrary I'm happy with them!

After 500 plays: The game still amazes me with its replayability. Some minor issues have started to annoy me, but not to the point of ruining the experience:
a)Thematic inconsistencies like a single goblin/spider/orc enemy with inprobable stats causing great havoc to a whole band of heroes could have easily been solved by making said goblin/spider/orc appear as a band/group in the card text/art without changing a single thing in gameplay.
b)As the game develops, the cards developed seem to drift even more slighly from the original lotr design to standard fantasy design - especially with the nightmare packs that on occasion are an absolute thematic nightmare. 
c)The card balance is gradually failing as more and more tough scenarios require better deckbuilding - and this has created pools of great, great on occassion, decent and poor cards detracting from the replayability and hurting variety.

Nearing 750 plays:
Finally this game begins to drop in my preferences. It takes an amazing game to reach 750 plays really, and Lotr has my respect totally. The rating reflects my feelings for it now, at the start it was a pure 10 of course.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is my first CCG or LCG and I was a bit reluctant to get into this type of game. I'm also not a huge fan of other cooperative games, finding them lacking in variability and/or feeling more like one player puzzles with a few other players sitting in. I ultimately chose this as my entry into the genre because my younger daughter is a huge fan of all things LOTR and I wanted a regular game to share with her. 

Now, after 40+ plays working our way through the core set scenarios and the entire Mirkwood cycle, I can say that I'm pleasantly surprised by the gameplay experience, and above all the variety of experiences this game has offered. Some scenarios are great (Journey down the Anduin, Conflict at the Carrock) and others are weaker (Hills of Emyn Muil, Dead Marshes) but the game itself has easily stood the test of all those plays and has us ready to revisit some favorite scenarios with newer cards and then dive into Khazad Dum and the Dwarrowdelf cycle. 

Update -- about 8 months and another 40+ plays later and still going strong with this game. Now halfway through Dwarrowdelf cycle and deciding whether to go to Hobbit saga or Heirs of Numenor next, but will inevitably get both. Considering making this my fifth 10 rating.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A living card game that is a coop.  This combination is such an obvious combination.  Obvious after someone else comes up with the idea.  My biggest problem with a living card game is the lack of dedicated opponent and the fear if I skipped an expansion pack I would be behind the curve if I did have a regular opponent.  Coop games have a finite number of plays until the random elements determine the outcome, and it becomes stale.  New excitement released on a regular basis.  A game design which addresses my biggest hurdles in two types of games.  Wow, such a great idea.

I'm not a Fantasy Flight Games guy.  I'm not a LOTR fan.  I also don't plan to play this solo, except for possible "new deck testing". Out of sheer curiousity and cautious optimism I preordered my copy.  Two plays in, I'm glad I did.  The different factions play differently. The different decks are far more unique in scope than say the Scientist and the Researcher (Pandemic).  

The deck building is underdeveloped at this point in time. Especially with two players, but the core set has me excited for when the system is fully fleshed out, and it has enough variety to keep things interesting without the expansion packs.

This may be a delicate system going forward, and FFG has their hands full keeping the difficulty in the right balance.  Other coops now have a new bar to clear as far as I'm concerned.  Your move coop designers.  

Its a nice depth.  By no means a brainburner, but enough meat for a gamer to chew on.

It may be thematic, but I'm not the person whose comments you should be reading if that is important to you.  I didn't want to finish the book and liked about 1.5 of the movies.  I still dig the game based on mechanisms and the fun factor.

6 plays in now.  Its very enjoyable.  There are quite a bit of bells and whistles to explore.  This is not going to be stale any time soon.

I have no desire to join a tournament, for me this system will be a gigantic sandbox for me to try things out and a nice social game for me and another player.  The core set leads me to believe this is exactly what I had hoped.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Feels more like a puzzle to solve instead of a game.

2014 comment update: Now with the sheer number of cards available, deckmaking seems more of a chore than solo fun. Playing still seems like a puzzle to solve.

RATING: 6
This game is okay. I really did love the game at first. But after a couple plays, me and my friend really decided that while the deck-building was unique, the game really lacked in design. The core set is a very good example here. We have tried and tried to beat the last quest in the cores set, with just the core set cards, to no avail. One would have to buy the whole Mirkwood cycle to even beat the last quest! That is outrageous if you ask me. Another good example is the fact that you can lose on turn one to the encounter deck. This is a very bad game design aspect. Apart from that, the theme is AMAZING and the art is superb. This would really be a legendary game if it was better designed and re-playable.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Beautiful card art, layout/card chrome, and several cool mechanics and synergies make persisting with it worthwhile. Just know: this game is hard. Really hard. That said I love nearly everything about it: the flavor is firing on all cylinders, theme comes through in mechanics big time. Each quest is very unique, and deck construction is quite important if you intend to overcome even the "easy" quests. I'm not going to claim I'm a brilliant strategist, but I am a consummate gamer of many stripes, and I can comfortably say this game is NOT for casual gamers in any way. If it wasn't so dammed cool I'd probably toss it, because I don't normally have the patience/attention span or the time required to succeed at something like this. Mostly the deck construction is what I'm too lazy for, but even playing it over and over to learn what NOT to do before that first successful run through a level, which is of course insanely rewarding given the time you've spent on it. If you like a challenge, enjoy extremely thematic games with a good bit of [painful!] crunch to them, or if you simply must have every LotR or FFG product in your collection - buy now. Even if you don't, though, it seems like this one will be around a long time. It sells well, and FFG have what I assume is their most successful tournament product in this line. So unless they lose the Tolkien license (like they did with the Game's Workshop one... Sigh) I expect they'll wring another 3-5 years out of it, easily.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Love this game.  On the heavy/complex side, and If you are going to play 2 player, you need to find someone you know is into the source material :)  If you are finding it hard to get a LOTR fan friend as huge as yourself, it is a SOLO game too!!!

Quite difficult early on. Lots of replay, and it is an LCG so I guess you can also buy more replay value.

My favourite thing is that the game is based on the original material (with some small liberties and emeblishments :) without pandering to the films.  This is NOT a film cash in game.  The artwork and lore is detailed and they dont use any photo stills from the movie or feel the need to make artwork look like actors etc.

Artwork is great.

Manual is like a small novella - but once you get into it they are some of the most clear rules ive read with loads of example pictures and walkthroughs of phases.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Even though the game offers some opportunities for players to support each other with events and attachments, Lord Of The Rings is mostly a solitaire experience in which heroes are pitted against a deck of monsters and random event cards. Especially in the Quest Phase, it feels like the outcome of a "battle" is at the mercy of the staging cards drawn that round and can therefore feel pretty unfair. I love the artwork of the game and the atmosphere that both drawings and flavour text convey, but the game can easily drag and the learning curve is far too steep for casual gamers. Hard to wholheartedly recommend, even though I would not mind playing it again. Your mileage may vary, especially if you enjoy deckbuilding (unlike me).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Think it's much better with 2 players then 1.

RATING: 7
Ugh, this game is just too hard for mere mortals. Unless you love building and tweaking decks (who on earth has time for that and how bloody dull!) then stay away. It was the hobbit saga that pushed me over the edge....bloody impossible!

OK, I saw Ava Jarvis's blog about using the easy rules to make it playable and to enjoy the narrative. I will try it again...

... I did and the Hobbit saga is STILL unplayable! 

Another update!
I have taken deck lists from the Hall of Beorn website and and am working through the core set with them; I'm hoping I learn enough to be able to play the Saga expansions. This is far too much trouble to go to for a card game - why oh why did FFG make this series unplayable by anyone except super serious gamers with unlimited free time to spend on deck building, a tiny minority surely? I'm only hanging in to recoup the money I stupidly spent on expansions! It's a crying shame, actual playtime is dwarfed by deck preparation and continual tweaking.

RATING: 7.5
I like the production values.  Nice cards neat threat counter.  Great art.  The rule book is daunting, but clearly written.

Once you get the hang of it gameplay is fairly straight  forward.  The theme was prevalent throughout the scenario.  I like the way the enemies are tailored to your location.

All in all a fun system.  My only complaint would be replayability out of the box.  The quest packs are going to be essential to keep this game alive.

Edit: Traded.  Though the game is excellent.  Deck building is not my thing.

RATING: 7
One of the most truly cooperative co-ops I own. If you aren't intimidated by the card game nuanced rules or put off by the theme this can be a rewarding (but often brutal) gaming experience. One of the best solo games I have played (rate it an 8). Lots of choices, lots of fun.
------------------------------------------

After many games and hours of enjoyment I am finding that the LCG format may not be for me. I like the idea of picking more adventures that look fun and purchasing them, however, the new player cards in each set seem to build on each other encouraging the completionists. There could still be more mileage in this one for me if I can find some one else as interested in the deck building aspect of the game. As it stands I feel like I've played out the scenarios that I have and none of the new ones really grab me.

RATING: 10
Absolutely brilliant. The deck-building and tactical depth of Magic the Gathering and the thematic feel of Arkham Horror. The monthly quest packs mean there's always a new challenge, but the different colours/deck styles/varied encounter deck means each quest has lots of replay ability. 

Don't be put off by the Lord of the Rings theme, if you're not into that sort of thing. The thematic feel is immersive hunt or battle, etc.

RATING: 5
This is a mighty fiddly game, and I'm very glad that I had someone to teach it to me, since I had such a hard time getting the basic order of the turn down.  It has some neat mechanisms that keep the game going (I especially like the balances among the quest, the strength, and the action on the cards), but ultimately it's a cooperative game, and they still more or less elude me.  It's a fine enough design, but I would much rather play a game where I'm going up against someone else instead of us all working together.  That being said, kudos to the designer for having all players keep their cards hidden instead of sharing them (though, of course, I was asking advice from my more-experienced cohort).

This is probably a game that I admire more than I like.  Nothing wrong with that, but it's clearly not the game for me.

2 plays: 2 players

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
A bit disappointed with this game. It comes across as a clever card game with the LOTR theme tacked on. Though advertised as a solo game, it tries to do too much, catering for everyone, being two player aswell, and even more players can be added on. So much so, that only a few games can be played solo, some are so hard that you need more than one player.

I can't really get into the theme. For instance, in the Passage through Mirkwood scenario, why are major and critical personages (eg Aragorn, Glorfindel) risking life and limb merely to deliver an obvious message to Galadriel that things are getting worse? Why can dwarves have multiple axes with cumulative bonuses? Why do some characters quest and others fight, are they a party sticking together or are they all doing their own thing? BUT those that are away questing and cannot fight can still get injured during a fight, so not sure what the logic is here.

As a positive, Gandalf is nicely represented, he acts as he does in the books, comes when there is trouble, then goes away. And the game can be fun to play.

I do find it hard to rationalize what is happening in the game, and many of the cards introduce new rules that can be difficult to figure out.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
One of the best games I've played for a very long time.

RATING: 9.25
After so many plays...I should probably rate this game. This rating is mid-Darrowdelf cycle. I love this cooperative game. Difficult and forces you to rebuild your deck, probably my favorite of the LCG format, as it really requires you to be able to adapt to the quest. 

It could become burdensome as we have to remember all the cards (we are starting from the beginning, which helps us know the card pool), and sometimes you just get a bad set of cards to come out either from your hand or the encounter deck...but we just reset and go again.

RATING: 9
A great game for 2 players. You can build decks and try them on the three different quests. The rules are not very difficult, but there are some card interactions where you need the rules or the FAQ.
Passage through Mirkwood is developed to learn the game and is very easy.
In Journey down the Anduin there are two difficult moment: beating the Hill Troll in the beginning and the beginning of stage 3 where all the enemies can engage you.
Escape from Dul Guldur is difficult to win. One of your hero's is captured at the start and when he's rescued a Nazgul comes into play. The fact that players can only play one ally makes it hard.

RATING: 7
I'm struggling with my opinion on this one. On one hand, it's certainly a well designed game that accomplishes exactly what it sets out to do, namely providing a challenging co-op experience for players to work through together. On the other hand, I'm just not feeling great about constantly re-building decks to take on the new adventure packs, especially when it's possible (and advisable) to look through the shadow deck and put in counters to everything it can throw at you. It just feels like a waste of time.

I've played it a ton, so it is a good game. It feels like a souped-up version of Space Hulk: Death Angel, which is pretty high praise. I just think my desire to spend time building decks for what is essentially a solitaire game is running a little thin. I might trade it or I might buy more expansions. I just can't figure out where I'm going with this one...

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The game is VERY difficult to play solitaire. The main problem is the lack of ressources and "cheap cost" cards in the Core Set. Being beaten 3 of 4 times by the first scenario after (re)building a deck is very unfair. There are many really nasty "when revealed" and "shadow" effects. This leads to the problem, that although the game is pretty exciting, it is very demotivating to lose twice in 3 hours, damn! Perhaps I should stick to playing solo without dealing Shadow cards...

Thus, the mechanics create a very gloomy game, but you still have a little control (not as random as Arkham Horror). Sometimes, I forget the thematic flaws and enjoy... 
But now my rant:

1. Already 4 Card Errata in the Core Set. 3 of them captured in the FAQ v1.1, 1 captured here:
http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/678604/wandering-took-question

So, I wonder, how many more card mistakes and misprints are still to come with the expansions. Someday one will need a sheet with only card errata printed, to play the game and to have fun, which is absurd! Please FFG, reprint the incorrect cards and put them in the Core Set and/or expansions. Like Plaid Hat Games did it with Thorkur from Summoner Wars.

2. Mediocre/bad theme implementation.
a) So playing "Steward of Gondor" on Aragorn would mean a messenger reaches the heroes and informs Aragorn about becoming a Steward of Gondor?!?! WTF? Why now, on the way through Mirkwood? How can 3 Heroes all be Stewards of Gondor? And what about Denethor? Completely unthematic, it's a pity.

b) Also, why can't your character attack the enemy after he defended? Oh, he is so exhausted! Damn it!

c) Also, why can't your characters attack enemies in the staging area when they are questing? What the hell are they doing there???

d) Also, you can lose a scenario, because some DARN BATS chased your hero away from questing thus you lose because of the Threat coming from distant locations like the Old Forest Road or the Forest Mountains! Oh, come on, BATS chased Aragorn away because he was the only one questing. That's ridiculous!

e) Also, in the scenario Journey down the Anduin, your heroes, already travelled through Mirkwood towards Lorien, arrive in the Brown Lands!!! Oh, come on!

EDIT: Won the first time, still playing the 1. Scenario without dealing Shadow cards. This way, it is still very random, but not so random as Arkham Horror.

[b]Pro[/b]:
- the enemy AI and the card abilties + effects function well, sometimes too well :\
- you can build a deck and try it out solo... and rebuild it...
- 2-3 hours play time
- suspenseful game
- rules: good turn summary including the timing when you may play actions

[b]Contra[/b]:
- card errata
- bad theme implementation
- very difficult game, especially for the beginners, no rules included to [b]really[/b] scale the difficulty (so play at least without dealing Shadow cards the first couple of games)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
I was very optimistic about this game but it let me down seriously. Main is the difficulty curve when enemies/locations are coming into game. Every turn the same amount of monsters/locations arrives, and difficulty is increasing in flat growing line. At the same time player can expand his power exponentially for some time (with cards like Steward of Gondor if I remember that name correctly). Problem is, if you don't handle monsters/locations from the first turn, that exponential growth will come too late. And if you're able to handle, then it's not a big issue to push a bit forward and start growing power. All it boils down whether you can match game difficulty curve (=line) with your power curve. Once you match, you won. So you lose very fast and know you'll win very fast (except that actual winning drags a lot). That's a lot different from MTG (well MTG is not solitaire, but I think it can be compared), where you aren't so forced to keep tempo and can have some slower or faster strategies. in LOTR LCG, game forces it's tempo thus reducing available strategies.
Plus, it's disappointing money-wise that there's only single copy of some key cards like Unexpected Courage so you need 3 base boxes. I have Android Netrunner which has similar problem with singles for some cards, but at least in Netrunner the singles aren't so critical (except for some very specific decks) so Netrunner is fine with 2 base boxes in almost all cases.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

8/4/12: Buying again for solo play.

8/9/12: I'm very happy I bought this game again. Solo play is difficult and it's a lot of numbers going on, but it feels much more thematic for some reason. [hr]

8/10/12: Three more plays and I'm eyeing the rest of the collection, what a game! Rating moved to a 10.

[hr]

November 29, 2014: I used to love this game, but I just don't play it nearly as much as I once did. I think this is mostly due to deckbuilding. I'd rather put more time into Netrunner which gets played versus this. Still, if you're willing to put the time into it, it's a wonderful game.

[hr]

March 31, 2015: This game has turned into a 6 for me and is being sold. I've had a love/hate relationship with this game from the moment I initially purchased it and I'm simply not spending enough time to play this game well and enjoy it any longer. It's still a wonderful game, but I'm no longer interested in playing.

RATING: 7
We currently own all of the expansions for this game.

Beautiful cards and the theme comes through well in gameplay and the quests. I was taken with the ability of this game to immerse the player into the fantasy of Lord of the Rings. The wins, and losses, all felt like a true result of the players decisions, be they mine in solo play, or the table as a group.  Encounters were the only luck factor, so chance was not rampant, but natural. One is wisked away for the duration of the game into danger, suspense, victories, sacrifices and adventure...all with a deck of cards. Good solo play as well.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Lays Potato Chips.  A game that I can't stop at just one.  

This game is a masterful design.  It amazes me at how easily it flows.  A twenty-five page rulebook which explains seven phases of every turn shouldn't play so smoothly!  Or create such an immersive experience.

But even as I'm playing, my mind is bubbling with imaginative pictures of spiders attacking me as I walk a narrow pathway through forests.

It can be frustrating, no doubt.  But even as I am logging my latest loss, I'm contemplating my next scenario.  Good stuff.

Beautiful artwork, quick play, endless re-playability.  A  wonderful game.  :) 

Edited 2-19-13--------

I left the game for about a year.  I wasn't able to defeat the second scenario and became a bit frustrated.  I wasn't angry with the game, I just realized that I would have to start deck-building to progress and I didn't want to do that at the time.  

I never did a deck-build in my gaming life and it intimidated me.  A month and a half ago, I went back to it after delving into the LotR:LCG forums in addition to watching videos.

I began to deck-build then fell in love.  This is the finest game I've ever played by a wide margin.  It's amazing how much this game consumes my thoughts.  I love the theme, the quick set-up, the game mechanics, the brain-burn, the sense of accomplishment I feel when I beat a scenario, the knowledge that new adventures will continue to come out, adding to my pleasure.

I have recently bought every expansion to date.  It wasn't cheap, but I know this will engage me for years.

Solo play or with others, it delivers an extremely immersive experience.  Negatives for the game are mere quibbles.  I will warn you that this game isn't easy, but it is beatable.  Don't expect to pick it up and have a chance if you aren't willing to put some thought into it and take your lumps along the way.

New Rating:  10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.8
After 10-15 plays in 2-3 players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Sept 2011: Our initial plays were engrossing hikes through Tolkien-land that have us looking forward to additional sessions.

Nov 2012: With two base sets, a few expansion packs, and 3-4 players, LOTR is great fun.  Just a fantastic design.

June 2017:  The game is as mathy as it's always been, but LoTR but is now a mainstay as a 3-player family gaming experience (adults + older teens).  After an extended break from LoTR - devoted almost exclusively to consecutive [url=https://boardgamegeek.com/boardgamefamily/23234/pathfinder-adventure-card-game]Pathfinder ACG[/url] campaigns - we're back in the Middle Earth saddle. My dusty expansions have finally been opened and enjoyed.

Jan 2018: We've completed everything up to and including The Lost Realms block, with a focus on constructing interesting but effective generalist decks.  We don't have the time or motivation to fine-tune our homebrew builds over 5-10 plays to beat each scenario, so in some cases we play on easy or semi-easy mode (see below) to keep things moving. Our next goal is to complete the Saga expansions in campaign mode; at the moment, we're halfway through.

[i]Note[/i]: The 9 rating is for the LoTR LCG as an extended experience that includes all releases - not just for the core set.

And even though the LoTR LCG is a top 10 game for me, it isn't without its flaws:

- The game can be sensitive to the exact cards that come out on set-up. It can crash and burn almost immediately, causing you to lose in just a few turns.
- Certain scenarios aren't balanced for certain player counts.  Some are much easier with 3-4 players, while others become impossible.  The reverse is also true: Some are a cakewalk with 1-2 players, while others are blatantly unfair with low player counts.
- In some cases stated difficulty levels simply aren't accurate.  Usually in the direction of "more difficult" - but not always.

Glossary:

Official FFG easy mode: Double starting resources, gold-bordered ("difficult") encounter cards removed.

Semi-easy mode #1: Standard resources, difficult cards removed.

Semi-easy mode #2: Double starting resources, no cards removed.

Before Heirs of Numenor, we pretty much only played in standard mode. Starting with HoN, we took the following approach: standard mode for scenarios ranked 5 or lower (with key exceptions in each block), and for 6+ difficulty we use semi-easy mode #1 or #2 as the scenario requires or the mood strikes us.  In extreme cases (i.e., stupidly impossible or just annoying) we revert to true easy mode. And sometimes even that doesn't help.

Final Thoughts: From a money perspective, LoTR hasn't been a great buy. Spending $13 for a few player cards and a single scenario (played twice at most) doesn't seem like the wisest financial decision.  But from a leisure and long-term campaign perspective, it's been awesome.  And someday the kids will enjoy replaying the entire series with their own kids and adult friends, or maybe they'll go the solo route.  So they'll get eventually get my money's worth even if I don't. Or at least that's what I keep telling myself.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
I was sure that I will never get into any CCG/LCG type card games. This one convinced me though using its solo mode. Now I do not need a gaming partner that is keeping up with all the nre cards. I can buy expansions as fast or as slow as I feel like ... GREAT

As for the game - it is so thematic and so hard that it just keeps coming to the table. I love the strategy part (deck building) and mostly tactic part (playing the scenario with a constructed deck) - amazing. 

Victory in LOTR:LCG tastes great!

Drawbacks :
- Sometimes bad luck will spoil your plans and in some scenarios you need ton of luck (at least with basic cards) to have a shot at winning at all.
- If you get into it (which means that you love it) it might be hard on your wallet.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.88
It is an interesting game but it seems a bit limited by and to its quest mechanism. When a quest becomes challenging, it is usually time to customise and optimise decks in order to make life easier and more fun (for those who like to win at least). However, that deck only serves to defeat a particular quest, contrary to CCG decks which are always challenged by new opponents/tactics. With CCG, one can aim for the absolute winning machine. Here it is merely a case of arranging cards together to beat the odds more often.
However, I tend to like it a lot. Its difficulty is often reinforced by the randomness of the hand and of the drawing of cards. Sometimes even fate cannot be overcome... That means that one should be prepared to lose a lot. Then if one gets discouraged, his impression will be one of repeated failure and utterly displeasing gaming experience. If one takes the challenge and tries to beat the quests, he may well spend days and days between metagaming and actual gaming. In the end, if one can win more than lose, he had a satisfying solution to the problem. Replayability is quite high with that in mind.
Solo game is enjoyable and probably a better source of metagaming. Two players games are probably a good way to work ahead of optimising a solo deck. They generate more ennemies per turn, but the players can tackle the main hurdles with much more possibilities.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Ah LotR LCG, how I love thee.  If my gaming den were to light ablaze and there was only time to grab one game on my way out, you would likely be the one.  Although I'd likely perish running back in for the others.. :P

My [b]Game of the Year: 2013[/b]

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Really happy with this game. It has lots of positive things going for it: great art, easy to follow rules in a good rule book, interesting co-op element, a stiff challenge and above all it's just a lot of fun to play -  win or lose. One of my favourite games in recent years. 

One of the set backs of the game is the time-consuming deck building and tweaking process. With every new deluxe box and adventure pack cycle the encounter deck throws new challenges at the players. This is a good thing since it keeps the game fresh but as the card-pool increases it takes longer and longer to prepare decks for the specific challenge posed by each quest. The game demands a lot of your time outside of the actual playing experience and this can create a bit of a barrier to wanting to pull this game out and play it.

Approaching a year since we last played, game currently sits in a plastic bin in the garage.

We pulled it out again and have started working through the adventures from the beginning. It brings back a lot of fond memories, we're having a great time playing this again.

The journey through the deluxe expansions is going strong, we are into the last quest of the Lost Realms  box after 87 games in this run I'm feeling more into the game than ever. I recently bought more saga expansions and the Dreamchaser cycle. Once we reach the end of the Harad cycle I think we'll start on the Sagas.

+ Mirkwood cycle, Kazad Dum cycle, Numenor Cycle, Isengard cycle, Lost Realms, Hobbit Saga, Lord of the Rings saga pt 1.

< April 2012

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
1. World-class art on EVERY card.
2. It's Lord of the Rings.
3. It is festooned with giant spiders.

You now know all that you need.

Plus, it's rock-hard solo!

Very good. Quite clever.
Extremely enjoyable solo, and this game can (and will) increase in enjoyment with every new card released.
I won't buy more than one pack of anything - no need. BUT I will be adding all the new cards as they appear. I will very much enjoy making decent hero decks - when there are vast numbers of cards to choose from, and I can limit every card to a maximum of one (Highlander style).

If this gets a mega-adventure pack, with a 6-10 encounter card [i]Mines of Moria[/i] adventure, and/or a decent [i]Cirith Ungol and Shelob's Lair[/i] set, I'll probably rate this game 8+. Maybe.

The short and sweet of what I don't care for, ma'am:

I think I preferred LoTR as a solo game, as opposed to some 2-player games we played later. Then it just appeared a bit too fiddly and overwrought for a 'quick' 2-player card game. Plus you don't really get a full game in the box - you really do need more cards to play it more than a dozen times, I think. I still will only buy one base set, however.

Some things felt lacklustre: lack of epic quest, and could have done with a greater number of quicker adventure stages, we found. I dislike the fact that after a while the locations just keep 'piling' into the staging area. Also (my biggest dislike) why do the main characters have to tap to complete the main quest? They can't then defend against the skittering hordes of spiders, or biting orc blades - what gives with that! Surely it's more heroic to fight the critters, not tap to add [i]determination[/i] or whatever it's called, to overcome the shadow's threat.

So I like it, but it's a little counter-theme in places.

RATING: 10
Another great game by FFG. I especially love this game because it can be played Solo or with up to 3 other friends (with another core set or enough expansions). The pacing can be annoying if you encounter too many monsters or vice verse with too many locations. Then again, that's the lite deck building aspect to the game as well. FFG sets you up with a difficulty number and it's up to you to decide how to handle the deck you're adventuring through with the four different spheres of influence. Not only this but it's a LCG (living card game) so a new pack to the cycle comes out each month to further the story line and new cards to your set.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
We had a blast with this in the beginning but now haven't played in in quite some time. Some quests (I'm looking at you, quest where you start with a friggin' troll) are incredibly hit-or-miss. I guess a valid complaint with this game is the fact that you either lose quickly and painfully or you just get stronger and steamroll through everything with very little in-between. Still, it's LOTR (which the mrs. loves) and we've enjoyed it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
I really like the mechanics of this game and the fact that it is co-op. There is a lot of thinking involved, but much like many card games there is luck of the draw as well. Each quest is going to have a different feel every time you play them based on what cards come out. It does add to replay value as well as occasional frustration. The game is balanced enough so that you usually have a fighting chance. (some of the more challenging quests can be a pain.)

The game does have a bit of a learning curve and I suggest watching the tutorial on Fantasy Flights website over reading the rulebook alone.

RATING: 7
Immersive
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Another great LCG from Fantasy flight. An easy to learn cardgame that shines in solo play. But is also good with others. The various quests feel different. FFG is getting more and more creative with the quest system. There is a lot of flavour and the game catches the spirit of LOTR universe. 

Some concerns : 
There might be some power creep after a few expansion (though the quests get harder each cycle).  And the difficulty rating of the quests is off track (this is mostly because a box expansion takes all cards of a cycle into account). However the quests are always thematical and thought out well.  

The deckbuilding with this game is awesome, there's a lot of interesting combinations and decks to be explored. There are a lot of submitted decks online but it more rewarding to find your own best deck. 

Thoughts after several expansions:
The game is still as hard as ever. Nightmare packs make the easier scenario's of the base set harder. The cards have remained as thematically as ever. New mechanism have been introduced that capture the spirit of the particular lotr quests. Game is in a very good healthy state. 

This or Arkham lcg ? 
While Arkham does ameliorate the gameplay in certain parts like location exploration, it does add the tokens and tests that make it much more random and annoying. Also lotr has made more cards that make interacting with locations better. 
The decks are very small so fewer deckbuilding if at all. Deckbuilding is just more interesting in lotr.

RATING: 6


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The artwork is beautiful, and I like the game mechanics and theme, but I found that my enjoyment of the game waned significantly with repeated plays.  I liked the difficulty, but I've found that, without an aggressive and strategic mix of players, not only will you lose frequently (which in and of itself is fine), but you'll begin to feel like you're engaging in an uphill battle by yourself.  This isn't the game's fault, of course, but I think it is illustrative of the key challenge in co-op style games.  Through my first several plays of this game, I really enjoyed it, but, since then, it has begun to ruin my enjoyment for co-operative games, though I haven't quite figured out why this game in particular has done that for me, where games like Arkham Horror, for example, haven't.  Maybe it's because it all boils down to the luck-of-the-draw reality of a card game; maybe I simply prefer a string of bad dice rolls instead of a string of mediocre hands of cards.  On the other hand, I'm a huge fan of Combat Commander, where a "string of bad cards" increases the tension of the game, and there's always the chance that fate will shift back into your favor -- in LotR:TCG, however, it just means the game is all but completely lost once you start to lose your footing.  Yup, I think that's the key reason this game has dipped down a bit for me.

Update:  Gah!  It's back up to a 9 for me, but I've decided to only play it solo.  I really enjoy the challenge of creating a good deck for a given quest, then testing it, tweaking it, and so forth.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
